TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. A short time ago I asked the Minister about foreign ownership of rural land in Australia. Since then, I have had several reports expressing concern on this subject. The main concern of people is that Australian rural land may be owned by nationals alien to our democracy. I ask the Minister whether the Government, in consultation with the States, will seriously consider setting up a Federal register of land ownership in Australia.

—I well recall the earlier question that was asked by Senator Elstob. The Government would share his anxiety if it could be revealed that there were trends leading to serious and significant foreign ownership of land, particulary rural land. I had indicated that primarily the matter is one of State sovereignty, although one does not resile from a Federal responsibility in terms of the entry of investment capital. I had traversed the ground concerning how difficult it is to trace investment capital through its various stages. Whilst I would not comment at this moment on the idea of having a Federal register, as such-it may present some difficulties in a federation-there is obvious merit in having consultation at the Federal-State level to consider the problem. As I understand the honourable senator, he is seeking a solution of the problem rather than the employment of a particular mechanism. I will refer the matter to the relevant Ministers who would be, I believe, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, and ask them to give it consideration. I believe that in fact the Treasurer already has under consideration the general question of the direction of investment funds in Australia. Our primary interest is to ensure, as far as possible, that a significant proportion of inflowing funds should be in the form of investment capital in developmental works which would employ Australians, not simply provide foreign ownership. In that spirit, I will refer the general principle of the question to the relevant Ministers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASPECT HOUSE AND CHILD CARE FUNDING

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to Aspect House, the crisis and respite centre for handicapped children in Hobart. The Minister last week said that he was considering the comments of parents on the report on the continuing funding of the centre. Is it a fact that the Minister has now decided that Aspect House will not receive recurrent funding from this Government? Is it also a fact that a similar decision has been made in relation to the Tasmanian Aboriginal Child Care Centre in Launceston? Why has the Government taken this attitude, if it has? If these decisions have been made, why have the organisations concerned not been informed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am frightfully chuffed by the fact that the honourable senator's source of information is so inaccurate. I am used to people getting all sorts of information from all sorts of places. The honourable senator seems to be grossly misinformed. I welcome this new development in Federal Government affairs. However, the matter of Aspect House is still under consideration. As I indicated before, I have been in close consultation with State Government Ministers from the honourable senator's home State. The matter is still receiving consideration at State Government level. I expect to speak again to the new Minister concerned, Mr Adams, later this week. I indicated before that the two governments were working together on the problem, and that is still the situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Aspect House received funding from the Commonwealth through the family support services scheme, a scheme which provides funds on the recommendation of the State government. So there has been a close involvement of both governments from the beginning in respect of Aspect House. That is continuing and I will at the earliest opportunity let the Senate know what the decision is with respect to Aspect House. I would, however, expect to make Aspect House aware of that decision before I make a public announcement because I think that would be the proper and polite thing to do. There are, as the honourable senator would know, a number of people who are very concerned about that situation. I have not responded to the detailed submission they have put in. I therefore will not make any announcement in this place until they have had a proper and formal reply to the views they put to me and to the Tasmanian State Government.

With respect to the Tasmanian Aboriginal child care agency, again I am a little mystified as to why the honourable senator should assume that it is not to be funded. There has been a quite long history to this matter, which may be the reason for the honourable senator's statement. I think most honourable senators would know that there was a proliferation of Aboriginal child care agencies under the administration of this portfolio by my predecessor, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who funded first the Victorian agency. Since then agencies have been funded in most States but not yet in Tasmania. A proposition put forward by a Tasmanian group has been under detailed consideration between the group and my Department and I think, again, relevant State authorities. I have looked at papers on that within the last 24 hours. I am not sure of the propriety of making an announcement here, but I can say to the Senate that funds are to be provided to the Tasmanian agency to provide some services in that State.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: ABORIGINAL LIAISON OFFICERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister approved the employment of 10 part time Aboriginal liaison officers for the Department of Social Security in Queensland? If so, why has the Minister refused to approve the employment of Aboriginal liaison officers in outback central Australia where English is not spoken or written by a large number of Aboriginal people? Is the Minister aware that, because of a lack of assistance available to Aboriginal people seeking social security benefits, many eligible people, particularly women seeking the family allowance, are not receiving the benefits to which they are entitled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not think I have approved the appointment of 10 part time Aboriginal liaison officers in Queensland. I was in Alice Springs a week or two ago and I spoke there with the Aboriginal liaison officer in Alice Springs. I can assure the honourable senator that we do have Aboriginal liaison officers in central Australia. We do not have our full complement at the moment. I think we are seeking at least one additional recruit. One Aboriginal liaison officer who was there retired recently. I think the allocation for that part of Australia is three.

ANSWER.PARA: There may be some confusion in the honourable senator's question with our proposal to appoint some paid agents of the Department on an experimental basis. That was announced at Budget time. The proposal is that, in centres where there is an inadequate volume of work to justify a full time officer of the Department, we might see whether the appointment of a part time paid agent might provide a useful link between the Department and the clients it seeks to serve. That is an experiment. The locations in which those paid agents will be appointed have not yet been determined. I am awaiting recommendations from my Department. But it is anticipated that they will be appointed in a variety of types of communities, including some Aboriginal communities, so that we can get an idea of whether that is a successful way of extending the contact between my Department and its clients in the more remote parts of Australia.

I will, however, check the Aboriginal liaison officer position generally. It may be that the number in Queensland is 10. I am sorry that I do not recollect the precise arrangements, but I will let the honourable senator have a more detailed reply. It is certainly true that there are difficulties in terms of client contact in parts of central Australia. At places such as Yuendumu the local Aboriginal council has itself employed someone to do liaison work between the Department and the community. This is an area in which the Government and the Department are concerned to ensure effective service delivery and we are looking to making continuing improvements in this area.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to the positioning of the proposed domestic satellite over New Caledonia instead of the Northern Territory as originally planned. Is the Minister aware that many people in Western Australia are concerned that services will be greatly reduced by this move, and that the concern is largely generated by articles which quote an eminent space scientist, Dr Brian O'Brian, who claims that an erratic attenuation effect will be created by the signals slanting through longer sections of the atmosphere? Will the Minister inform the Senate as to the correct position and, I hope, put to rest the concern expressed by many Western Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Thomas comes from Geraldton he would have a very keen interest for himself and his constituents in whether the satellite is properly placed. I am aware that some people in Western Australia have expressed concern about the planned orbital position of the satellite. The early planning proposals placed the satellite in an orbit above the Equator at a position, I understand, 128 degrees east, which is aligned with the Western Australian border with the Northern Territory. Following further studies and advice from two international consultants, it was decided to place the satellite at 160 degrees east. This is the basis of the concern expressed by Senator Thomas. The planned position of the satellite does not disadvantage Western Australia; in fact, to the contrary. I think that is the important point to make. From that position further east Australia will look narrower than it would from a position above the Equator.

ANSWER.PARA: The signal strength of the transmission received from the satellite by Western Australia will actually be greater, not less, than it would be if the satellite were placed north of Australia. I am advised, although I do not claim to be a physicist, that this arises from application of the basic laws of physics. I am not told which basic laws of physics, but I have no reason to doubt what I have been told. I understand that this will mean that the beam will be narrower and therefore more concentrated on the target area. The matters have been discussed with the Western Australian Government and it acknowledges that the location of the satellite, as specified in the request to the tenderer, will not disadvantage Western Australia. I think that is the point that Senator Thomas was trying to bring out.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: SOCIAL WORKERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Department of Social Security recently conducted a reassessment of social workers within that Department? Will this reassessment lead to a decline in the number of social workers in some regional offices of the Department, as feared by many people in these regions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In strict terms, the answer to the honourable senator's initial question is no. There was a Review of Commonwealth Functions decision that involved examining the work of social workers in the Department of Social Security, and that was specifically related to the need to ensure that their work was related to the responsibilities of my Department. The review was carried out by the Public Service Board, not by the Department, and is either not yet complete or just complete. Honourable senators would be aware that, in the various decentralised offices of the Department, social workers provide a link between the clients and the Department, particularly in circumstances of difficulty, whether difficulty of communication or difficulty of social circumstance. The role of those social workers is, I think, well established and unlikely to be interfered with.

ANSWER.PARA: The concern that led the Government to have the review made relates to, I suppose, the tendency of any organisation to extend the ambit of its activities. We did not want to see the Department of Social Security moving into the broad, general welfare field, which is the responsibility of State or Territory welfare departments. It is really a definitional exercise and one which, I think, will advance the operations of my Department rather than inhibit them.

Does the Minister agree that the committee's proposal, which would extend the present ban on advertising on television and radio to newspapers and magazines, is completely in line with the Government's adopted goal of reduced tobacco consumption? What recommendations will be put to the States by the Federal Government when the next meeting of the Health Ministers convenes to discuss the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator refers to a report from the Tobacco Products Sub-committee of the National Standing Committee of the Health Ministers Conference. It made a number of recommendations to the recent Australian Health Ministers Conference. As the honourable senator observed, the Committee is comprised of State and Commonwealth representatives. At least that represents some kind of joint approach to the problem. I understand that the proceedings of the Health Ministers Conference are confidential, but I am able to advise the honourable senator that the Tobacco Products Sub-Committee, which has met once since its establishment, has put to the Conference a number of proposals seeking to clarify possible directions it might take in the future. I understand that none of the Sub-committee's proposals had been discussed with the tobacco industry prior to the consideration by Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Health Ministers Conference has authorised the Sub-committee to pursue discussions with the tobacco industry towards the development of a revised voluntary advertising code for cigarettes in Australia. I am unable to foreshadow what kind of recommendations might emerge from the Sub-committee for consideration by the Health Ministers at their next conference. The honourable senator asked a number of other questions. I think that one related to whether an extension of the existing ban on television and radio advertising of cigarettes would be in line with the Government's stated policy. I can emphasise that the Commonwealth has no power to extend the existing bans to the print media. This is very much within the province of the State governments. The bans which we introduced were introduced under the Broadcasting and Television Act. The question of further bans is primarily one for consideration by individual State governments. It is up to them to decide the extent to which such an extension would be good social policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I ask the question in view of the very detailed knowledge which the Minister clearly has in relation to the proposed domestic satellite and which was displayed in his answer to Senator Thomas. How many transponders will there be on the proposed domestic satellite?
—I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES RAILWAY FARE INCREASES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted yesterday's decision of the New South Wales socialist Government to increase all railway fares by between 18 per cent and 25 per cent? I repeat '18 per cent and 25 per cent'-not 2.5 per cent. Does the Minister consider that these rises are modest and realistic, as they were described by the New South Wales Minister for Transport? Further, can the Minister inform the Senate of the effect of these increases, particularly in freight charges, and their relationship to food prices and effect on inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether the Treasurer is aware of yesterday's decision of the New South Wales Government to increase the rail fares and transport charges.
—Tell us about Victoria, Senator.

— I am not dealing with the one about New South Wales, let alone with one that has not even been asked. The question poses a matter for the New South Wales Government. Perhaps the Treasurer has some information on it. I am not aware of what reaction he would wish to express on this matter. I do not know whether we have any assessment of the impact that the charges would make with relation to the consumer price index or any other statistic that we would like to measure. However, I will refer the question to the Treasurer to see whether there is any information that he can give to Senator Lajovic.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been drawn to the case of Vietnam veteran Mr Brian Huston of Wembley, Western Australia, who was refused admission to the Hollywood Repatriation General Hospital in the early hours of 22 September? The registrar on duty directed Mr Huston to the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital despite the fact that his card was marked 'S.S.', which I understand means special service. Mr Huston was suffering from severe internal bleeding and was later diagnosed as having a ruptured duodenal ulcer. He was admitted to the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, transfused, and later that day was admitted to the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital. Vietnam veterans have been assured, I believe, that they are entitled to urgent treatment at no cost regardless of whether the illness was caused by war service. Can the Minister assure Vietnam veterans that their records are clearly identifiable so that there cannot be a recurrence of Mr Huston's distressing experience?

—I am not entirely sure whether I am speaking of the case to which Senator Giles refers but I did note a Press report a fortnight or so ago which referred to the case of a Vietnam veteran who had not been admitted upon request at Hollywood Hospital in accordance with the guidelines laid down for urgent treatment. I understand that in that case there was some confusion over the eligibility of that person and that it was not clear upon his presentation at the hospital that he was, in fact, a Vietnam veteran. I understand that the matter was subsequently cleared up and that suitable apologies were made to that veteran by the officials at the hospital. As regards the more general matter to which Senator Giles refers, yes, the Department is doing what it can to ensure that proper identification is made of suitable records. But there is something of a difficulty, as one would acknowledge, in particular cases where there is not suitable identification upon the presentation of a patient at the hospital. Nevertheless, I will draw the concern of Senator Giles to the attention of officials of my Department and see what we might be able to do to improve that situation.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, by stating that it has been rumoured that there is some slack at the Industries Assistance Commission because of the shortage of references before Commission. In the past the efficiency of private industry has been the target of some comment. Recognising the Commission's expertise in this area, will the Government consider putting a request to the Commission to report upon the efficiency and cost effectiveness of transport by sea and the impact that these costs have on Australian industry and the Australian economy?

—I am rather surprised at Senator Watson's assertion that, in fact, there is some slackness in the work load at the Industries Assistance Commission in view of the fact that several government references are before that body at the moment, in particular, the matter relating to protection and, of course, industry incentives. Nevertheless, we would need to refer that matter to the Minister and seek a reply for Senator Watson. As regards the particular matter he raised, that is, the difficulties of high levels of costs in the transport industries, especially in regard to the export industries of Australia, I believe the IAC may not be the appropriate body for that kind of consideration. In fact, Senator Watson may have in mind a reference of that kind perhaps to the Bureau of Industry Economics within the Department of Industry and Commerce to examine that matter. Nevertheless, I will refer that point to the appropriate Ministers and see whether I can obtain an early reply for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence been drawn to an article appearing in yesterday's issue of the Sun headed 'Joke Force'? The article states, inter alia:

QUESTION.PARA: The total defence effort in Darwin consists of one functional but slow RAAF Caribou transport plane, four naval patrol boats and just over 100 regular soldiers.

Would the Minister not agree that this level of deployment is laughable and will he take steps to see that Australia's northern coastline is more appropriately protected? At present inadequate funds are being made available to Norforce, the reservist force currently being developed to service the north. Will the Minister provide a more appropriate level of funds for this group?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article. I do not know whether the Minister for Defence has. As I said in answer to a question asked by Senator Kilgariff earlier today, maritime activity in and around the northern approaches has recently been increased and this will be maintained. Also, I gave details of current financial year expenditures in the north and west of Australia. The Minister for Defence has given details of the planning in his speech, which has also been made in this place. However, I will refer the question to the Minister and draw his attention to the article to see whether he wants to comment on it any further.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: Is it a fact that where public utilities consistently obtain a low percentage of their gross capital expenditure from internally generated funds those utilities are providing their services at an uneconomic charge and are thereby saddling their sponsoring governments and their future taxpayers and consumers with future debt and inevitable high cost? Is this the reason for the Commonwealth Government's insistence that Telecom Australia generate revenue sufficient to provide approximately two-thirds of its gross capital expenditure requirements? Further, is it a fact that of all major public utilities in Australia the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission has, for the past two years in particular and generally, had the lowest proportion-that is, less than one-fifth-of its gross capital expenditure provided from internally generated funds? Does this indicate that current consumers are in fact being heavily subsidised? Will the Commonwealth apply the principle which it applies to Telecom to any approval by the Loan Council of any application for future borrowings by Tasmania for the HEC? If so, will any development of capital intensive hydro-electric power in South West Tasmania necessarily involve relatively huge increases in consumer charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae's question raises some very important principles. It is a fact that a number of statutory bodies, no doubt directed by governments for political purposes, have engaged in what is very improvident husbandry. That is, to take a quick trick, if I may use that phrase, they have kept tariffs unduly low. They are putting their heads in the sand by not disclosing to the people, the community, that if they do not bear a substantial proportion of capital development from revenue, they will have to get it in the end from borrowing. The interest charges on that borrowing in the long run will cost the consumer much more heavily. So the device of a low percentage is an illusory one; it is bad husbandry and, in the long run, punitive to the community itself. It is true, therefore, that the Commonwealth Government has been taking the view that Telecom should increase its percentage of capital development out of the ordinary tariff revenue so that the long term indebtedness would not build up with huge interest charges and bear more heavily on the community. The fact of the matter is that all responsible treasuries in Australia recognise this and all responsible economists recognise this.

ANSWER.PARA: I will now give an illustration of the situation by way of figures. The percentage of internally generated funds as a proportion of gross capital expenditure for Telecom, for example, during the two previous years was 64.8 per cent in 1978-79 and 66.7 per cent in 1979-80. I think Senator Rae asked about the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission. Its figures were 12.4 per cent in 1978-79 and 20 per cent in 1979-80. By comparison with most other areas, it is significantly lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try the SEC in Victoria for size and see how you get on.

—I will take the State Electricity Commission in Victoria, by contrast with the figures of 12.4 per cent and 20 per cent. I am grateful to Senator Button for raising this. The figures are 33.4 per cent and 20.6 per cent, so they are considerably higher. Wherever one looks that is so. The fundamental situation is that we can always pay for fruit on the sideboard today by mortgaging the future. That is a bad principle. When we do not take enough of our capital expenditure out of revenue today, all we do is build a huge indebtedness for the future. That, sadly, has been the tendency of many public utilities in Australia. The Loan Council infrastructure discussions and dialogue today are directed towards better husbandry.

—I refer the Attorney-General to his Press release dated 16 October reporting the outcome of the meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers concerned with censorship in which he states that the Ministers 'expressed general satisfaction with the classification of films by the Film Censorship Board'. I ask: Did the Ministers reach this conclusion having regard to the apparently much more stringent policy applied by the Board in recent times in relation to serious films such as Oshima's In the Realm of the Senses, and Sigmund Freud and Dora, which policy has been causing mounting concern among those in the community who are concerned to maintain reasonably sophisticated and civilised standards of censorship in Australia and to avoid our plunging back into the dark ages of censorship of the 1960s and before? More importantly, perhaps, does this statement about films mean that the proposed new uniform literature censorship system, which was also decided and announced at that meeting, will apply the lowest rather than the highest standards of tolerance now prevailing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having viewed some of the films that are in fact banned altogether I think we would be plunging back into the dark ages if they were perpetrated on the Australian community. All the State Ministers who had the opportunity at that meeting of viewing some of the absolutely ghastly material that is produced by obviously sick minds would, I think, be astounded at the suggestion that control of censorship of this material should be completely removed. I think it was also clear from the discussions that took place and the methods of cuts on certain films employed by the Film Censorship Board that there is still a fairly liberal attitude indeed taken-perhaps many people would think a too liberal attitude-by the Censorship Board. However, as I said in that Press release, the general view expressed by the Ministers was that the Board was in fact giving effect to community standards in this area and was doing a good job. The only criticism of the Board expressed in some quarters was that it perhaps was being a little too liberal, but not in the direction that Senator Evans is complaining about. That is what I meant by the statement. For my own part, I reiterate that from the discussions I have had with the Board, from what I have seen of its work and certainly from what I have seen of the films that it has actually banned, I believe that it is setting a sound community standard.

ANSWER.PARA: The literature censorship scheme is very much in the early formative stages. The general principle would be to endeavour to obtain agreement on the sort of material which would be placed in specific categories and the form of access to that material. That would be the responsibility of a national body, the form of which has not yet been determined. Each State would still reserve the right to make specific decisions about what material was in fact put into any particular category. I cannot give the Senate very much detail about the scheme, but that was the approach that was agreed upon. Officers have been asked now to prepare a detailed scheme and the Ministers have decided to meet within the next 12 months to give it further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney-General, for the purpose of evaluating his answer: Can we assume that the Durack test of obscenity is the same as the Frankfurter test of obscenity which became famous in the United States?

—I am not suggesting any test of my own. I am simply saying that, from what I have seen of the work of the Board, it is doing a very fair job of what is a difficult task. Its members are the ones who are called upon to determine community standards and, if the honourable senator wants to put it in such terms, the test of obscenity is that of the Board.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether he has seen reports of statements made by the South Australian branch of the Australian Tuna Boat Owners Association expressing concern at the seemingly unlimited supply of canned tuna that is entering Australia from Thailand and the Philippines? Does the Minister recognise the fears of those in the industry that, at a time when they have made a huge investment in that industry in Australia, such imports could affect their livelihood? Can the Minister advise the Senate (1) of the ability of the Australian industry to supply the local market and (2) of the percentage of the Australian market that is being supplied by overseas producers? Will the Minister assure the Senate that action will be taken to safeguard this important industry in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular statements to which the honourable senator has referred. However, they do not sit well with the information that I have received from the Minister for Primary Industry concerning tuna imports, in that it would not appear that there is an unlimited supply, one that is rapidly increasing; rather is the reverse the case. That is not to say that the matter is not of concern to the Government, but probably I can put some of the honourable senator's fears to rest on the basis of the information that I have. I am advised that in recent months there has been a marked fall in the importation of canned tuna into Australia. In the last financial year 2,300 tonnes product weight of tuna was imported, compared with 2,900 tonnes in the previous year. That trend has continued, with imports in July and August totalling 122 tonnes as against 402 tonnes for the same months in 1980.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the Australian industry is capable of supplying the domestic market. However, imports have been required to fill a gap in the market which has resulted from the fact that Australia exports a good deal of its tuna to overseas canneries, so it is a two-way trade. Last year 5,500 tonnes of pole tuna was exported and almost 7,000 tonnes the year before. Overseas tuna prices fell last year and that, coupled with a record Australian catch of 17,800 tonnes, was another important reason for the difficulties that the industry is now experiencing. The Department has advised me that the proportion of the market held by imports has varied in recent years as follows: For 1980-81, 29 per cent; for 1979-80, 53 per cent; for 1978-79, 28 per cent; for 1977-78, 26 per cent; and for 1976-77, 22 per cent. The Government has taken a number of initiatives to assist in the development of the industry, including a tariff of 15 per cent on imports. Industry views have played an important part in the annual talks with Japan on the terms and conditions of access of Japanese tuna vessels and the Government will continue to consult and to work closely with the industry on appropriate policies for its development.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. I preface it by drawing his attention to an article which appeared today in the Australian Financial Review under the heading, 'More aid may be given to home buyers'. The article states that the Government is looking at initiatives that will require extra funding for the home building industry for inclusion in the next Budget. I ask the Minister whether this means that the home building industry of this country which, as we know, is very seriously depressed at the moment, will have to wait 12 months before it can hope to receive extra funding from the Federal Government.

—I did notice cursorily the article in this morning's Australian Financial Review to which Senator Siddons referred. However, I am unable to confirm whether or not that article represents the opinions or the views of the Minister in this matter. I think in the circumstances the only course I can adopt is to refer his question to the Minister and bring down an early reply.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, is asked merely in an attempt to protect the rights of senators to expect to be able to receive answers to their questions from the Government. Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment made a policy statement on assistance to public libraries on 24 September last, only a month ago? I also remind the Minister that a question was placed on the House of Representatives Notice Paper on the subject by a member of the Government parties on 9 April last, seven months ago, and a reply was tendered yesterday by the Minister. Why does my question that was placed on the Senate Notice Paper on 24 February, namely, nine months ago, remain on the Senate Notice Paper completely ignored? Will the Minister ask his colleague in another place and the officers of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment to jazz themselves up in answering questions in this place?

—I would endorse the right of honourable senators to receive answers as promptly as possible to questions they place on notice. If Senator McClelland placed a question on the Notice Paper on 24 February to which there has been no response and if a response to a similar question was made yesterday in another place I think that is a matter which should be referred to the Minister whom I represent. I think the problem has been set out in the substance of Senator McClelland's question. I will make sure that is passed on to my colleague and I would hope to be able to come back to the honourable senator on it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to a report in the 9 October 1981 edition of Overseas Trading which states that a plant to produce enough synthetic motor fuel to replace about 10 per cent of petrol used in Sweden is planned and that production will be based on coal and heavy residual oil feedstock. The Minister will be aware, of course, of the developments in Victoria in the conversion of coal to fuel. Does the Swedish decision to proceed with a full scale production plant indicate that the need for pilot plants has been obviated? Further, will this technology be available to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am aware that a number of countries are investigating a wide range of synthetic fuel options specific to their energy requirements and resource bases. In general, the objective is to reduce dependence on imported crude oil by more effective use of alternative resources. By way of interpolation, I think I read, perhaps in this morning's Australian Financial Review, that the Bank of America is forecasting that indigenous oil-oil from the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries-will cost in the order of $100 a barrel by 1990. So, although there might be a becalmed situation at the moment, the need in the future to get alternatives, including syncrudes, is very obvious, as is the need for lead times.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the specific Swedish decision, I am not aware of the particular technology contemplated for this project. But in any case, I doubt its applicability in the Australian context since it involves the production of hot water and synthetic fuel gas, presumably for heating, as well as some synthetic motor fuel. As Senator Lewis would know, in some countries of Western Europe municipalities actually pipe hot water both for domestic use and for heating--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a refreshing change from hot air.

—Indeed, and who would know better than Senator Button because he has it continually piped en suite, as it were. I am not aware of the specific situation. Our approach so far has been to focus on projects that will essentially produce liquid fuels for the Australian market. This is reflected in the research and development work carried out under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program and in the co-operative projects such as the joint Australia-West Germany study being carried out with other countries. A total of something like $14.3m has been committed in recent years for investigations of synthetic fuels.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, I will ask my Department to have a look at that Swedish proposal. But I make the important point that whatever may be the lulls now in the synthetic crude situations or in conservation, the fundamental need for the world is to realise what I have said repeatedly; that is, we are using oil at twice the rate we are finding it. We are going to run out. Syncrudes must come on stream. They take an enormous amount of research and pilot plant in the first place. One has to get all that work done ahead of the time when one needs the commercial plant, and that is what we are trying to do in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to a communication from Mr Dixon of the Metal Trades Industry Association to the Government on 26 August, as published in today's Australian Financial Review. In that communication Mr Dixon said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the general reference-
That is by the Government-

on tariffs to the IAC 'is a public declaration that large sections of the manufacturing industry are deemed to be expendable, and that the adverse economic consequences, especially increased unemployment, are in fact acceptable to the Government'.

I ask: Is this a further blow to the Fraser Government's already shaky credibility as an economic manager? Does this statement in fact signal a further deterioration and breakdown in relations between the Government and Australia's leading manufacturers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the letter or of its authenticity at all. I am surprised that Senator Gietzelt asks this question because there is documentation that his party's spokesman, Mr Willis, on 18 July 1979 said:

ANSWER.PARA: We just can't keep on supporting small manufacturing industries all the time with protection.

So I take it that is supported by the Labor Party, or would Senator Gietzelt like me to go on and read the number of policy statements that have been made by the Labor Party recommending a cut in protection? Would he like me to remind him of the 25 per cent cut in protection by the Labor Party which caused disaster in 1974-75?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true, as you well know.
—I repeat, that the 25 per cent across the board situation--
—Answer the question.

—The answer to the question is quite clear and that is, I have seen a newspaper report. I do not know the authenticity or otherwise of the letter. What I do know is that if the aim of the Labor Party is to be critical of a reduction in protection in Australia then its track record is disastrous and the spokesmen of the Labor Party are continually saying there must be reduction in protection.
—They are not saying that at all.
—Well, in a speech to metal trades workers in June 1978, Mr Bowen said:

ANSWER.PARA: We must accept that in future a more efficient manufacturing industry may involve fewer workers.
He said:

It is clear that Australian industry must be specialised. For example, in the car industry, it may make more sense to specialise in a particular component of the car than to produce the whole machine on an Australian assembly line.
I repeat that Mr Willis said:
We just can't keep on supporting small manufacturing industries all the time with protection.
The fact of the matter is that the Australian Government, as I said yesterday, stands for the maintenance and expansion of a strong manufacturing industry in Australia that will develop--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not doing very well. Ask ICI about how well you are doing.

—The fact is that we do not have to ask ICI. We have to remind ourselves of the Whitlam Government's 25 per cent cut which, on record, put 110,000 people out of work in secondary industry in the space of one year. I suggest that before the Labor Party starts preaching about protection it should look both to the statements of its spokesmen on the front bench and to its actions when in office. The Government will pursue policies which will maintain and expand the manufacturing industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. As a public health measure, will the Government legislate to control or eliminate smoking in enclosed public places with particular reference to public transport? Is the Minister aware that it is frequently impossible for a passenger to obtain a non-smoking seat on an Australian airline and that if such a seat is obtained the fact that these airlines divide their seating zones on a longitudinal rather than a transverse basis means that the position is meaningless? Will the Minister recommend to the airlines that they follow the practice of most United States airlines whereby smokers are confined to the rear two or three rows and passengers, as of right, are entitled to have a smoke-free seat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two parts to Senator MacGibbon's question. The first concerns the introduction of legislation to restrict smoking in enclosed public places. I will pass that matter on to my colleagues. I point out that there are certain guidelines already existing within the Commonwealth Public Service which seek to arrive at consensus agreements whereby those who are non-smokers can obtain work conditions in which they are in a smoke-free environment, if they so wish. Those guidelines are being progressively extended by agreement and negotiation.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a more difficult problem with aeroplanes. Like Senator MacGibbon, I am sometimes unable to obtain a non-smoking seat. I believe the airlines need to take much greater cognizance of the fact that today a majority of Australians are non-smokers and that those who smoke, whilst exercising a perfectly legal right, are in a minority and that appropriate divisions of seats should be made to allow the non-smoking majority to obtain non-smoking seats, if they so wish. As to whether seating in planes should be divided in a different fashion, I think that is a suggestion which might be made directly to the airlines with the comment that in providing a public service they might want to look seriously at such a suggestion.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Carrick-I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
Senator Mulvihill-I want to make a statement on that.
Senator Townley-Mr President, I raise a point of order.
Senator Mulvihill-I will ask for leave to make a statement after the Minister has finished, Mr President.
Senator Townley-Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wish to ask a question of you today. I wonder whether it is appropriate to put that on notice or whether I should ask it now?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Townley, it rests entirely in your hands.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Carrick-The hour set aside for questions without notice has expired, that being the general consensus. If, as I understand, there is some important reason why an honourable senator from either side wishes to ask a question, I have no objection to the Chair being invited to call him.
Senator Mulvihill-Am I in order in asking a question?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —We will deal with Senator Townley's point of order first.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Townley-Mr President, have you ruled on the point of order?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not ruled because I have not heard all of it. I was getting clarification from the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Townley-The question is not extremely important.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Townley, I suggest that you write to me if it concerns me as occupant of the Chair.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Townley-Is it on order to put it on notice to you, Mr President?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am directing these remarks to you, rather than Senator Carrick, more in sorrow than in anger. I say quite fairly that I think it is time that we had a proper assessment made of the situation at the end of the day and that those honourable senators who miss out on asking a question without notice one day-that is sometimes unavoidable-should come into play the next day and be able to ask their questions in order after the leaders and shadow Ministers have asked theirs. That is not being done. I believe this suggestion will get over a problem. I know there are tactical involvements in the operations of other parts of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Carrick would know that I was remarkably tolerant yesterday in accepting the umpire's decision. I can see no reason why, on the second day of trying, five honourable senators do not get an opportunity to ask their questions once those of the leaders and deputy leaders have been asked, subject to questions of priority. I do not know how you would tabulate it, Mr President. I think my request is fair. I am not trying to rock the boat. I will be raising the matter with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) at 10.30 tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Mulvihill, I inform the Senate-and I have discussed this with the Whips of the various parties-of the system I use at Question Time. I keep a list of the individual questions asked each day of every week and list the names of honourable senators on a separate sheet of paper. I can go back four days to see when honourable senators asked questions. Every day at Question Time, to give priority to those who have not asked a question for some time, I work gradually through the list, with the exception of the leaders of the two parties. I refer to Senator Mulvihill's own leader and that of the Australian Democrats. On occasions, his deputy leader, Senator Grimes, is able to ask an extra question on two consecutive days. Other than that, I try to work it out evenly. I invite Senator Mulvihill to my office so that I may show him the system that I am using. If he can make any better suggestion, I am very willing to listen.

—I want to make a minor correction to an answer I gave to Senator Walsh on Tuesday on product sharing. In the supplementary answer, I referred to a pilot plant on shale being undertaken by the Japanese. I should have said that it was a feasibility study being undertaken by the Japanese on shale-a very expensive one of, I think, about $24m-and a pilot plant on brown coal.

—Yesterday, Senator Colston asked me a question concerning the cases deferred pending the High Court of Australia judgment in the case of Mrs Nancy Law. I promised to give him additional details on the number of claims that are pending at each level of the repatriation determination system. This is broken down as follows: About 100 cases have been deferred by the Repatriation Boards. If I might summarise, the report highlights two things; firstly, the short-sighted approach of this Government in the amount of profit it demands that the Overseas Telecommunications Commission remit; and, secondly, the way in which staff controls are affecting the operations of this statutory authority just as they are hampering other government bodies. The profit of the Commission is considerable, and the organisation is to be congratulated on its performance during the year ended 31 March. It was the seventh year in succession that the Commission reduced its tariffs. There was only a marginal fall in profit. In the previous year abnormal items added a once-only profit of some $5m. It is noteworthy that the tariff reduction generated during the year a total increase of one-third in telephone traffic and an increase of 20 per cent in telex traffic. Because of the tariff reductions, telephone revenue increased over 23 per cent and telex revenue by only 10 per cent. My second comment is in regard to the Government's policy on profits of organisations such as the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. The Chairman, Mr Bob Somervaille, points out in the report that the short-sighted policy of this Government in plundering the Overseas Telecommunications Commission of profit, and this applies equally to Telecom Australia, has some very bad effects. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission is faced with major capital expenditures on projects already approved by this Government. When this Government sees a prestigious program coming forward, such as the proposal to put a cable under the sea to Canada, it approves the proposal as there is a lot of prestige attached to that approval. But when it comes to working out how it will be financed by a body such as the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, it restricts that Commission's financial capacity to meet the cost of the project. The particular item of capital expenditure to which I have referred is the new trans-Pacific high capacity submarine cable system known as ANZCAN, which the Government has approved.

The Overseas Telecommunications Commission, as is indicated by this report, wanted to pay the Government a dividend of 15 per cent or $7.5m this year-that is not a bad dividend, I would have thought-and retain the balance of its profits for major capital works such as the submarine cable. Not many honourable senators can obtain an investment in a major Australian corporation which returns much more than 15 per cent. That is what OTC wanted to pay to the Government but the Government said that it must pay more. That creates difficulties for the Commission in funding capital works. The Government has insisted on a dividend that is three times that suggested by the Commission. It is not a recent policy. It has been going on for the past five years, and it ought to stop. The result, for the OTC, is that the $200m that it has to contibute to the cost of the submarine cable-contributions are to be made also by Canada and I believe New Zealand and so on-will now have to be provided, in a lopsided way, through borrowings.

The Commission, by not obtaining permission to retain a higher proportion of profits, will have to seek short term accommodation in order to tide over periods of tight liquidity. This requirement comes from a Government which talks about its business management capacities. The Chairman of the OTC makes the point in this way:

With this higher order of borrowings, it is inevitable that the future customer will pay more for the service than would have been the case if a greater share of past profits had been retained by OTC for its capital financing requirements.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the same shortsighted attitude on the part of this Government has already greatly harmed Telecom Australia and prevented it from meeting its commitments out of the profits which it generates in the area of domestic communications. Now the same policy is being applied to the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. Domestic communications have been damaged-not just according to me but according to the Government's own expert committees on Telecom-by the shortsighted financial policy of the Government. While Telecom's capacity to deliver domestic services has been inhibited and, to quote the words of the McKinsey report, not my own, its productivity and efficiency lowered, the Government is embarking upon similar policies in relation to our international communications. Far from displaying any degree of pride in the efficiency of the OTC, the Government has its fingers in the till of that organisation to a greedy and exorbitant extent. I draw the attention of the Senate to the point made by the Commissioners of OTC in their report about staffing. That point, which I imagine has relevance to many other areas of government, concerns the difficulties that are created by the poor salary scales available for skilled workers. This already has caused disruption in such departments as Transport, which skilled workers in aviation control have left for private industry. It has caused problems also in Telecom. Indeed, it caused the recent industrial dispute about which the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) indulged in such huff and puff before conceding the justice of the claim.

There is also the problem of the drift of skilled workers from these instrumentalities because of an incapacity to pay adequate salaries. OTC reports the same problem. Many private firms avoid the high cost of early training by paying higher salaries to attract government employees. The artificially depressed wage scales represent not only shortsightedness on the part of the Government but also create a capacity for it to engage in unfair dealing with its own employees. However, ultimately the consumer pays the Bill by meeting the cost of training skilled workers, at public expense, for the eventual use of private employers.

The OTC also makes the familiar point about the effect of tight staff ceilings. It seems to me to be an amazing illustration of this Government's ignorance of good management that an enterprise which is as profitable as is OTC is not able to exercise freedom to any degree at all, in determining the size of its work force. One wonders what else this organisation would have to do to show that it was managing its affairs competently. Its profits are impressive. Its reductions in charges show its capacity to deal in the market place. It seems that that is not enough for this Government, which is incapable of coming to grips with the most fundamental aspects of management and policy direction.

I commend a close reading of this report to any honourable senator who is interested in questions of business efficiency and the importance of the Government operating efficient business enterprise. Here we have one such enterprise, but its efficiency, productivity, and capacity continually to reduce tariffs are being curtailed by the Government's policies. It is time that the Senate looked more closely at those policies and at the kinds of difficulties raised in the report concerning them, because they are symptomatic of the effects of government policies in many areas of gross mismanagement. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
