DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATION AND STAFFING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That General Business, Order of the Day No. 2, relating to the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriation and Staffing, be postponed until the next day of sitting.

I think it is appropriate that I should make a few comments at this stage. In moving for the postponement of this matter I am very conscious of the interest the report has created on both sides of the Houses of Parliament and also the interest that has been shown overseas. This morning I had discussions on the subject with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. He has assured me that he is pursuing the matter. We believe, as a matter of courtesy, it is important to get the Government's reaction to the report before it is debated in this place. He has assured me that this matter is receiving his active consideration at the moment. He has indicated to me that an interdepartmental committee report on the document will be ready for him to examine tomorrow. He has assured me that as soon as possible after that time he will present it to the Cabinet to seek its reaction. I believe we should extend this courtesy to the Government to get its reaction to the report. I propose to ensure, certainly before the end of this session, that the matter is debated in the Senate. I understand that Senator McClelland, the Deputy Chairman of the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriation and Staffing, is seeking an appointment with Senator Carrick to discuss the matter with him personally to impress upon the Leader our very strong wish and determination to see that this important document is debated as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jessop has made a statement as to why he has moved that the discussion on this matter be deferred. I briefly want to comment on this matter. Senator Jessop has indicated that I have sought an appointment with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick, to have a discussion with him about the matter and about the attitude of the members of the Australian Labor Party who sat on the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriation and Staffing. They put in an awful lot of work on the subject. It is only because of my commitments in this chamber this morning that I have not been able to see Senator Carrick as yet.

SPEECH.PARA: But I want to impress upon the Government that we regard the matter as one of great importance. There is a tendency on the part of, if not the Government, the bureaucracy, to want to shelve these things. I instanced in a question to one of the Ministers this morning how there is a tendency on the part of the bureaucracy to ignore the affairs of this Parliament and particularly the Senate. Merely because an interdepartmental committee was appointed by the Government to report on the report of the Select Committee, that is no excuse at all as to why there should be any attempt on the part of anyone to fob off this Parliament's dealing with the report.

I merely want to say that I agree that the Government is entitled to seek advice from its advisers but equally the Senate, and particularly the members of the Committee, are entitled to receive a response from the Government on the matters contained in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to debate it this session.

—And, I was about to say, to ensure that the debate comes on in this sessional period. Senator Jessop, as chairman of the Select Committee, has indicated his attitude. I indicate that I support and my colleague Senator Robertson, who also sat on that committee, supports wholeheartedly the attitude enunciated this moring by Senator Jessop. If action is not taken by Government senators to bring on the debate, we well certainly initiate action.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: In Committee
Consideration resumed from 15 October 1981.
Ordered that the items of the report be considered separately.
Item 1. Membership of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the proposed amendment to Standing Order 33 be agreed to.

Honourable senators should have before them the report of the Standing Orders Committee, which sets out the argument concerning each of the matters addressed by the Standing Orders Committee. Briefly, Item No. 1 relates to the fact that the two leaders, who are members of the Standing Orders Committee, sometimes find it difficult to attend meetings. This was one reason why meetings of the Standing Orders Committee occurred infrequently from time to time. The proposal, as set out in the report as a recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee, reads:

That the Standing Order for the appointment of the Committee . . . be amended to provide for the two Leaders to be ex officio members and to allow them to appoint other Senators to act in their place as members of the Committee when they are not able to attend meetings.
That is all that is contained in the proposed amendment. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposition has the support of the Australian Labor Party. Whilst we would hope to see the leaders present on most occasions, we appreciate the fact that on some occasions they will need to appoint proxies. We have already done that. I announce to the chamber that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Don Grimes, will be the proxy for our leader on the occasions when he cannot attend.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 2. Deputy President

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Aboriginal Affairs) (12.54)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the proposed amendments to Standing Orders as contained in Appendix B to the report be agreed to.

I again refer honourable senators to the report of the Standing Orders Committee. I draw their attention to the proposal that there be a change to the title which you, Mr Chairman, hold by virtue of your office. At present you are known as 'Chairman of Committees'. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the text of the report, which states:

That the official title of the position be Deputy-President and Chairman of Committees, that the title Deputy-President be generally used and that the title Chairman of Committees be restricted to the role of the position as Chairman of Committees of the Whole.

I believe that there is very little of substantial change to the practice of the Senate, but I believe that what is proposed reflects more accurately the reality of the situation with the Chairman. I commend that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to item 2. I want either to oppose it or to suggest that it go back for reconsideration by the Standing Orders Committee. Honourable senators will recall that at the beginning of this session we had a debate in this Parliament on a proposal which I moved that there should be instead two officers, a Deputy President (Procedures) and a Deputy President (Committees). The proposal, which was put forward by Government senators, was defeated at that time. It was opposed by the Australian Labor Party substantially on the basis, I think, that the matter had not been discussed by the Standing Orders Committee and there was objection to the way in which it had proceeded. That, of course, was a proposal for two officers and it was proposed that certain functions should be separated.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the title 'Chairman of Committees' would give the impression that somehow the Chairman is responsible for the running and management of the committee system, whereas we know from practice that he does not have such effective operation. In fact, that aspect of the Senate's work is headless in the sense that there is no direct attention given to how the committee system is operating. I have since had correspondence with the President on that matter and I understand that it has now gone before the Standing Orders Committee, having been on its agenda for some period.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. It is before the Standing Orders Committee.
—It is before the Committee but the Committee has not dealt with the matter at all.
—Yet.

—Yes, yet. We have a proposal today which seeks to give two names to the one officer. I say that the proposal concerning the Deputy President seems to be a sensible idea. I am not objecting to that. But in effect, we are pre-empting the proposal put forward. Honourable senators on this side certainly intend to press for the adoption of the proposal because we believe it provides for a better system of operation. Senator Button argued so persuasively at that stage that the proposal should have gone before the Standing Orders Committee. It has gone there. Now the Standing Orders Committee has put forward a recommendation that impliedly rejects that suggestion. I know that that is not a fact. I know that the Committee has not considered it. I think the matter ought to be considered by it. I think there is a need for a change in the situation. But the motion pre-empts that and seeks to change the title at this stage. I cannot see the need for doing that before it has been considered. I cannot understand why the Standing Orders Committee has passed over this item on its agenda and not given consideration to the proposal which was debated in the Parliament and which I think was defeated very substantially on technical grounds and not necessarily on the merit of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I think that I should seek to move that consideration of this item be postponed until the Standing Orders Committee has further considered the proposal which was debated in the Parliament at the beginning of the session. It would be quite wrong for this chamber to adopt today the item without consideration of the alternative proposal and the alternative titles of Deputy President (Procedures) and Deputy President (Committees), or some other titles. To pass this motion would be impliedly to suggest that the Standing Orders Committee is not prepared to face up to an examination of the proposals that were then put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, no such implication can be drawn, as Senator Missen suggests. What Senator Missen is really saying is that an idea is floating around which has to be considered, and if that idea is ever adopted this proposal would be wrong.
—It is on the agenda.

—I understand that. Senator Missen, there may be all sorts of things in the minds of honourable senators for inclusion in the agenda of the Standing Orders Committee for consideration. According to Senator Missen's argument we remain paralysed about taking any decisions on anything until we have considered the ramifications of all possible changes to Standing Orders. That is not the position at all. I am a member of the Standing Orders Committee. I assure Senator Missen that if the proposal he, amongst others, is floating around is adopted by the Standing Orders Committee I will meet and vote with him on any change that has to be made subsequently to the title of Deputy President, as suggested in this document. I assure the honourable senator of that. If that proposal is adopted we will meet him on the changes. By this recommendation the Senate Standing Orders Committee is not in any way trying to pre-empt the discussion on that matter. As I indicated on an earlier occasion in this chamber, we would like information and argument about how the proposal will make the Senate more efficient, as the honourable senator suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: When we are considering those arguments, we would be prepared if we accepted them-I believe all honourable senators ought to be prepared if we accepted them-to reconsider an alteration to the Standing Orders which would then be consistent with the new arrangements. I think it is wrong to ask the Senate Standing Orders Committee to adjourn consideration of this proposal on the basis of some hypothetical consideration which we have not yet dealt with. I think it is unfair-I use that in the nicest possible way I can-to suggest the implications of adopting this proposal are as Senator Missen says.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reinforce what Senator Button said before the suspension for lunch and, to return to item 2 of the Standing Orders Committee report which we are debating, I agree that you, Mr Chairman, be given the title of Deputy President, and Chairman of Committees. To take up the point Senator Missen raised, my understanding, as a member of the Standing Orders Committee, is that Senator Button has presented the situation accurately, that is, that the issue of the two positions-a matter which was debated in the Senate earlier this session-remains to be considered by the Standing Orders Committee.
—We know that.

—I am just acknowledging that. What is proposed is proposed with no prejudice to that discussion or to anything that may flow from it. The intention of the Standing Orders Committee was that the title which Senator Douglas McClelland should carry should reflect quite accurately the positions he holds in the Senate. To call him Deputy President and Chairman of Committees seems to be an accurate representation. I reiterate what Senator Button said today. If a resolution occurred in the other matter, he would aim to meet us on the question of an appropriate title. I give the same undertaking as a member of the Standing Orders Committee and would commend the proposed change.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 3. Presentation and Consideration of Government Reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman and Mr Deputy President, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the proposed sessional order as contained in Appendix C to the report be adopted.

This is the single matter of real substance in this report of the Standing Orders Committee which may attract some controversy and debate. The matter is discussed at some length on pages 2 and 3 of the report. I draw the attention of the Committee of the Whole to the limits of the proposal. It is proposed only that the Standing Order should be for a trial period, should be by way of a sessional order and should provide for a procedure to apply on one day of the week only, that is, on Thursday. It will try to ensure adequate time for the discussion of papers which are presented. It involves some acknowledgement that time would have to be found for that within the program of the Senate. I do not intend to go through each of the proposals in turn unless they attract the concern of honourable senators. I add that this was a proposal that emerged from the Standing Orders Committee by consensus as a result of considerable discussion of what has been a difficult matter. It is the considered opinion of the Committee. On the basis that the proposal is for a trial period by sessional order, I commend it to the attention of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President and Chairman, I wish to query this matter. I wonder whether we are proceeding in the right way even though it is only a sessional order and it is for only a trial period. Of course, there have been difficulties with the presentation of papers. I wonder whether we will not create other difficulties which will be equally as annoying to some of us. First, I raise the simple matter that obviously the House of Representatives will not fall in line with it. The way it went on yesterday, it most certainly will not. We will then have a situation-I know it sometimes occurs now but it will occur obviously more often-whereby sometimes a very important report comes down in the House of Representatives and does not turn up here under those circumstances for at least two days or even a week. That may create some difficulties with some people who are keen to talk on such reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter is the rigidity of the time of an hour and a half for consideration of motions. One day early last week we considered a series of reports which had come in a fortnight before. We attempted to debate them in the time available but took much more than an hour and a half. If everyone had been here who would have liked to have spoken on those reports on that Thursday night, it would have taken considerably longer than an hour and a half. I wonder what consideration has been given to that sort of difficulty because quite frequently we do have batches of reports all coming down together, including those of the Auditor-General. It may take much longer than an hour and a half to deal with those reports even if only one senator spoke, such as the shadow Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that it is within the competence of the Senate at any stage to order that the procedures should be varied on any particular day. If Senator Grimes is saying that there may be some days when special circumstances arise which require special arrangements, I believe they could be accommodated by goodwill and by arrangements on both sides of the Senate. Again both the Standing Orders Committee and I are only suggesting that we have a trial period to see how it goes as a sessional order. It will be no more than that.
—Minister, could I put a point to you? Of course it is up to Ministers to say whether they will bring down reports. There is nothing to force them to do it on a Thursday.

—I was trying not to make that point. Senator Grimes was raising the point that, if papers are tabled and if a special need exists because of some particularly controversial piece of material, the Senate has the capacity to order otherwise at any stage, using the procedures of the place.

—I would like to speak briefly on the same point because it is one that had concerned me and it is one which I have discussed with some officers of the Senate. I have taken into consideration the comments made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I feel that there could be an occasion when the hour and a half would be too inflexible. I note that it is only a sessional order and if it does not work satisfactorily it will not necessarily become a Standing Order. However, it is possible that it could work satisfactorily for one session, and an occasion could arise when it would not be satisfactory, for example, if a large number of very important reports were presented, say, on the last day of a session. Honourable senators might feel that they had been unfairly precluded from commenting on things that are important. I would not oppose the sessional order. If it worked satisfactorily, I would not oppose it becoming a Standing Order. I think it should be understood that honourable senators do have a concern that on some occasion in the future this may prove to be a rigid requirement. I am sure that none of us would want then to be in the position of being told: 'This is the way it must be done because it is in the Standing Orders and it is necessary for the Government to get its business done' or whatever. If it does become part of our procedure, it must be on the understanding that it is not intended in any way to limit senators' rights to debate reports of controversial matter. It is intended in fact, to give us all a better go at having an opportunity to debate certain types of reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President and Chairman, I support this proposal, as indeed I did after a lot of discussion on the Standing Orders Committee about it. I largely support it for the reasons hinted at by Senator Martin, in that this is only a sessional order at the moment and for a trial period. I refer to paragraphs (b) and (d) of the proposal. I feel remiss, as a member of the Standing Orders Committee, that I allowed without comment paragraph (b) to be inserted, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: No petitions shall be received on Thursdays.

I think it would be a very good thing for the Senate if the Standing Orders Committee considered at some stage amending that sessional order so it reads: 'No petitions shall be received on Wednesdays or Thursdays'. The reason for that statement is that, because of my responsibilities as communications shadow Minister, I have occasion to consider the question of ratings. I tell honourable senators that the ratings of this Parliament, in terms of its listening audience, are rock bottom. One of the reasons for that is the material for debate which we allow to go on air. For example, frequently the Standing Orders report is debated on a Wednesday. Any listener to a Standing Orders debate in the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one?

—Any listener to a Standing Orders debate in the Senate would be pardoned for concluding that it was not a show of the calibre of the television program Not The Nine O'Clock News for example. I have been present in the Senate chamber when up to three-quarters of an hour of broadcast time has been taken up with the reading of petitions. I think that people who listen to the broadcast are entitled to ask: 'What is that place all about? What are they doing?'. I believe the Standing Orders Committee should consider the terminology of paragraph (b). In relation to paragraph (c) of the recommendations, it just might be-I am very much conscious of my own conduct in this regard-that the imposition of a 10-minute time limit would sharpen the concentration and wit of those honourable senators who are making a contribution in regard to reports. Indeed, if brevity, as we are told, is the soul of wit, it may do something to improve the quality of the discussion. I am fully supportive of the proposal and I commend it to the Senate, subject to the qualifications I have made about the reading of petitions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that we were discussing one item at a time. It had been my intention to say something about petitions also. I did not intend to be quite as strict about the matter as was Senator Button. I am sure that he would have no objection to a suggestion that the Wednesday proposal be included. The point I wanted to raise is that a difficulty could arise if there were a blanket banning of petition on certain days if it happened that the day-whether it be a Wednesday or a Thursday-was the last day of the parliamentary session. It may be that just the timing of the receipt of a petition would mean that that petition was not presented for several months. I am not suggesting that an amendment be made to the wording, but I think that when the new Standing Orders are drafted-if we decide that this should go into the Standing Orders-provision should be made similar to that which exists in paragraph (a). Paragraph (a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: reports shall be presented by Ministers on Thursdays only, unless there are exceptional circumstances requiring the presentation of particular reports on other days;

I would propose that words such as 'unless there are exceptional circumstances requiring the presentation of petitions on other days'. The circumstances, as I see it, would be where there was an undue delay in the presentation of a petition, perhaps several months. Because of the timing of the receipt of it, perhaps it could not be presented during that session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am attracted to what Senator Button and Senator Martin have said. Mr Chairman, I seek your advice. I take it that if the honourable senators have a strong view on this, it is quite competent for them to move an amendment to paragraph (b), perhaps in the terms Senator Martin has suggested. She has suggested an amendment that petitions should be received on Tuesdays only-if I understood her correctly-unless there are exceptional circumstances requiring the presentation of petitions on other days. If that is the honourable senator's view and she wants to test the feelings of the Committee, I suggest that she move an amendment to that effect.
—Senator Peter Baume's modesty is impressive. For the purpose of testing the view of the Committee I shall move--

—Senator Martin, it appears to me that this matter we are dealing with relates to the presentation of papers. After this matter has been dealt with I suggest that Senator Martin should move that the matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for further consideration or move another motion for its consideration. At this stage I feel the matter relates to the presentation of papers.

—That arrangement would be satisfactory if, after settling the matter of the presentation of papers, we can deal with petitions. I understand the Minister suggested that I might move an amendment to the sessional order which the Committee could deal with now after we have finished dealing with the subject of the presentation of papers and reports.

—I want to make two comments about the matter. I am a member of the Standing Orders Committee. I suppose I am the only member who does not understand the Standing Orders; perhaps that is why I am there. Two fairly distinct understandings are needed for this sessional order to work. The first is that, basically, there will be no discussion of matters of public importance on Thursdays. It really devolves on this side of the chamber to stick to that side of the bargain. The second point-we have to emphasise this necessity if the arrangement is to work-is to get the reports as early as possible. It is not much use honourable senators coming into the chamber on a Thursday just before papers are presented, being given a bundle of reports and papers and then be expected, as Senator Button said, to make a lucid, concise and concentrated 10-minute speech. There would just be a desperate shuffling of papers as honourable senators tried to make their points. If the proposed sessional order is to work, those two matters need to be borne in mind.

—I wish to ask a question of the Minister. I refer to the point raised in passing by Senator Robert Ray that on Thursday mornings, when the presentation of reports will take place, there is nothing to stop matters of public importance being brought forward and wiping out the morning. Paragraph (c) provides that discussion could continue for an hour and a half. I suppose that is the answer to my question. The reading of petitions on that day has been wiped out, which usually takes only 10 minutes or so, but the possibility has not been wiped out that the rest of the morning might be taken up with a discussion of a matter of public importance. Can I have some comment on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond. I make it clear in passing that the Standing Orders Committee report is not a matter of Government Business. I am responding as a member of the Standing Orders Committee, not as a Minister in the Government. I think that paragraph (d) of the proposed sessional order takes account of the matter by stating that the consideration of papers may go on after 8 p.m., if necessary. It was in people's minds that, while normally there would be no matter of public importance, if there were and if we needed more time, it was possible to obtain the balance of the one and a half hours after 8 p.m. I believe the point which the honourable senator raised is adequately catered for.

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up the other matter raised by Senator Robert Ray that papers should be available in proper time. I think that has been adverted to already this morning and it is something that we will be looking at again.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested that I move an amendment to the relevant sessional order. When I looked at the wording of that sessional order it became a little difficult to do it off the top of my head. The wording has been designed to fit in with petitions and reports. Previously when we have considered reports of the Standing Orders Committee we have gone through the recommendations seriatim and accepted, rejected or amended them. It would be easier for me to move an amendment to recommendation (b) on page 3 of the Standing Orders Committee report to the effect that no petition shall be received on Wednesdays or Thursdays unless there are exceptional circumstances requiring the presentation of a petition on one of those days. If the Committee accepts the recommendation, it should direct whoever has to present the sessional order to us for acceptance as a sessional order to redraft that sessional order in accordance with the Committee's views-whatever it determines in relation to recommendation (b).

—I would like to suggest an alternative to Senator Martin's proposal and, that is, that she move some motion to refer to the Standing Orders Committee the matter of petitions being received on Wednesday, rather than trying to amend the Standing Order on the run at this stage. What bothers me is that if someone presents a petition like that which Senator Mulvihill presented the other day-how many signatures did it have?
—Five thousand, but it was the voice of democracy.

—If someone like Senator Mulvihill presents a petition with 5,000 signatures then I think it is not unreasonable to have that petition read and broadcast over the radio, with all due respect to my Victorian colleague, Senator Button, and the ratings. I presented a petition with over 6,500 signatures in relation to subscriber trunk dialling telephone charges. I can assure honourable senators that I always tried to choose a Wednesday to present it because I knew that large numbers of people in Victoria, especially in rural Victoria, were trying to listen to the petition being read. It seems to me that it is not the sort of decision that the Senate should make on the run and that it would be much better if the matter were referred back to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration.

—I find myself in the unusual position of supporting Senator Lewis. I think the matter ought to be referred back to the Standing Orders Committee, not necessarily because I agree with the point Senator Lewis made, but rather because I think there may be other ways through the dilemma of Wednesday's petition time-which is driving all of us bonkers-which might not be quite as far-reaching as that proposed by Senator Martin. For example, another alternative that might be considered is simply enabling honourable senators to introduce a petition and shortly describe its contents in the way we do at the moment, without having the terms of the petition actually read. That would give everyone a place in the sun with their petitions on broadcast day and serve the interests of democracy accordingly but not bore everyone witless for three-quarters of an hour while the detailed texts of the petitions were in fact read. I would be happy for that proposal, for example, to be adopted right now, but to draft that on the run is probably a bit too much of an enterprise even for someone of the calibre of Senator Martin or Senator Lewis. I suggest that the appropriate course is to refer the matter back, and I would support any such motion moved by Senator Lewis.

—I stand up to be counted shoulder to shoulder with Senator Evans and Senator Lewis. We cannot stifle democracy. I think it is a way of mass participation. On that ground I support my colleagues who have just spoken.

—It was my fault for inviting Senator Martin to test the water. She has tested the water. It seems that there is an indication that it might be appropriate to refer the matter back to the Standing Orders Committee. Maybe that is the way we should proceed at this stage. I think I have detected an inclination to look at this practice of the Senate fairly critically, but people seem to want it done in a more measured way than by just taking it on the run now. If that is the wish I would like to ask, if it meets Senator Martin's concurrence, that we have that matter referred to the Standing Orders Committee for its attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to close the circle. I note that in the framing of the sessional order there is no reference to exceptional circumstances relating to reports. I take it that that is covered by understanding under the words:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders . . .

That is the let out to enable reports to come down on days other than Thursdays. I think in this debate there has been no suggestion of disagreement with my original suggestion that petitions ought to be able to be presented on a Thursday if there are exceptional circumstances. I think it is understood that that part of what we are debating is accepted. I will accept that it is covered by the present sessional orders. I am sure that both Senator Button and I will be delighted to debate further the subject of whether petitions should be presented on Wednesdays. I think it is reasonable to let the matter go back to the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been persuaded by Senator Martin's moderation. I concur with it, but, so that I can have my own bit, I ask that the matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration promptly.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of this Committee that the matter raised by Senator Martin and supported by Senator Button be referred to the Standing Orders Committee.

—Not to be pedantic and so that the Standing Orders Committee is not confused about which issue it is supposed to be looking at, the matter was actually raised by Senator Button and supported by me. That was the matter of petitions being presented on Wednesdays. Do I take it that it is necessary to move a motion referring the matter of whether petitions should be presented on Wednesdays to the Standing Orders Committee?
—That is not necessary, Senator Martin. The Standing Orders Committee will naturally take cognisance of the debate that has taken place in this Committee of the Whole.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. At this stage I want to say something about the situation with West Block which, I believe, is to be handed over to the Department of Administrative Services next Monday. Recently that building has had about $4.1m spent upon it. One or two of us are going to have a look at the building later in the day if we can get a pair. Even if we cannot, I think we might have a look at it. I will go through a bit of the background of the building. Under the Parliament Act 1974 West Block lies within the parliamentary zone. I feel that Parliament has a need to consolidate its accommodation requirements in one building. Currently we have an overflow from this building. We have to use the Hotel Canberra and the Hotel Kurrajong. I feel that half of West Block would meet the needs of the Parliament until the completion of the new Parliament House building in 1988. On 22 November 1979 the Senate passed a motion requesting the Government to allocate West Block to the Parliament. The appropriate resolution is recorded on page 1090 of the Journals of the Senate of 22 November 1979. Part (c) states:

SPEECH.PARA: that-
(i) the Government be again requested to allocate West Block to Parliament for its use, pending building of the New and Permanent Parliament House;
(ii) if the request is granted, refurbishing and restoration of the building be undertaken without delay, after consultation with Parliamentary Departments; and
(iii) the Government be requested to advise the Senate, during the first sitting week in 1980, of its attitude to the occupancy of West Block by the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did we have any reply to that?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that most of the benefits around this place are going to bureaucrats, Ministers and those who claim special positions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak very briefly not only to give this matter the attention it deserves but also to support what Senator Townley has said in regard to West Block and the provision of premises that the Parliament needs and without which, under the present arrangements, it cannot capably operate. We have here a limited number of 64 senators who have to serve on a growing number of committees in this Parliament, and for us to be expected to operate here as our own 'fetch and carry' people and to not have facilities provided is a crazy way to run a parliament or a house of a parliament.

So far attempts that have been made to get the Government and the Minister to take a sensible attitude towards this matter have led to our receiving rather stereotyped letters. The letter I got and the letter Senator Townley recently got from the Minister could be substituted for each other. We put forward different arguments and different remarks but we got the same sort of reply. 'It has been done for this one and that one over the years and independent members have been given particular facilities, but when we ask about the situation now it is just said that this has been done in the past only for particular purposes and there is no addressing of the reply itself to what should be done for members of Parliament. I am saying that the committee system of this Parliament is at a crisis stage. We have more committees and more demands for them.

There are things that are not properly done in this Parliament by all of us. I regard myself as quite incompetent to handle the things I am taking on at this time. I invite others to suggest that they are in the same position. If the people of this country think that, by paying us a reasonable sort of salary and not supplying us with the proper support and assistance, they are getting a proper go for their expenditure, I say that is not so. Certainly West Block would provide that accommodation and ensure that someone was quite close. An honourable senator referred to staff for members of committees. Although not adequate, it is a help. I am sorry to take up the time of the Senate but I want to declare war. I am not satisfied to go on in this way any longer. I will campaign now vigorously to ensure that members in this House of the Parliament-those in the other House do not answer us or write back to us and we do not know what they are doing; they can fight their own battle-who are doing a job and creating a committee system are getting a rotten go in this Parliament, and I am not content to let it last.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wonder whether anyone can tell me where he can get 23.75 per cent interest on a Commonwealth Government guaranteed security? SPEECH.PARA: A consistent policy of the Fraser Government since it came into power, the only consistent policy, probably, has been to redistribute income in a regressive way. Before the latest increase, the yield on IEDs was 7 per cent, which is totally unrealistic in the current market. An acceptance of the NFF's formula for the IED rate pegged 2 per cent below Commonwealth bonds would lift the IED yield to around 12.5 per cent.

This item is not the only item of expenditure which escapes being included in Appropriation Bills Nos. 1 or 2.
