We have seen the film tax rort under which the Government will pay between 90 per cent and 120 per cent, concealed in the taxation system, of the cost of making a film. It would be cheaper for the Government to make the films itself and give them away than it is to subsidise them through the taxation system by more than 100 per cent as it is doing. I defy Senator Guilfoyle to provide any rational justification for that rort produced off the top of the head of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the heady days of the last Federal election, apparently at the instigation of a Channel 7 make-up girl.

There are tax concessions for water pumping and distribution, for irrigation, which, under certain circumstances, will cost the revenue 103 per cent of the investment. That is just as bad as the film rort. There are concessions for storage of fuel in small tanks by small business. To store 267 million gallons of fuel in thousand gallon tanks costs $174m. Subsidised through the tax system in this way it would cost government revenue, at a marginal tax rate of 46 per cent, $80m to provide a tax concession for the storage of 267 million gallons of fuel. The same quantity can be stored in million gallon tanks at a total cost of $67m. Again, it would be cheaper for the Government to buy the tanks outright and give them to oil distributors than to subsidise storage through the taxation system in that way. Needless to say, that is another Malcolm Fraser special.

I could continue to quote from that list but believe that I have cited enough examples. I have given three instances, in two of which, because of the hidden taxation concession for investors, the loss of revenue is greater than is the investment itself. It is not possible to devise any more effective mechanism for maldistributing investment resources. In the case of the other concession, which is rationalised as a plan to provide emergency stocks of fuel, it would be cheaper and more effective for the Government to buy appropriate tanks outright than to subsidise it in this hidden way through the taxation system as it has done. I repeat: Once the taxation law has been amended, it escapes annual parliamentary scrutiny until such time as the amendments are repealed.

Another item that is highly relevant to the budgetary outcome but is not shown in the Appropriation Bills concerns government borrowings. Under this Government we are afflicted with a cargo cult theory of private borrowing, one under which it is implicity stated that borrowings in the public sector affect the capital market and push interest rates up, but borrowings from the private sector do not have that effect. That is the implicit belief which underlies all recent Government statements on the subject. That example of cargo cultism was repeated in the House of Representatives today by Mr Sinclair when, in between falsifying his Hansard records, he stated that it would be quite inappropriate to allow Telecom Australia to borrow an additional $3m on the capital market in order to provide the business data facility which he prevented it from having. He said that it was much better to allow private enterprise to do this. The cargo cult belief could scarcely be more clearly stated. If Telecom borrows money on the capital market, it pushes interest rates up. If Kerry Packer or the Myer group borrows money on the capital market, interest rates are not affected. No wonder the country is in a mess.

An item in these Bills on which I wish to comment, because it is equally as ridiculous as some of the other things that I have mentioned, is the provision made for national disaster relief funding. A particular scheme which was announced by the Prime Minister on 23 June would be funded under this item. On that date, the Prime Minister announced that money would be made available under this provision allegedly to assist drought-affected New South Wales wheat growers in planting a crop and that the security for the loan would be a lien against the crop that was about to be planted. Of course, the announcement of 23 June was too late for its ostensible purpose. Any wheat farmer who, by 23 June, did not actually have his crop planted, or at the very least have all the necesary pre-arrangements made for planting, would be well advised to forget about planting at all. But even if one overlooks that gross error of timing, that fundamental error by a government which prides itself on having half a dozen farmers in the Cabinet, something even more interesting was revealed in the proceedings of the Estimates committees.

Under present arrangements, the first $10m spent on national disaster relief in New South Wales is provided by the New South Wales State Government. All expenditure in excess of that amount is provided, as to 75 per cent by the Commonwealth Government and as to 25 per cent by the State Government. It is anticipated that total payments under this scheme in New South Wales this year will be in the vicinity of $18m. In other words, at the margin and $8m below the margin, of every dollar lent under this scheme the Commonwealth will be providing 75 per cent. Interest is paid to the State at 4 1/2 per cent on the face value of the loan, but since the State provides only 25 per cent of the loan the effective interest rate to it is 18 per cent. This is an open-ended invitation to a government to ingratiate itself with its own electorate by distributing irresponsibly Commonwealth largesse and making a profit in the process. Who could blame the New South Wales Government if it behaved in that way, if it followed the axiom that if you see a mug you might as well rip him off. One would be battling to find a greater collection of mugs than the people who made that provision available.

One might legitimately question, as many do, whether money should be made available at all on those terms-partly on equity grounds, because these funds at 4 1/2 per cent interest do go to people who have considerable assets and net worth. The equity of the general taxpayer who provides loans under such concessional terms might legitimately be questioned. On efficiency or resource allocation grounds it can also be argued, and ought to be by anyone who purports to believe in a market economy, that the cost of drought and disaster should be negatively capitalised in the price of land. Arrangements such as that to which I have referred frustrate that market outcome. But if money is to continue to be made available at an interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent we are at least entitled to demand that the mugs who are running this country, the mugs who have issued this open-ended invitation to yet another group to raid the Treasury, should clean up the most blatant sloth over which they have presided.

The Appropriation Bills and the Budget with which they are associated are slothful in detail beyond the point of ridicule. They are fatally flawed in regard to what the one-time Treasurer, the pre-Stumpy Gully Treasurer, used to refer to rather boringly as the broad thrust. It is to be condemned in both the micro sense and the macro sense.

A great contemporary myth, which unfortunately is even believed by some gullible journalists, is that the economy is healthy. The myth is peddled by the same people who asserted in 1975 that the economy was in ruins, that indeed it was in such a condition that any political action, any sleazy act-as a present Liberal member of the House of Representatives, the then Senator Hall, described it-was justified in grabbing power. The justification given was the allegation that the economy was in ruins. It is worth while just to look at a few objective facts behind those two assertions that are peddled by the same people-that the economy is healthy now and that it was in ruins in 1975.

The outcome of the 1975 Budget produced this effect on the following major economic indices: The level of inflation was then 13 per cent and falling. At the end of June 1982, according to the forecasts put out by this Government, it will be 11.9 per cent, near enough to 12 per cent, and rising. In 1975-76 the rate of unemployment was 4.5 per cent and stable. The rate of unemployment now is 5.8 per cent and rising.

I now turn to economic growth. The level of non-farm real gross domestic product growth in the calendar year 1976-the period affected by the 1975-76 Budget-was 4.2 per cent. This level has not been reached in any year since. The forecast for this year by the Government is for non-farm real GDP growth of 3 per cent which the present indicators clearly show is an overoptimistic forecast. The range of interest rates, of course, can be measured. Right across the board, interest rates are now 3 per cent higher than they were in 1975-76. Of course, notwithstanding the assertions by the Treasurer that interest rates have at the very worst peaked and are probably falling, we saw that ridiculous and scandalous example yesterday where the Treasurer increased interest rates furtively and surreptitiously to a few favoured clients of this grazier Cabinet to 23 3/4 per cent, secure I suppose in the knowledge that the level of numeracy of members of this Parliament-certainly on the Government side, and probably in the community in general-is such that they are incapable of understanding just how much they have been ripped off by this scandalous decision.

It was asserted in 1975 that taxes were at a crippling level. As a proportion of GDP they are now 10 per cent higher than they were at that time due to what the Prime Minister used to call 'the secret tax of inflation'. Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers will pay 22 per cent tax more this year than they paid last year, even with so-called half indexation and real 40 per cent indexation. That has now finished. There are no constraints at all any more on what the Prime Minister used to call 'the secret tax of inflation'. At present rates of increase in money income, income tax, after adjustment for inflation, will grow by $1,500m a year. After adjustment for inflation there will be a real increase in personal income tax of $1,500m a year for as long as what the Prime Minister used to call-he does not talk about it any more-'the secret tax of inflation' continues. There are now no longer any constraints against it.

The position of single income families, about which this Government professes to be primarily concerned and about which so many of its back benchers make mawkish speeches from time to time, is much worse than that of taxpayers in general. It is much worse than the position of pay-as-you-earn or wage and salary earner taxpayers in general. Wage and salary earners' taxes will go up 22 per cent this year on the Government's own forecast. If we look back over the whole period of the Fraser Government, a single income family with two dependent children on average weekly earnings-the source of this data is not the Australian Labor Party and not even the Parliamentary Library but the comments of Eric Risstrom published in the Sydney Morning Herald last week-is paying anything up to 81 per cent more tax in real terms than it paid six years ago. It is not paying 81 per cent more tax in money terms but 81 per cent more tax after adjustment for inflation than it paid six years ago. That is what the Government has done for the group about which it professes to have a profound concern.

One of the most popular boasts of this Government right now is that the economy is in good shape, that growth has been restored and that Australia has emerged from the recession. It is true that growth last year in non-farm real GDP was in the vicinity of 4 per cent which is high only by comparison with the other Fraser years. It is lower than it was in 1976 when the economy, insofar as it can be controlled by a Budget, was controlled by the Budget of the Labor Government. The recession in Australia, unlike that of the rest of the world, bottomed not in 1974 or 1975 but in 1978 when non-farm real GDP growth fell to almost zero-specifically to 0.7 per cent. The recession bottomed after three years of Fraser and it is going in that direction again. Australia is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which has never had a recovery from the slump of the mid-1970s. This Government's economic policies, by its own terms, by its own standards, have been a dismal failure. The objective record cannot show anything else. Fraser looks good only by comparison with his alter ego, Margaret Thatcher whose acronym is TINA-there is no alternative. She will find out in a couple of years that there is certainly an alternative Prime Minister.

Is it worth looking at the OECD and the Australian figures for the major economic indices-unemployment rates, GDP growth and inflation rates-in respect of two period, namely the calendar years 1974-1976 and 1977-1979. Unemployment rates in Australia during the three years 1974-1976 averaged 3.8 per cent whereas in the OECD as a whole they averaged 4.6 per cent. For the latter period-the Fraser period-they averaged 6 per cent in Australia and 5.1 per cent in the OECD as a whole. GDP growth in 1974-1976 averaged 3.2 per cent in Australia and 1.5 per cent in the OECD as a whole. That was our performance during that period compared with the rest of the OECD. Our average growth rate in 1974-1976 was more than double that of the rest of the OECD. How has it been since? In 1977-1979-the Fraser period-non-farm real GDP growth was 2.5 per cent in Australia and an average of 3.8 per cent in the OECD. Only in respect of inflation did the Australian figures bear out what the Government keeps asserting is the international reality and then only to a marginal extent. Of course, in reality the figures refer to the 1977-1979 period; they do not refer to the present.

There is a preposterous claim regularly reasserted by Government spokesmen that we are beating inflation. However, the Budget documents show that the consumer price index up to the year ending last June increased by 8.8 per cent and the forecast for next June is 11.9 per cent. An increase from 8.8 per cent to 11.9 per cent is some way to beat inflation! It requires a great capacity for self-delusion to believe that we are beating inflation with this Budget. Those who have such a capacity for self-delusion mouth an associated piece of nonsense. It stands as a piece of nonsense quite independent of the fallacious assertions about inflation. This piece of nonsense is that if Australia has a lower inflation rate than that of our trading partners we can guarantee that we will remain internationally competitive. That has not been true since the Bretton-Woods Agreement was buried 10 years ago.

If the Australian inflation rate or if any country's inflation rate were consistently below the average of its trading partners, other things being equal as a consequence of that the exchange rate would be appreciated. The international value of the currency of that country would be changed upwards, not perhaps immediately and maybe not in a precise one-to-one ratio but the so-called competitive edge which a lower rate of inflation gives to a country would be eroded almost entirely before very long by exchange rate adjustments. I suppose to have a view of international exchange transactions which is only 10 years out of date, only 10 years behind reality, is not really that bad for a government whose views on general economic questions reflect pre-Keynesian primitivism.

This Budget achieves the almost unique distinction of being both contractionary and inflationary not because we of the Opposition say so, not because some academic economists which the Government regard as being kinkos might say so, but because this Government in its own published estimates in Budget documents, admits that economic growth will fall, and by a revised estimate would have to fall even more, and that inflation will rise from 8.8 per cent to 11.9 per cent.

I made a comment a while ago about pre-Keynesian primitivism. It is almost inconceivable. Indeed, it is conceivable I suppose only to those who watch Margaret Thatcher-TINA-that any government in the 1980s and even in the 1950s faced with an unemployment rate of 5.8 per cent and rising could bring in a Budget with a domestic surplus of $1,500m or if it is adjusted for the freakish event of an extra pay period, an effective surplus of $1,900m. There is some linkage between that high surplus, the high inflation rate and the decline in growth, all of which the Government itself has forecast. The linkage of course is the very high levels of indirect taxation which the Government has imposed in recent years and which it exacerbated with the sales tax Bills, some of which have managed to get through the Senate; more is the pity.

I would like to comment on just one other price. We know that the increase in the consumer price index, what is loosely called 'inflation' by the general public, is going up, according to the Government's forecast, from 8.8 per cent to 11.9 per cent. But there is one price that is coming down and that is the price of shares, stock and equity in public companies. On 9 October last year, which was just before a Federal election and when there was a perceived need by one media meglomaniac to prostitute his media outlets in order to minimise or defeat Labor's chances of winning government, the All Ordinaries index had fallen. It fell the day before to 661. The Daily Telegraph reacted with these headlines:
Mums and dads hit hardest say brokers

The brokers who allegedly said that were not identified, nor if they had been of course could anyone explain how they could identify whether it was the mums and dads or who it was who had been hit hardest. 'Millions lost in new plunge', shrieked the Daily Telegraph, and 'Labor's poll lead to blame'.

The infallible judgment! The All Ordinaries index then was 661. Ever since the middle of April this year that same index has been falling. It fell on 25 September to 563-16 per cent below what the Murdoch Press asserted was a catastrophic, disastrous level. It was 16 per cent lower 18 months later. There was no comment from the Murdoch Press. But there was this comment, and I quote from the editorial of the Australian of 29 September which reads:
One would think that the share collapse, and the low prices now being quoted, would spur the small investors to get into the market for bargains.

I suppose that is what Monty Python might call looking on the bright side. It is certainly not the hysterical, fraudulent reaction of the Murdoch Press at the time there was a perceived need, perceived that is by its megalomaniacal proprietor to destroy Labor's electoral chances. Just before I finish my remarks I want to make one other comment which I should have made when I was speaking about this fallacy that is mouthed by the mugs who are temporarily running this country. I suppose it is a charitable description to call them mugs. The alternative is that they actually do know better but they consistently follow policies that deliberately mislead the public. I refer to this nonsense that if a country's inflation rate is below that of its trading partners, international competitiveness is guaranteed. I leave aside of course the fact that our inflation rate is no longer in that position although it was a couple of years ago. In the annual report of the Australian Dairy Corporation I read with some horror yesterday this extract:
The Corporation appreciates the . . . overriding policy of containing inflation as being in the best interest of producer, manufacturer and consumer alike.
The first comment is that it swallowed this nonsense that inflation was being contained although in fact it is going up. But it got even worse. The report continued:

It is to be hoped that the Government's success in inflation control will ultimately permit some relaxation of the upward pressure of the trade weighted index on the value of the Australian dollar relative to its USA counterpart.

It might be necessary for those who are interested actually to read the text of that and work it out for themselves. But what these mugs are saying is that if our inflation rate is lower than that of trading partners, lower than that of the rest of the world, the pressures to appreciate the Australian dollar will disappear, will be deflated, which is the reverse of the truth. As I said, I read that passage with some horror. It was almost reminiscent of the profound economic illiteracy displayed by the wool industry knights, William Vines and William Gunn, back in the 1960s when they put up the ridiculous proposition that if the wool supply increased prices would rise. I had hoped that economic illiteracy at that level had been purged from Australian statutory authorities. Apparently that is not so.

My final comment before I move the amendment on behalf of the Labor Party is that the Government in a desperate last attempt to extract itself from the political difficulties of its own making and the electoral defeat which it now faces is orchestrating a campaign for phoney tax cuts sometime next year. I say phoney tax cuts advisedly because thanks to the secret tax of inflation, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) used to call it-he never talks about it now but a few years ago he used to talk a lot about the secret tax of inflation, which I mentioned earlier-at present rates of increase in money incomes, income tax will automatically increase by $1,500m a year in real terms-not increase by $1,500m but increase by $1,500m after allowance has been made for inflation. The reality of that is that any tax cut, so called, of less than $1,500m is a disguised tax increase. Any tax cut of less than $1,500m is phoney and is in fact a disguised tax increase. I know that the public interest in the details of these matters is frequently minimal. Even more deplorable, I suppose, is that much of the media has an equally minimal interest in them. I suppose the public reaction reflects that. It is vital that that simple arithmetic reality be recognised; under present circumstances any tax cut, so called, of less than $1,500m is a disguised tax increase. For those reasons, I move the amendment which has been circulated in my name on behalf of the Opposition. I move:
At end of motion add ', but the Senate rejects the budget strategy because:
(a) it deliberately reduces the rate of economic growth;
(b) it increases unemployment;
(c) it adds substantially to the rate of inflation;
(d) it relies on a massive private capital inflow;
(e) it fails to tackle the real causes of rising interest rates; and
(f) it increases the burden of taxation to the highest level in our history,

and in addition, deplores the Government's callous disregard of the millions of Australians living in poverty and its continued attempt to reduce the living standards of the great majority of Australians'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment moved by the Opposition to Appropriation Bill (No. 1). We wish to move an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add ', but the Senate considers that Appropriation Bill No. 2 should be amended so as to increase payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory in Division 896 under the Department of Housing and Construction for the purposes of the Housing Assistance Act by $189,300,000 to $251,500,000 so as to provide a total expenditure for the purposes of the Act of $451,500,000'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Siddons, although this is a cognate debate, the amendment moved by Senator Walsh in respect of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is the matter before the Chair. When that is disposed of, you can move your amendment in respect of Appropriation Bill (No. 2).
—Mr Deputy President, I think Senator Siddons might be confused. As far as I know, there is nothing to stop him speaking on my amendment or forecasting his own.
—Senator Siddons, I meant that Appropriation Bill (No. 2) has to be called on before you can move your amendment. At the moment you can speak in respect of both.

—Mr Deputy President, I foreshadow the amendment. In doing so, I want to point out two things. Clearly, Appropriation Bill (No. 2) is amendable by the Senate. Under the so-called 1965 compact the practice was accepted of having two separate appropriation Bills. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is for the ordinary annual services of the Government and is not amendable. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) is for capital expenditure and for grants to the States for such things as the construction of public works and buildings, the acquisition of sites and buildings, and items of plant and expenditure which are clearly definable as capital acquisition. Those capital items are contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which is clearly amendable. However, the Senate cannot amend Appropriation Bill (No. 2) under the terms of section 53 of the Constitution, which states that the Senate may not propose amendments in such a way as to increase the charge or the burden on the people. This means, in fact, that Appropriation Bill (No. 2) can be amended so as to decrease the expenditure on one item and increase it by a corresponding amount on another or to decrease the total expenditure. One may not increase it.

SPEECH.PARA: We gave careful thought to whether we should move an amendment reducing expenditure on one item under Appropriation Bill (No. 2) and increasing it on another. We were very tempted to do this because it is significant that under Appropriation Bill (No. 2) the allocation to the States for housing has been reduced by $24.3m. In 1980-81 the amount was $286.5m and it is shown in the Bill under discussion as $262.2m for 1981-82. That is a drop of $24.3m in the allocation to the States for housing. It is significant that in the same Bill the allocation for the new Parliament House is $24m. We have a situation in which the Government has seen fit to reduce the allocation to the States for housing by $23.4m and to create a new allocation for the new Parliament House, a luxury for the members of this Parliament, of an almost identical amount. It has taken money from the people for housing and put it into the expenditure for this current year on the new Parliament House. We were very tempted to move an amendment along these lines. However, we refrained from doing so because we felt that that may delay the passage of these appropriation Bills to the degree that it could cause hardship in certain sections of the community and may delay vital and important capital expenditures in other directions.

However, the Australian Democrats point out that they are greatly concerned about the contraction of the Australian housing construction industry. Adequate housing is one of the most basic requirements of a civilised and humane society, yet housing assistance to the States is being reduced. We have suggested in our foreshadowed amendment that it be increased by $189.3m. How was that figure arrived at? First of all, we took the amount of $165m-the amount recommended in the Democrat's alternative Budget-as the increase that could be afforded for housing. I point to the amount of $165m because it is significant that the Democrat's alternative Budget was balanced. We had an increase of $165m for housing and we fully indexed taxation, yet we were still able to have a balanced budget. Clearly it is within the realm of good economic management to make this additional grant of $165m to the States. To that we believe should be added the $24.3m that is being taken from the States this year in relation to expenditure last year. The $165m and the $24.3m add up to the $189.3m incorporated in our foreshadowed amendment which we hope will be attached to Appropriation Bill (No. 2).

I do not wish to pursue the importance of housing to any greater degree. It would seem to us to be self-evident that something has to be done. Apart from a basic human necessity, housing is, of course, a vital industry. It is one that would, if given additional funds, react quickly and substantially contribute to lowering the rate of unemployment in this country. We believe that it is intolerable that the States should be asked to take an actual reduction in their allocation for housing this year. In the amendment, the Australian Democrats are proposing that the reduction be restored and that an additional allocation of $165m be appropriated. I commend the amendment. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with grave concern that I continue this debate on the Appropriation Bills on behalf of the Opposition. I have grave concern for the elderly, the poor and the unemployed in the Australian community. I have grave concern for Australia's manufacturing industry and those workers whose livelihoods depend on its well-being. I have grave concern that this Government, in bringing down the 1981-82 Budget, has totally ignored the welfare of 90 per cent of Australians. In budgeting for a surplus of $1,500m in this financial year, the Government has deliberately taken money away from the people through massive increases in taxation to satisfy its manic desire to bring down the growth in money supply. This financial year pay-as-you-earn tax collections will increase by 22 per cent; indirect tax collections will increase by nearly 40 per cent; and, pay-as-you-earn taxes alone will account for 60 per cent of the total revenue increases. Receipts, as a proportion of the gross domestic product, will reach a record 27.5 per cent this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the Budget allows for $300m in tax avoidance by companies and by the wealthy. It is pretty obvious where this Government's sympathies lie. The increases in sales tax will particularly affect the low income groups in the community. Pensioners and the unemployed will be forced to pay more for pet food-up to a massive 17 1/2 per cent-clothing, footwear, sheets, blankets, pillow cases, towels and mattresses. The Australian Democrats would be advised to take note of the last five items, which are also regarded by most people as necessities of life. Pets are companions for many old people, but this Budget will make it impossible for many to keep their cats and dogs. So much for the lucky country!

The massive increases in taxes will also have a disastrous effect on the Australian economy. As manufacturing industry slows down, unemployment will soar to record levels. The Budget is deliberately designed to slow down the economy as a means of bringing down the rate of inflation. But the economy is already slowing down. Growth of gross non-farm products fell from 6.1 per cent in the first half of 1980-81 to 1.6 per cent in the second half of that year. Unemployment is increasing once again, rising from 5.2 per cent in June to 5.8 per cent in August. Not only is unemployment rising but also there are distinct trends towards long term unemployment. The most recent figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that more than one in five unemployed persons in Australia has been out of work for at least a year. Indeed the percentage of those unemployed for more than nine months has risen from 25 per cent in 1980 to 31 per cent in 1981.

The increases in indirect taxes in particular will have a catastrophic effect on many of Australia's manufacturing industries. Australian manufacturers have already been badly hit by the appreciation of the Australian dollar over the last 12 months. Already in the first quarter of this financial year imports have been at record high levels. The massive capital inflow which this Government has encouraged is directly to blame for this state of affairs. The imposition of increased taxes will only compound the problems of many vital industries as consumer spending declines.

In my home State of South Australia the motor vehicle and white goods industries, which between them account for over 25 per cent of the manufacturing work force, will suffer greatly. This Budget will also hit the already ailing building industry. Rising interest rates caused by the massive inflow of speculative money from overseas have already affected the demand for housing in Australia. It has become impossible for many Australians to save enough money for the initial deposit, let alone be able to afford the forever increasing cost of mortgage repayments. The latest figures released on home loan approvals by building societies confirm the downward trend in the building industry. In August the amount of approvals was $7.1m less than in July and $81m less than August 1980.

The Government's persistence in restricting the money supply and its stupidity in imposing sales taxes on building materials will plunge the building industry deep into recession. In fact, this Budget will throw the whole Australian economy deeper into recession. If the current trend of rising unemployment continues, the unemployment rate will reach 7.6 per cent by June of next year. All this Government can offer unemployed kids is useless training schemes, such as the Special Youth Employment Training Program, which is used by many employers simply as another source of revenue. We have already witnessed the fiasco over CYSS, the Community Youth Support Scheme, which clearly showed the insensitivity of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to the needs of the unemployed. There is no better example of this insensitivity than his recent advice to one unemployed girl when he was reported to have said that she needed a psychologist rather than a job. How dare a Government Minister make this sort of remark! Just think what it did to the poor girl's confidence.

Australia should be experiencing strong economic growth, but instead we have the spectacle of companies, such as ICI Australia Ltd, deferring construction of the proposed $500m Point Wilson petrochemical project in Victoria. The company has blamed the deferral on the Federal Government's mismanagement of the economy, pointing to the appreciation of the dollar, and its uncertainty with regard to future support for the manufacturing industry. Clearly, the Government is in trouble. It targeted for money supply growth in this financial year of 11 per cent, but the rate in July and August was equivalent to an annual rate of only 4.2 per cent. The possibility of a credit squeeze cannot be ignored. Even the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, has publicly opposed the stance of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in relying on foreign capital to maintain the growth in the money supply and compensate for the balance of trade shortfalls. The fact that inflation is now into double figures and rising clearly indicates that this Government's policies are not working. No doubt early in the new year we will see a mini Budget introduced in which Mr Howard will offer income tax cuts and try to persuade the Australian people that he is doing them a favour. He will have to do this to avoid too large a reduction in the money supply and a credit squeeze.

The Australian economy is in a shambles. As we come hurtling off the economic rails and follow the path of Britain and the United States of America, this Government is determined to plod on with its restrictionist monetary policies. The Government cannot simply rely on the phoney resources boom to provide the jobs which Australians need. Between now and 1985 over 700,000 new jobs need to be created in Australia. The most optimistic forecast of the impact of the resources boom shows that it will create only an additional 200,000 jobs. This Budget will not even create one of those additional jobs. The Government's economic strategy is being opposed by Australians from all walks of life. It is with grave concern that I also oppose this Budget which will only further increase the burdens on the majority of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on these Appropriation Bills. Two amendments have been mentioned-an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which has been foreshadowed by Senator Siddons. I want to indicate why I support the amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and why we will not be supporting the amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which is to be moved by the Australian Democrats. The amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) deals with the substance of the economic issues as we see them. That amendment is concerned about issues such as the effect on the Budget on families and the imposition of higher taxation-increased by 22 per cent-on pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. The amendment is concerned about the rate of economic growth and increased unemployment. The last paragraph of the amendment expresses particular concern about the number of Australians who live in poverty. However one defines the poverty line, a figure of 3 million Australians living below the poverty line has been bandied about. The figure might be 3 million or 2.5 million; it depends on one's definition of the poverty line. But it is a shocking thing to have said about a society such as the Australian society, a society in which we are parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the essential issues of the Budget, as indeed is the area of housing. I fully share Senator Siddons's concern about the level of the Commonwealth allocation in this Budget to housing. When one looks at a Budget one has a lot of concern about the general thrust of it and the effects it will have on Australians, particularly on the least wealthy members of the Australian community. What concerns me about the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Siddons is simply this: One could select for special attention any number of items which bear on the social good of members of the Australian community, such as the unemployment benefit, family allowances, the effects of inflation and interest rates, and one could say: 'Why don't we move an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) to increase the rate of the family allowance or increase the money available for welfare relief schemes or the unemployment benefit?'

One could do all of those things and the Democrats have chosen to do that in respect of housing. I do not want to be unkind to the Democrats but I rather feel that as a political party they see themselves as some sort of political equivalent of a rape crisis centre where anybody who has some complaint or feels threatened in some way or another can bring his cause, have it taken up and dealt with. I find that unfortunate, in a sense. What happens as a result of that is that undue emphasis is given to an issue when there are a range of issues which ought to concern this Parliament in the context of a Budget debate.

What has happened here-I assert this quite openly-is that the person who has sought relief in the Democrats' political rape crisis centre is Mr Kennett, the Liberal Party Minister of Housing in Victoria. It is common knowledge that Mr Kennett has been touting this issue around for a very long time. He could not get anywhere with the Federal Government and he could not get anywhere with the Opposition, so where did he go? He went to the Democrats. The Liberal Minister of Housing in Victoria went to the Democrats in search of succour. If I might use the word succour again, or with the same sound but a different spelling, that is what they are for taking up this issue. Let us look at Mr Kennett's performance as a Minister of Housing in Victoria, and his conflict with Mr McVeigh, the illustrious Minister for Housing in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —His voice is better.
—Mr McVeigh's or mine?
—Yours.

—Thank you. We can look at Mr McVeigh, the Federal Minister for Housing, in the House of Representatives. It is indeed difficult to find out what Mr McVeigh's thought processes on the subject of housing in fact are. Insofar as one can divine them, they have brought him into conflict with Mr Kennett in Victoria. Mr McVeigh felt constrained to point out to Mr Kennett at one stage that there is some case for putting your money where your mouth is in relation to matters such as housing. Mr McVeigh pointed out in the course of that disagreement between the Federal Fraser Government and Mr Kennett in Victoria:

SPEECH.PARA: The average expenditure on housing per head by all the State Governments in Australia is $16. The figure in Victoria is only $6 per head, and that is the lowest of any State contribution anywhere. So if the Victorian Government goes to Canberra to ask for further funds, it is speaking with a hollow voice because the Federal Government in Canberra-

Will refuse those requests. The Victorian Government came to Canberra and sought further funds. It failed and the Minister then went to the Australian Democrats, the alternative government as I think I heard Senator Siddons describe them, having an alternative government program for the land of Nod or somewhere like that, I suppose, but certainly not for this country. Mr Kennett went to the Democrats and prompted this amendment to Appropriation Bill No. 2 which Senator Siddons has foreshadowed.

I do not want in any way to decry the importance of housing. It is of vital importance. The performance of the Federal Government in relation to housing is abysmal and getting worse, but so is the performance of the Liberal Government Minister in Victoria. I have just read the figures which show what he is prepared to spend on housing in Victoria. What is Mr Kennett's solution, backed up against a wall as he is and having in front of him only the quaking Premier of Victoria? They all have their backs to the wall waiting for the axe of the next election in Victoria. There they are quivering away and Mr Kennett rushes off to the Democrats. He is trying to distance himself from the Fraser Government because he knows that if the members of the Liberal Party in Victoria can at least distance themselves from the Fraser Government they will not lose 27 seats in the next election; they will only lose about 15 seats.

I find it sad that the Democrats are being used by a smart, articulate, very capable, likeable young Minister in Victoria. They are being used as a Trojan Horse in his little scheme. The Democrats are a wooden horse being trundled into the Senate with Mr Kennett inside in an effort to embarrass the Fraser Government and distance Mr Kennett from the Fraser Government for the purposes of a State election in Victoria. What a shameful little exercise to be indulged in by the party which is going to keep people honest. I am very surprised that the Democrats have allowed themselves to be used in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget came out weeks before he made the statement.
—You should be concerned about housing, too.

—I read out the figures about housing. One of the Democrats can get up if he wants to and deny that Mr Kennett has been touting his bag around their camp. It is no good doing it by interjection. Let us hear it from them directly.
—We will.

—I hope the honourable senator does. I hope he is very accurate in what he says. I find this a most unfortunate exercise and, concerned as we are about housing, concerned as we are about the other issues which are dealt with in the amendment to Appropriation Bill No. 1, we cannot for those sorts of reasons support the amendment to be moved by the Democrats. By the way, let us look at the figures in respect of housing in Victoria and at the bona fides of my friend, Mr Kennett. He is one Minister in Victoria with a bit of style. I have a lot of admiration for him. Let us look at the allocation for housing in State Budgets. In Victoria in 1979-80 the allocation was $52.2m. In 1980-81 it was $67.1m. In 1981-82 it was $56.4m. The allocation was going backwards.

SPEECH.PARA: In New South Wales, just to take an example, the comparable figures are of the order of $90m in each case. I think it is sad that this matter has come up in this way. I think we should look at the real issue of the attention which the Fraser Government is paying to welfare housing. Although Mr Kennett is not good at allocating large sums of money to assist the housing situation in Victoria, he is pretty good on the rhetoric. Let us hear what he has to say. Speaking about the Fraser Government, he said:
. . . no idea of what's happening to people out there. They don't see the tragedy of people who have nowhere to live, and the effect on families.
Mr Kennett went on to say:
The situation is at the stage now where I must decide where my loyalties to the Liberal Party and the people I represent start and finish. I have decided that people are more important than politics.

That is pretty good stuff. Mr Kennett said that he had decided that people are more important than politics. I do not know whether that is foreshadowing a resignation in the near future, but I would think not, knowing Mr Kennett's upward political mobility. On 3 September this year Mr Kennett announced that he was unrepentent in his attitude to the Fraser Government and that he would fight this one to the end. Here it is-the end is here today-the amendment to be moved by the Democrats to Appropriation Bill No. 2. He is fighting it to the end. Mr Kennett goes on to say:
The Federal Government has got to realise that its policies might be very good for resource development, but they are hopeless for people.
He went on to deal with the figures on the allocation for housing. He indulged in a bit of xenophobia and said:
It's amazing. An extra $100 million in foreign aid just like that. Yet in housing they--
That is the Fraser Government-
Actually cut the money.
If Senator Siddons looks at the Victorian Budget he will find that shortly afterwards Mr Kennett actually cut the money too in the Victorian Budget. Mr Kennett went on to say:

Many of the marriages of low-income people without decent accommodation are breaking up. The Federal Government doesn't understand. They don't realise what they're doing to people. Instead of investing in homes that provide security and satisfactory living conditions, they are more willing to let families be destroyed and then pay the cost through higher social welfare payments.

That, if I might say so, is the nearest Mr Kennett gets in his rhetoric to a genuine, well phrased and articulate social critique of the importance of housing. That statement is important. It is related to all the other issues in respect of which this Federal Budget should be condemned. It is very hard for us to say that we will vote against a suggestion that $189m more be allocated to housing because, of course, that is important. But to single out that issue as the most glaring iniquity in this Budget, to single it out from all the other iniquities, the sins of omission in terms of social policy-'concern for people' as Mr Kennett would put it, concern for social welfare and concern for equality in society; all the things which are ignored by this Budget-particularly when one has regard to the fact that housing policy demands contributions from both State and Federal governments is, as I say, unhappily to allow oneself to be used for a shabby political trick by a clever politician in the State of Victoria who is anxious to distance himself from the authors of this dreadful Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators holding the balance of power in the Senate have been given a special deal on staff by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: We have only one of those.

I challenge the Remuneration Tribunal to look at the work that goes through my office and to compare it with the work that goes through other offices that I prefer not to mention. I challenge it to see the volume, the range and importance of that work and to compare it with the work of other offices. The mail that comes across my desk is numbered in the thousands.
