TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to announce today to honourable senators the Australian Government's decision on the question of Australia's participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force. In doing so, I want to set that proposal against the background of the history of the Middle East over the last 30 years, for it is only against that background that the importance of the proposal can be judged and the decision relating to it understood. Over the last three decades the Middle East has been the most unstable region in the world. This instability has had many causes, but what has given it special character has been the conflict between Israel and the Arab states. This has generated more bitterness, more hatred, more suspicion than any other conflict in the world during this period. Four times in one generation it led to war: In 1948 immediately after the creation of Israel; in 1956 during the Suez crisis; in 1967 and again in 1973. These wars not only disrupted the region itself, but also threatened the peace of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as war, the conflict caused a terrible refugee problem, fed fanaticism and terror, and distorted and warped the lives of the countries involved. By the mid-1970s, for example, Israel found it necessary to spend 36 per cent of its gross national product on defence, with crippling results for its economy. All efforts to end the conflict, and there were very many, failed in the face of accumulated suspicion and hostility. The differences appeared irreconcilable. Then, in November 1977, the nearest thing to a political miracle in our time occurred. In an extraordinary act of political courage and vision, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt flew to Jerusalem and addressed the Knesset, the Israeli Parliament. This single dramatic act created a new situation overnight. It set in train a process of negotiation between Egypt and Israel, with the United States of America closely involved. Within a year, this had culminated in the Camp David Accords of September 1978, and, in another few months, it resulted in the Egypt-Israeli peace treaty of March 1979.

These events were generally welcomed as an historic breakthrough. It was not a matter of believing that all problems were solved, for clearly there was a long hard road ahead and the principal actors would need not only great determination and skill, but all the support they could get from the international community, if they were to complete the journey. But the problems no longer appeared utterly intractable and a willingness to contemplate compromise had replaced complete dependence on solution by the gun.

The Camp David Accords and the peace treaty contained two essential elements. One dealt with the procedures for implementing 'full autonomy' for the inhabitants of the West Bank and Gaza after the establishment of an elected self-governing authority. The other dealt with the bilateral aspects of the peace treaty and, specifically, with the return to Egypt of the territory occupied by Israel in the Sinai Pensinsula during the earlier fighting.

Several things need to be noted about these two parts. First, they are not separate and discrete but interconnected, two parts of a total and very carefully negotiated package. In particular, progress on the future of the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza depends on maintaing confidence at the bilateral level between Israel and Egypt, and this in turn depends on the completion of the return of the occupied territories of the Sinai to Egypt. Secondly, the future attitude of the other Arab states to the Accords is likely to depend very substantially on the successful carrying out of the Accords as they relate to the Sinai. If the current reservations and suspicion of the Arab states are to diminish, it is essential that they be carried out. Thirdly, both elements of the peace process require substantial political and strategic concessions by Israel. These were agreed to by Israel in return for an agreement on a satisfactory set of arrangements to guarantee its security. It is here that the peacekeeping force assumes prominence.

On the basis of the confidence established at Camp David, Israel has already withdrawn from approximately two-thirds of the Sinai and, given the history of the relationship between the two countries, that it has done so has been remarkable. It is scheduled to have withdrawn completely from the Peninsula by the end of April 1982. But, as the text of the treaty makes clear, that complete withdrawal is conditional on the existence of a peacekeeping force which will supervise both the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and the implementation of the security arrangements agreed on in the treaty. The existence of an effective peacekeeping force in the Sinai, one which would by its presence secure Israel's southern flank, is therefore a necessary condition for total withdrawal. It would also help to create the kind of confidence required for progress to be made with respect to the West Bank and Gaza. The existence of such a force would not guarantee success-nothing can do that-but without it there can be little hope. The peace force that was envisaged in the treaty was a United Nations force. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to bring that into being. The Soviet Union, which has consistently opposed the Camp David Accords and which vetoed the extension of the mandate of the United Nations emergency force, stands as an insurmountable obstacle to its creation. The Soviet Union has consistently adopted an obstructionist approach to the search for a Middle East peace, has sought to encourage and take advantage of instability and to position itself to make strategic gains.

The question has been, therefore, whether, faced with the Soviet veto, there should be no force at all-with the disastrous consequences that would entail in the whole peace process-or whether there should be an international peacekeeping force outside the United Nations system. In considering that question, it should be noted that the likelihood of a Soviet veto was anticipated at the time of the signing of the treaty. In letters to both President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin, President Carter undertook that:

If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.

That letter and the assurance it gave were an integral component of the agreement reached by Egypt and Israel in 1979. The Australian Government believes that while it would have been preferable for the Sinai peacekeeping force to be established under the United Nations mandate-if that is ruled out by the position taken by the Soviet Union-in terms of what is at stake, in terms of peace in this highly sensitive region, it is infinitely preferable that there should be an international peacekeeping force created outside United Nations auspices than that the whole peace process should be frustrated by the absence of any force at all. Let me add that we should be careful, in a situation where it is possible to take significant initiatives for peace, before we circumscribe them by establishing circumstances in which the Soviet Union would gain a permanent capacity to interpose a veto, for that might give to the Soviet Union a greater power than it could manage on its own account to thwart and frustrate progress towards peace.

Granted that the need for a peacekeeping force to support the continuation of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty is accepted, the question remains as to whether Australia itself should participate in such a force. No one would pretend that this is an easy question to answer and this Government has deliberated long and hard over it. I make no apology at all for the time we have taken in coming to a decision. There are considerations which weigh for and against participation, and these were set out in the statement to the Parliament by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on 26 May.

A number of major arguments point in the direction of participation. Participation by Australia would encourage the formation of a more broadly based peacekeeping force which would enhance prospects for international acceptance of the peacekeeping force-a force which is needed to ensure that Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai can be carried out in accordance with international commitments. Australia has given strong support to the development of the peace process in the Middle East and has a responsibility to follow up with practical assistance. President Sadat took great political risks in initiating and persevering with the peace process and it is vital for his successors who have committed themselves to support that peace process that the remaining third of the Sinai still under Israeli control be regained by Egypt in April 1982. The failure of Australia and other Western countries to participate would require the United States to bear the burden itself and would be seen as a failure by the West to support United States policies in the Middle East. This would risk giving propaganda opportunities to the Soviet Union, whereas participation in peacekeeping would encourage constructive United States involvement in efforts to bring about a lasting settlement of Arab-Israeli differences. Our participation would be welcomed by Egypt and Israel, as well as the United States, and our participation would imply our continuing support for Israel's security. It would have positive impact on Israel's approach to negotiating similar arrangements for its other borders.

A number of arguments have also been used against Australian participation. It is sometimes said that our policy has been to participate only in United Nations sponsored peacekeeping operations, and that a force which was not broadly based would find little international acceptance. Some have said that the Middle East is remote from Australia and that the reactions of other states in the region might be adverse. Some have said that the extent of any Australian commitment would be uncertain and potentially too extensive, especially in view of our commitment to participate in peacekeeping in Namibia. Some have said that participation in a peacekeeping force in such a volatile area is too risky, and that it might even result in an adverse impact on support in Australia for our relationship with the United States. While there are weighty considerations on both sides a number of factors have led the Government to the view that Australia must be prepared to contribute to the multinational peacekeeping force. The starting point is that Australia has a clear and strong national interest in the progress of peace in the Middle East. It is first and foremost a matter of deciding what it is in our own national interest to do, and then acting accordingly.

Without question, the continued progress towards peace in the Middle East is of enormous significance to Australia. An outbreak of conflict would have repercussions not only for the region but also for the peace of the world which would affect us profoundly and in manifold ways. It would affect our allies and friends in ways which could not but impinge greatly on our international relationships and with risks for the strategic balance of great moment to our national security. Australia's interest is in seeing what is probably the single most serious threat to world peace removed. Further warfare in the Middle East could trigger off a much wider war. Australia has a legitimate interest in preventing this. This point is so evidently true that I believe it does not require elaboration here. There is also the economic fact that Egypt is Australia's largest single trading partner in the Middle East. As the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said in the House of Representatives yesterday, a stable Egypt is very important to the whole of our trade with the Middle East region. It is in the interests of Australia and the whole world that Egypt's stability be maintained, and this maintenance requires continued international support for the policies commenced by President Sadat, and which his successor President Mubarak is pledged to continue. That we have an interest in peace, rather than war, in the Middle East is, I believe, indisputable.

This leads to the second fact which has weighed in our decision-that the peace process which has been begun in the region under the Camp David Accords is the only framework for peace which has been put forward in the long history of that region which shows some prospect of achieving its immediate objectives. While other proposals have been made from time to time, none has yet achieved the degree of acceptance from Israel and Egypt the Camp David Accords have achieved. Senator Church made this point eloquently in Canberra yesterday when he said:

There has been much said for and against the Camp David Accords, but remember that those Accords, though they are still only partially implemented-and far from perfect-represent the only formula that has yet achieved a peace in this part of the world . . .

A central part of the Camp David process is the establishment of a peacekeeping force in the Sinai. The Government is aware that many Arab governments have stated public opposition to the Camp David Accords. The Government believes, however, that there is support for the concept of returning Arab land to Arab sovereignty; in this case returning Sinai to its rightful owner, the Government of Egypt.

The Government attaches great importance to its relations with Arab countries, and understands their wish to achieve a settlement which makes proper provision for the interests of the Palestinian people. Australia hopes that its relations with Arab countries will continue to develop. There is a growing realisation that many countries, including a major part of the Arab world, are seeking the same objective-peace. Given that peace in the Middle East is in Australia's national interest, and given that the only existent basis for peace is Israeli-Egyptian accommodation, and the establishment of a multinational peacekeeping force, Australia cannot avoid the question: Do we have a capacity to make a contribution to the peace process by membership in that force? One fact is plain: There is a limit to what Australia as a middle power can do. We must avoid an unrealistic view of what we can achieve. But to say that there are limits is in no way to say that we could not make a useful and a valuable contribution, in conjunction with other countries which share our interests and our concern for peace in the region.

Egypt, Israel and the United States-the nations which signed the agreement in August this year providing for the establishment of a multinational peacekeeping force-have made it clear that they would welcome Australian participation in the force. Indeed, they have indicated that they attach great importance to our participation and that the assassination of President Sadat has made that participation even more important to them. President Sadat's successor, President Mubarak, has indicated his determination to remain on the course set by his predecessor. President Sadat's assassination has in fact created a greater need for international recognition of the conditions for peace in the Middle East.

Egypt without President Sadat needs more support from other nations to continue the peace process than Egypt with President Sadat, and the Egyptian Government made clear to the Deputy Prime Minister on his recent visit that this was very much its own perspective. This consideration has weighed with the Government and has been significant in tipping the balance in favour of participation in the peacekeeping force. We have a capacity to contribute, and our contribution is sought by the countries most closely involved. These facts place the most weighty responsibility on us. This Government has never taken the view that Australia should refrain from doing what it can to create a better and more peaceful world. Within realistic limits we have consistently argued that Australia has responsibilities, and must recognise those responsibilities in our actions.

Australia has had recent involvement in peacekeeping in the Middle East: Australian forces were part of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Sinai from 1976 to 1979 and were only withdrawn when the Soviet Union indicated that it would veto an extension of the force's United Nations mandate. In this case it would obviously be more comfortable to do nothing-to say that peace in the Middle East does not concern us, or that we cannot contribute to peace. But neither of those propositions would be true. Those attitudes widely adopted amongst nations in other times and in other conflicts have led in the end to catastrophic war. If all nations wanting peace were to leave the active pursuit of peace to others, peace would fail by default-and we would all bear the tragic costs. Australia is concerned. We can contribute. And accordingly, we have decided, provided certain reasonable conditions are met to make a contribution to the multinational force.

On 12 October the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wrote to President Reagan informing him that the Australian Government would agree to participate in the peacekeeping force if certain conditions were met. The Prime Minister informed President Reagan that the Government has decided that Australia will agree to participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force subject to Britain and Canada also agreeing to participate. In the interests of obtaining the broadest-based international acceptance of the force, significant European participation is a critical factor. We are glad to see from published reports that France is reconsidering her attitude. The Australian contribution would be limited to the contribution we are initially called upon to make, and that contribution will be of limited duration to be agreed.

Apart from the membership of the peacekeeping force there are other matters which the Government believes are important to provide full protection for Australia's independence and sovereignty, and which were set out in the Prime Minister's letter to President Reagan. As is usual practice, we would need to instruct the commander of any Australian contingent that if he received orders from the commander of the force which he believed were contrary to, or went beyond, the agreed purposes of the force, he should not comply with them until he had consulted with Australian authorities. No part of the peacekeeping force, including the United States component, should have any association with the United States Rapid Deployment Force. A solution to the Palestinian issue is clearly central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East. In participating in the Sinai peacekeeping force we would be concerned that our contribution would have the maximum positive influence in continuing and broadening the peace process in the Middle East. Australia has consistently supported the continuing peace process but we have been disappointed by the lack of progress and prospects for further movement in the autonomy negotiations.

The Prime Minister stated in his letter to President Reagan that Australia will be looking to the United States to exert and sustain the strongest pressure to ensure effective progress in implementing the Camp David Accords as they relate not only to the Sinai but also to Palestinian autonomy.

We recognise how much the United States has been doing in an endeavour to establish lasting peace in the Middle East. We recognise also what President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin were trying to do in their search for a peaceful solution. It is important for the Middle East and for the whole world that these efforts should be continued and should have the widest possible support.

Our participation in the peacekeeping force would be on the understanding that all the parties to the Accords abided by word and deed with their provisions, and press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East. The conditions necessary for Australia's participation have all been conveyed in the clearest terms to President Reagan. The Australian contribution under consideration at present comprises elements of an air transport unit, equipped with helicopters and fixed wing aircraft, and probably involving some 200-300 personnel. But the precise composition of our contribution will of course depend on the outcome of discussions with other participants. I want to set out step by step the timing of the decision and the discussions and consultations which led up to it, because it is important that there should be no misunderstandings about this. During the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting the Prime Minister obviously would have wanted to consult with leaders, and at the time President Reagan put the same suggestion to him and to certain other countries. As a result, our Prime Minister consulted with the Prime Ministers of Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom in Melbourne during the Conference. Then following the assassination of President Sadat, the Deputy Prime Minister consulted with Secretary of State Haig, Dr McGuigan, Lord Carrington and Mr Colombo, who were in Cairo for President Sadat's funeral. These consultations in Cairo took place on 10 October, and the Prime Minister was informed of their content by cable and in telephone conversations with the Deputy Prime Minister.

The decision that Australia would participate under the conditions that have already been outlined was taken on 12 October. I want to make it plain that that decision was taken after consultation with, and with the agreement of, the Deputy Prime Minister who was overseas at the time. The Government's decision about participation in the peacekeeping force and the conditions for that participation were conveyed by letter to the President of the United States and to the Prime Ministers of Great Britain and Canada on 12 October and the Prime Minister of New Zealand was subsequently advised of our position. It will be obvious to the Parliament that while Australia's decision was taken on a completely independent basis, the practical commitment which will flow from it will depend upon the decisions of other governments. That is why the Prime Minister said in the other place on Tuesday 'There is no procrastination on this issue by this Government' and also said: 'I expect to be in a position to make some announcement about this decision in the relatively near future, but that is not necessarily waiting on decisions of this Government, but decisions of other governments'.

It was appropriate, in view of the conditional nature of Australia's decision, that the other governments should have some time to formulate their own positions in relation to that, but it is the view of this Government that events have now moved ahead and that Australia's position should be made known. The Australian Government believes that this multinational peacekeeping force is a significant step for peace. It is not a decision which is pro-Arab or pro-Israeli. It is a decision pro-peace. It is a decision which could never have been made had President Sadat not taken his historic initiatives. The assassination of President Sadat has strengthened, not weakened, the need for international support for the peace process. A role of the utmost importance now falls on Prime Minister Begin. Many have questioned his approach to peace and the implications of his policies.

Australia has made abundantly clear on many occasions, its support for the State of Israel behind secure and recognised borders as specified in United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. Our credentials on that matter are not exceeded by any nation. So let me from that point of support and friendship say that much will now depend on Prime Minister Begin and on the Israeli Parliament. There are many who believe that it was President Sadat who was foremost in carrying the banner for peace in the Middle East. Notwithstanding that Prime Minister Begin has fully participated in the progress to that point, with President Sadat's death there now falls to Prime Minister Begin the opportunity to hold aloft the banner of peace that President Sadat carried with such courage. Prime Minister Begin now has the opportunity to make sure that the autonomy talks are meaningful, and do all that he can to bring about positive results. Let him make sure that there is a true and fitting memorial to President Sadat in a peace settlement that can endure and that leads to a wider settlement in the Middle East. There is a challenge before Prime Minister Begin, Israel, Egypt and other countries such as the United States to act with vigour and initiative so that those who celebrated President Sadat's death by firing their guns for joy are confounded, and the terrorists and promoters of discord are defeated. Let those who have used terror as an instrument recognise, with the vision of a Sadat, that the true road to peace lies in a recognition of Israel's right to exist, then discussion and negotiation can replace the sound of gunfire.

In making this commitment I wish to emphasise that what Australia will contribute to is a peacekeeping force-not to a conflict. The Sinai peacekeeping force will not be taking sides with either Egypt or Israel. It is not going to be involved in either military attack or defence in any military sense. Its role is to monitor, to observe. I consider it most understandable that when two countries, with a long and sorry history of mutual conflict, decide to put this history behind them and engage in a new era of peace, they should wish to have mutual friends in whom they can have confidence to assist them in the sensitive business of overcoming past suspicions. The Sinai peacekeeping force is to play the role of mutual friend. If the time should come when either party should wish to attack the Sinai force, then the whole peace process would have come to an end. By definition the force's role would also have come to an end and it would leave the region. But this situation will not come about, and it will not come about because Australia and other countries are ready to play their part, which is after all a modest part, in ensuring that Israel and Egypt pursue their mutually declared objective of developing a new and friendly relationship.

I realise that at the moment there are differences of view on this important issue. I hope that honourable senators and the Australian public will give very careful consideration to all the considerations I have mentioned and will agree that in the end the right course for Australia is the one the Government has decided to take. Australia has played a significant role over many years by its willingness to contribute to peacekeeping forces in trouble spots around the world, and while this particular decision has been more finely balanced than others, I have no doubt that in the end the easier decision would be irresponsible and wrong. The easier decision would be one we might well live to regret, for surely none of us would want the situation in which a failure on our part to help two countries in their search for a lasting peace might contribute to increasing instability in a region where it is the interest of Australia as of the whole world that there should be increasing stability.

I appeal to members of the Opposition not to seek to divide Australia on this issue. I appeal to them not to be swayed by talk of war when the proposition and possible prospect is one of peace for one of the most war-torn parts of the world. The conditions wrapped around this particular decision are such that all parties can accept the decision itself as one that in no way derogates from Australia's sovereignty, as one that recognises our responsiblities to do what we can to help achieve the objective of peace that is so close to the hearts of all Australians and as one that is in Australia's widest national interest. I commend the statement to the Senate and move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) has just read a statement which has been read by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the House of Representatives. There are two very significant pages in that very lengthy document. Page 6 really indicates what the Government's decision is about insofar as one can divine it from reading page 6. On page 10 the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to members of the Opposition not to seek to divide Australia on this issue.
I am sorry, but that is an appeal which falls on deaf ears. The statement also appeals to us:
. . . not to be swayed by talk of war when the proposition and possible prospect is one of peace . . .
We do not have many debates on foreign affairs in this Parliament. Perhaps we should have more. On page 10 of this statement the Prime Minister-I take it they are his words-states:
. . . I have no doubt that in the end the easier decision would be irresponsible and wrong.

What does 'the easier decision' mean? I do not think this was a hard decision for the Prime Minister. He has been seeking to make it for weeks. It was not a hard one for him to have to make. He wanted a decision which would bolster his amibitions and so on as an international statesman. There is a bit of nervousness about that in this statement. On page 8-a very significant passage, I think-he says:
I want to make it plain that that decision was taken after consultation with, and with the agreement of, the Deputy Prime Minister who was overseas at the time.

Why is that inserted in the statement? It is inserted in the statement because many people in the community believe-rightly so, I think-that this is a decision of the Prime Minister. In the current state of volatility within the Liberal Party he has to be very careful about making those grandstand decisions on his own at this time. He has to embrace in the statement the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and go to specific lengths to mention that the Deputy Prime Minister was involved in this decision. I would have hoped so. I would have hoped that any government taking a decision as serious as this would embrace the views of the Deputy Prime Minister and other Ministers. I am very gratified to see that at least the Deputy Prime Minister was involved in this decision. I wonder who else was.

The essential part of the statement is that a force of between 200 and 300 Australians will be sent to the Sinai. It is still undecided whether that force will have aircraft or helicopters, et cetera. However, that force will be sent subject to certain conditions. The Prime Minister says that on 12 October, some 10 days ago, he wrote to President Reagan telling him we would participate under certain conditions. The first condition was that Britain and Canada should also participate. Why should they participate? We do not know whether they will. I should have thought the British Government would be very ill advised to send British troops to the Sinai having regard to the history of British involvement in that region. The second condition it that a significant European participation is a critical factor. What is meant by 'a significant European participation'? Who is he talking about? Who decides what is significant? Who decides what is participation? What does that expression mean? The third condition is that the force will be there for a limited time. What is a limited time? I remember hearing a similar expression in about 1963 when advisers were first sent to Vietnam. The fourth condition is that there be no association with the United States Rapid Deployment Force. Who guarantees that? What criteria are available to us to determine whether there will be an association with the United States Rapid Deployment Force?

Those are very serious qualifications and in a strange way they go to the question of Australian sovereignty in relation to this issue because the statement brought down by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate is in fact the response to an ancient summons made by ex-President Carter. The advisability of this course has been a matter of discussion for a very long time and we are now responding to that summons. However, we are responding to the summons, not so much because we believe in putting our troops where our mouths are, but subject to the assurance that Britain and Canada, which we have selected as the other two powers which should be involved in this matter, also agree. We are doing it on the basis that there be a significant European participation. So ultimately the Australian decision will not be made in this Parliament or in this country; it will be dependent upon the views of foreign governments and foreign parliaments in Europe, Canada and the United Kingdom. That is where the ultimate decision lies. Of course it is a provident, sensible and prudent course to say we are not going to do it alone; it is a very sensible course and the Government is to be congratulated for that. But ultimately the decision on whether Australia participates will not be made here.

Let me say, speaking not so much as an Australian Labor Party senator but as an Australian, that I am sick of those decisions about the commitment of Australian troops being made elsewhere. That is the entire history of this country. Australia's involvement in international affairs has a history of glorious failures, from the Boer War to Gallipoli and to Vietnam. Perhaps it was not a glorious failure in Vietnam, just a failure. In all those areas Australian troops have been committed because some foreign government has crooked its finger and sent out the call for Australian troops to be involved in an exercise which does not involve the basic concerns of this country-not at all. The Sydney Morning Herald referred to that this morning in its editorial. It stated:
Why should Australia which has plenty to occupy itself in its own strategic neighbourhood, get involved in a Middle East mess like that?

That is a question which could have been asked year after year and decade after decade in relation to decisions made by conservative governments in Australia in conjunction with conservative governments elsewhere to commit Australian forces to ventures of this kind. It would be understandable if one felt for a moment that this Government had a world view about some of these issues. This statement of the Prime Minister is full of rhetoric about the importance of international justice and international peace and about the importance of hosing down the inflammable situation in the Middle East. It is full of rhetoric about that sort of thing. However, where is the Prime Minister's world view when it comes to considering issues in South America, for example? The same sorts of questions are involved there-the question of sovereignty of particular countries, the question of corrupt regimes and so on. Where is the Prime Minister's world view in relation to the situation in El Salvador? It is very different from the Canadians there; it is very different from the French there. They are the people whom he calls upon as being suitable fellow participants in this venture in the Middle East. Canada and France have a quite different view about South American realities from that of the international statesman, Malcolm Fraser, the hero of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting's Melbourne Declaration and so on. There is no consistency in his world view because, on the one hand, he spends his time sucking up to American Presidents and, on the other, he spends his time hosting CHOGM and attempting to persuade the world of his bona fides in Africa, about which I happen to believe he is genuine. There is an inconsistency in all of that and it is important that when we consider these issues we should debate some of these matters.

So, if the Government has its way, by Anzac Day next year Australian troops will be in the Middle East for the first time in a number of years, apart from the small peacekeeping force referred to in the statement. We will be exposing those troops and this country to further involvement in the region through the errors and commissions of foreign commanders and foreign governments and the policies of others. For those reasons, the Sinai venture is seen by the Opposition as not being without very serious risks in terms of command and in terms of overall purpose. The rhetorical question that can be asked in strategic and world terms is: Why should Australia contribute military forces to the Sinai? Some argue, first of all, that in a world of economic interdependence the stability of the Middle East, which is a major oil supplier to Europe, Japan, to some degree Australia, and the United States, is important to all countries because of our links with world markets. If that is the basis for the commitment, Japan should be providing the largest force in the Sinai because it has the biggest stake in Middle East oil supplies; it has the biggest stake in Middle East peace in economic terms. Has Japan been asked to contribute by President Reagan? Has Japan made an offer? If not, why not? Why has Australia been asked? Certainly Japan's Middle East interests are much greater than those of Australia, and Japan, like Australia, has a security treaty with the United States, which is sponsoring this force.

Another aspect of the proposal which disturbs the Opposition is the fact that the emphasis and purpose of the multilateral force seems to have changed since it was first touted. Originally it was intended to protect and further the Camp David process but now, in the wake of the death of President Sadat and the emergence of instability in Egypt, it seems, if one looks at the statement and pays by weight, that the main purpose of the multilateral force is physically or symbolically to prop up the new Egyptian regime of President Mubarak. The history of propping up unstable, unpopular or incompetent regimes in Iran, in South Vietnam and in South Korea would provide many lessons to any government but a Liberal government led by Malcolm Fraser. In the end, the Shah of Iran collapsed under the weight of arms intended to support him. He collapsed under the weight of the hostility that his policies and American policies stirred up in the Iranian people. In Vietnam, a generation ago, President Diem collapsed under the weight of American arms and his own unpopular policies. There are many other past examples, and there are future possibilities of this sort of event if we do not have some better world view of Australia's role in international affairs.

Of course the Opposition understands the importance of Egypt in this situation. It understands the importance of President Mubarak's success, the importance of progress towards a Middle East solution. But the Opposition just does not understand the Government's claims that the best way to go about that is through a multinational military force in the Sinai. At the same time as the Sinai force is being patched together, one patch depending upon the arrival of some other patches from other places, and a recognisable and significant European presence and so on, there is an American build-up in Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia of arms aid and bases which bears a sinister resemblance to what happened in Iran and Vietnam. There is a Soviet build-up, too, in countries which fall in the status, I suppose, of remote or mini-satellites of the Soviet Union.

If this Government is to commit troops it should also obtain from the United States and other nations involved in Sinai some recognition that there will be a renewed and greater diplomatic effort for a Middle East solution. In other words, the Government should not think it can rest on its laurels on the Sinai troops issue, if that is how it perceives the matter. Any effort at a greater diplomatic solution to the problem would involve some consideration of the Israeli position relating to the other half of the Camp David Accords dealing with the West Bank and so on. As the Prime Minister rightly points out, there is a lot of onus on President Begin to do a few things in pursuit of the Camp David Accords which he has been pretty reluctant to do to date. Those matters would have to be taken into account in pursuit of greater diplomatic efforts to solve the Middle East problem. If we commit troops to the Sinai it may be of more help to Egypt's internal situation than it is to the longer term aid of a Middle East solution. So the Government should now promise and explain in some detail its post-Sinai policy. If there is no wider Middle East solution than the Sinai force it may well be there indefinitely, and the longer it stays the greater the risk of it being involved in hostilities.

This Government is taking a very high risk decision and the Australian people should understand those risks. If ever there is a nation which, from years of bitter experience, has had its fingers burnt as a result of this kind of venture it is Australia. This decision was glibly entered into not because of all the attention which the Prime Minister claims in those agonising sentences in the statement, the work of some wordsmith in his Department, but because the Prime Minister has been desperate to make it for weeks on end in search of his own aggrandisement. It is a dangerous way for a government to make decisions. We think it is a wrong decision. We think it is a wrong emphasis in trying to provide a solution to the long-term problem of the Middle East. We think it is inconsistent with Australia's overall attitudes to world realities and, as I said earlier, we think it is a decision which we should be warned against by the sad history of previous involvements of this country in efforts of a similar kind.

We do not seek to divide Australia on this issue. We seek to have a government which makes sensible decisions about this matter and recognises Australia's place in world affairs for what it is and does not go on with all this tub thumping and so on which is contained in this statement. We will fix that up at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are opposed to sending Australian troops to Sinai. There are no geographic, historic or other reasons why we should take part in that force and many reasons why we should not. I will deal with some of those a little later. This decision is an irresponsible act that is plainly against the wishes of the majority of Australian people. I believe that it is an act of cynicism on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and for the Leader of the Government (Senator Carrick) to have stated that the Government had no wish to divide the Australian people and did not want the Opposition parties to divide them over this issue. I have news for both the Prime Minister and Senator Carrick. The Australian people do not want it and the effect of the Government's statement will indeed be to divide them very deeply and profoundly over this unwise and stupid decision. It is perhaps not too late for the Government to change its mind. I hope that will be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Are the Australian people really against it? Of course they are. This has been shown by polls already conducted. For instance, the poll conducted by the Melbourne Age on 21 September showed that 72 per cent of Australians were opposed to sending troops to the Sinai. It is not just a matter of a 51-49 vote. This represents a vote by virtually three-quarters of Australians against the proposal. There is a parallel with the sales tax legislation as it concerns the necessities of life. Again the Government is flying in the face of public opinion. I wonder how, in a democratic system, the Government feels that it can justify this under any circumstances.

This matter is one of deep concern to the Australian Democrats, whose opposition to an Australian contribution to a Sinai force was specifically reaffirmed by a motion of the national convention of the party in Brisbane last month. I believe that most Australians, if they had the choice, would rather see us tackling the issue of East Timor, which is close to us and with which we are morally involved. This is very much to the point because the parallel with East Timor must be one of the deepest possible irony. Here we have a small country just to our north, one that is close to us, with which we do have geographic and historic links of the deepest kind, a part of the world where people gave their lives in tens of thousands in order to enable our people to escape during World War II, and we ignore it. The Australian Government has said that it is its policy to accept the six-year pattern of aggression and genocide employed against these people. The Government now has the cynicism to say that something that has happened in the Middle East, far away from Australia, historically and geographically, where we have no obligation, has to be acceded to.

It seems to me to be a matter of deep concern to the Australian people that this sort of judgment in foreign affairs should have been made by the Government, that it should have said: 'Yes, we will commit Australians and accept the possibility of Australians fighting and dying in the Middle East but there is no way in which we could go back to Indonesia and say: ''These people should have self-determination. Maybe we could have an armed force in there if necessary to see that things work out equally for the people and that there is fair play in the small territory, which has been damaged so much''.'

The Sinai decision is wrong. It has ominous and possibly tragic possibilities for the future. It is rather surprising that 10 days have elapsed since the Prime Minister wrote to President Reagan without this Parliament being told anything about what was going on. I suggest that this is in effect rather contemptuous treatment of this Parliament which at least might have been told of it. Did the Government have the opportunity to tell us? Indeed, it did. Only two days ago, on Tuesday, I asked the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate, a detailed question concerning what progress had been made in regard to the Sinai force situation. I was given the extraordinary answer, for a question which presumably a senior Minister would know about, that I had better place it on notice. That was indeed extraordinary but now, of course, I appreciate that the Government already knew that Australia would go into the Sinai but was not prepared, when a member of the Senate asked a question, to reply to it-stating instead that it should be placed on notice. That seems to me to represent a degree of dishonesty and dereliction of duty towards the Parliament that it is very difficult to comprehend. I hope that it will not be repeated.

That one example should be enough to show starkly that the Government, the Executive, sees itself as a sort of dictatorship of this country, that it does not accept any responsiblity to provide information to honourable senators who, after all, with their fellow members of parliament are the representatives of the Australian people. If the parliament is to be treated in that way in the future, I hate to think how far the precedent might be extended. We derive from it the idea that no matter what happens the Government will make the most deeply involving arrangements for the Australian people, such as this might be, and then go ahead and blandly say that it will not tell the Parliament about it.

There are great dangers of a major conflict developing in which our people will be heavily involved if they are sent to the Sinai. The movement of peoples and goods out of Sinai itself may well be a violent process. It is certainly unlikely, in any realistic view, to be without incident. However, one of the main reasons why we should not participate is the fact that it is not to be a United Nations Force but rather one sponsored by the United States of America. I want to make it quite plain that the Australian Democrats are not in any way adopting an anti-American role, far from it, but we do foresee problems.

In June of this year, Senator Don Chipp and I, in a joint statement, drew attention to the grave dangers that could arise if Australia decided to send troops into the Sinai. We called on the Government then to declare publicly that Australia would not participate in the Sinai force. I would like to recapitulate some of the points made then because they are very valid still.

The parallels with Vietnam are too obvious to be ignored. In regard to Vietnam, the United States sent forces to a distant location without the endorsement of the United Nations on international opinion in order to promote what it saw as its national interest vis-a-vis the Soviet Union. The results were catastrophic for the United States and Vietnam and also, of course, for this country. We cannot run the risk of the same thing happening again in the Middle East.

Secondly, we considered it objectionable that Australian participation in the proposed force should be sought by Washington in order to give the appearance of general support and respectability for the move when such support did not in fact exist. We made that statement in June. Were we prophetic or merely cynical? What is happening now is precisely what we forecast in that statement-the sort of situation in which we have said: 'We will be in it if Canada, Britain and a major European power will be in it. We will put our two bob's worth in and maybe that will persuade the others to do so'. That is exactly what we meant when we said that that appearance should not have been given by Australia. We are not in a position geographically, historically or even in size by world standards to make that sort of decision. Our decision should reasonably follow, if it is to be made at all, a decision by those other countries, not be contingent on the decision of other countries. Senator Button made the point very well that it is wrong that decisions of this weight in this country should depend on decisions made in other countries. Of course, such decisions will be made without regard to our interests. That is natural and reasonable. I do not expect the other countries involved to consider our interests. They must consider their own. That is reasonable enough.

The third important aspect on which we expressed concern in June was that the Soviet Union could use the Sinai force as a precedent for sending its own multinational so-called peacekeeping forces to distant trouble spots. Presumably, that is something that the United States and every other part of the free world would deplore, yet again we are creating the precedent. We can foresee, if this goes ahead, a situation in which zonal so-called peacekeeping forces on both sides roam the trouble spots of the world. What better combination for trouble and war could we get than that? The hidden trap that perhaps the Government has not understood is that by contributing to an American-sponsored force we are creating a precedent for the Soviet Union to say: 'If it is good enough for the Americans to do it, it is good enough for us', and the Soviet Union will go ahead and send forces to trouble spots such as Angola and have them involved in much the same way as our force eventually will become involved in the Sinai.

Is it a fair comment to attribute to the Prime Minister-that this would be a contribution to an American or a zonal force? It is a fair comment because the Prime Minister has said it himself. I have not heard anybody who has yet spoken about this matter draw close attention to the statement of the Prime Minister. On page 9 of his statement the Prime Minister said:

The failure of Australia and other Western countries to participate would require the United State to bear the burden itself and would be seen as a failure by the West to support United States policies in the Middle East.

So here we see the situation stated quite plainly by the Prime Minister in his statement. This force will be there to support United States policies. It is not for us in this place to debate extensively whether United States policies are justifiable. That is a matter for the Congress of the United State to debate and for the President of the United States to decide. But we are Australians and it is up to us to have some rights to decide how far we will be involved.

How far would we go to support United States policies? I repeat that these are in the Prime Minister's written words in a considered statement. Would we go to a limited nuclear war that President Reagan has recently talked about; to a Korean type war as has happened before; to a Vietnam type war; to a task force in some part of the Middle East to fight for the oil pipelines? These are all questions which I think are going to beg an answer before we are finally committed to this force. It would appear now that unfortunately the Government has committed us to such a force. That, of course, is the reason-this is relevant-why the Australian Democrats have moved in this place that no commitment of Australian troops abroad for a peacekeeping force or any other military purpose should be made without a motion of approval by both Houses of the Parliament because the Houses of Parliament are at least responsible to the people in a sense that the Executive is not.

It is a matter of record that half an hour after I gave notice of those amendments to the Defence Act, the Government removed that business from the Notice Paper of the Senate. It came up again recently; it was removed again. Is it because the Government did not want that matter to arise here before it announced its decision on the Sinai force? I fear that that may be the case. This is a classic example of the necessity for these sorts of amendments to the Defence Act that the Australian Democrats are promoting. Indeed, there should not be any participation in peacekeeping forces or any participation in any foreign adventuring without the approval of both Houses of the Parliament. If there is an urgent necessity, the Governor-General may approve by proclamation but both Houses of Parliament must be called together to approve of that within 48 hours. There is nothing new about this; it is done in other respectable Commonwealth countres. For instance, it is done in Canada. I think it is time it was done here and this decision is a perfect example of what I am talking about.
The Prime Minister on page 14 of his statement quotes Senator Church of the United States. The Senator, in a very reasonable statement, said:

There has been much said for and against the Camp David Accords, but remember that those Accords, though they are still only partially implemented-and far from perfect-represent the only formula that has yet achieved a peace in this part of the world-

This is given by the Prime Minister as justification for our participation in the Sinai force. Senator Church made the point in that quotation that the arrangement is not perfect, that it is far from perfect. Is a far from perfect Camp David Accord the best that can be got together following the death of Anwar Sadat? Is it not reasonable that we should perhaps look at the agreement again? Is it not reasonable that the whole question of consultation with the Arab world at large is at issue? Should this not be done before small middle powers like Australia decide we are going to commit our young men to an area which could explode like a powder keg and where their deaths can now be said to be a strong possibility? That is what we are talking about. We are talking about a decision which places the lives of young Australians at risk. The fact that they are servicemen, that they have enlisted in the martial profession, is no reason whatever to place their lives unnecessarily at risk.

I think that the Government is well aware, as the Prime Minister has said, that many Arab governments have stated public opposition to the Camp David Accords. The Government believes there is support for the concept of returning Arab land to Arab sovereignty. I suggest that is irrelevant to the basic issue of what is happening. It is the relationship between Israel and the United Arab Republic of Egypt which is at issue.
We find from reading page 19 of the Prime Minister's statement that the Australian contribution has not even been decided yet. The Prime Minister said:

The Australian contribution under consideration at present comprises elements of an air transport unit, equipped with helicopters and fixed wing aircraft, and probably involving some 200-300 personnel. But the precise composition of our contribution will of course depend on the outcome of discussions with other participants.

That is an extraordinary statement which worries me intensely. In other words, we do not have sufficient sovereignty in this place to say for ourselves what we are going to do. We are going to be told by somebody else what we are going to do. I suggest that is very serious. I recommend that the Australian people should read this implication in the Prime Minister's statement again and again. They should take this statement very much to heart because, in the Prime Minister's words, we are going to be called on to provide armed forces to serve in a hostile theatre of war far from our country. We are not even going to have the right to say ourselves what the force is going to do.
Page 25 contains what I think is the most tragic and cynical statement. It is a statement which I think is appalling in its implications. At the top of the page the Prime Minister said:
If the time should come when either party should wish to attack the Sinai force, then the whole peace process would have come to an end.
By definition the force's role would already have come to an end and it would leave the region.

How naive, how cynical can one be to say that if a group of 50 to 90 Australian soldiers in the desert come under attack at night from forces from either side and are forced to defend themselves the Prime Minister can sit back quietly in the safety of the Lodge and this place in Canberra and say: 'The whole peace process would have come to an end. By definition the force's role would already also have come to an end and it would leave the region'? This to me seems a tragic and terrible assessment of the situation.
I could say much more on this statement. However, I know that the Senate is pressed for time. I have made the main points that I wished to make. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
