TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of matters under this general heading, not the least of which is the situation relating to Airlines of Western Australia. If that name is unfamiliar to the majority of honourable senators, might I make the point that until recently it was MacRobertson Miller Airline Services. The name change has not done a great deal for the service unfortunately and will not prevent those people who rely on that service in Western Australia from affectionately or otherwise calling it Mickey Mouse airlines. There is a reasonably good reason for people in Western Australia to refer to it in such a way. However, because that airline has such a monopoly on air services in the State it is virtually able to run services when it is ready. I am prepared to admit that that may sound a trifle unfair, but I am sure it is not an unusual statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell the Senate what happened to me when I had to travel to Geraldton which is some 300 miles north of Perth or some 45 minutes flying time. Senator Thomas who comes from Geraldton probably experiences much more frequently than I do the problems of travelling to and from that place. I rang to make a booking and said that I wanted to travel on a particular day of the week and he said: 'Yes, certainly senator, 6.15 a.m.'. I said: 'No, I do not mind rising early but I prefer to travel a little later than that. How about noon?' He replied: 'No, if you don't go at 6.15 a.m. you can go at 6.45 p.m.'. I said: 'Why do I have to leave so early when it is going to take you only three-quarters of an hour to get me there?' He said: 'Oh, we would like you to be there for the start of the business day'. I am prepared to admit, Senator Thomas, that the people of Geraldton are very industrious but I do not know very many people in the city of Geraldton who start their business day at 7 a.m. If you want to travel to Geraldton in the morning you now have to leave at 6.15 a.m. and arrive in a country town at 7 a.m. Your alternative is to leave at 6.45 p.m. and arrive at 7.30 at night which is frequently too late to attend a dinner or an evening meeting and just a little out of the ordinary, I would say.

This is not unusual and I am not saying that it applies just to Geraldton. It applies to places even further up from Geraldton. The disadvantage that people in Geraldton and Carnarvon in Western Australia have is that they have to come down to Perth before they can go any further. The airlines do not, for instance, run flights from Geraldton say through to Karratha, Newman, Port Hedland, Broome or Derby. You still have to come down to Perth. The fact that the airlines do not charge you any extra-they charge you as if you were going directly north from Geraldton-really does not matter. The point is that you have the inconvenience of having to come down before you go back up. The reason they like you to travel that early in the morning to get to Geraldton is that they are not so concerned about getting you there for the start of the business day as they are about getting the people of Geraldton back to Perth for the start of the business day.

I think it is called something like utilisation of aircraft. I do not know about utilisation of aircraft. I have seen aircraft taking off at the same time in the morning with up to eight or nine flights leaving between 6 and 6.45 so I suggest that the aircraft are not being properly utilised. But I imagine that the difficulties which I experience when I travel to the north of my State and which Senator Thomas experiences when he travels are nowhere near the problems that are experienced, for instance, by Mr Graeme Campbell, the member of the House of Representatives for the seat of Kalgoorlie, who not only has the largest electorate but also has the inconvenience of having a monopoly airline in the State. This frequently prohibits his travelling to sections of the same area on the same day. For instance, he may be able to travel to one part of the Pilbara but he may not be able to get through to the other part without some unnecessary delay or having to come back down to Perth before he can go on any further.

There are problems of course with transport in the north of Western Australia because of the high prices that are charged. The charter aircraft companies, I know, are feeling the pinch at the moment and it is not surprising in view of the increase in the price of avgas and the subsequent increase in the price they now have to charge for their charter flights. But there are other problems because, for instance, they have to go to Darwin to renew their licences and to have their aircraft checked over. They also have the difficulties of coping in the wet. I remember one occasion when I went to Fitzroy Crossing on a beautiful fine day. I arrived there at about 12.30 in the afternoon and proceeded to attend to my state of affairs after having advised my pilot that I would be ready to leave at 8 a.m. the next day to go on further into the Kimberleys. Unfortunately, that afternoon at about 4 o'clock it started to rain and we had something like five inches of rain in four hours so it was impossible to get the aircraft off the ground. The airport was closed. Whilst I was able to hire a car and drive back to Derby and continue on my trip on the domestic commercial flights the pilot had to remain in Fitzroy Crossing for up to three days because he could not get his aircraft off the ground. I realise that these climatic conditions are not something that governments can sort out but there are areas that governments can sort out.

I think it is appropriate at this time in a general discussion that we have a look at the other airlines, that duopoly that has the charge of transporting people from one side of this continent to the other or up and down the east coast. I think I would qualify, after the 7 1/2 years that I have been a member of Federal Parliament along with other members and senators from Western Australia, as one of those people who travel perhaps more kilometres than the majority of other people in Australia. I am not bragging about that.

I am simply stating that I travel 7,000 kilometres every week, as do my other Western Australian colleagues, to get to and from my place of work. Whilst this session may be the shortest on record it does not mean that I and other members of the Parliament will not be travelling because we all serve on our various committees and that of course accounts for a certain travel period even when the Parliament is not sitting. The point I make is that in all of the time that I have been travelling I have never once been asked whether the aircraft are travelling at a time which suits me. But when I complain to the airlines that this is so they say they do constant surveys.

Coming from a background of radio, television and public relations let me assure the Senate that there are ways of conducting surveys and ways of conducting surveys. One of the best ways of conducting a survey is to frame the questions in such a way that you get the desired result. Just as a matter of interest on that same point, I have not met with anybody who has been invited to participate in one of those surveys either. But I can, for instance, imagine the type of question which would be asked. If you were on a midday flight or a flight around midday departing from Perth and your alternative was a flight at midnight and the question posed you was, 'Did this aircraft leave at a time that suited you?', then naturally you would say 'Yes', because you would not want to leave at midnight to land in Melbourne at 5 a.m. So naturally you would answer yes to that question. If that is the way the airlines conduct their surveys then they probably get the yeses in the right places and the noes in the right places. But it is not the way that people should conduct surveys.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that how they are done?

—I am not suggesting for one minute that that is the way they conduct their surveys. I am questioning whether in actual fact they conduct surveys at all because there are times when I feel that these two airlines have confused dual scheduling with competition. If I may give a further instance, on a recent Wednesday I wished to go to Sydney and having obtained a pair in respect of my commitment that morning I decided I would leave on a midday flight and come back on a flight which was to leave at 4.45 p.m. When I contacted the airlines I was told that the 12.40 p.m. flight had been cancelled. I said: 'Well, in that case I will try the opposition.' He said: 'Oh no, they have cancelled theirs as well'. I said: 'You mean no one has a flight leaving Canberra at about 12.30'? He said: 'That is correct'. I said, 'Well, I would have anticipated that if you were both going to cancel your flights one would have cancelled the 12.30 flight and one would have cancelled the 2.30 flight', to which he replied, 'If we did that it would not be considered competitive'. As I said, I think the airlines confuse dual scheduling with competition.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting now to see the attitude that has been adopted by both major airlines in this country in regard to the provision of a service by East West Airlines Ltd. I was very happy to note that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) had expressed criticism of both airlines on the matter that I have just raised and that is the cancelling of flights, sometimes at a minute's notice for the people of Canberra who want to travel between Canberra and Sydney and Canberra and Melbourne. A typical attitude has been adopted with the announcement that East West intended to provide a no frills service between Canberra-Sydney-Canberra at what I considered to be in these days of high prices a fairly reasonable rate. I am intrigued by the fact that now both of these major airlines have suddenly made application for and received permission to have these same no frills flights to Sydney which after all take about 35 or 40 minutes. Let me assure honourable senators that there is not much of a frill on such a service even for someone paying the full price. I would not call having a cup of tea plopped down in front of me and then the tray being taken away before I have had time to drink it a frill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends where you sit.

—I admit that it depends upon where one happens to be sitting in the aircraft, but that is the most frill I have had on a flight between Canberra and Sydney. I cannot understand how the airlines can reduce their prices so dramatically for a no frills flight anyway.
—But you don't get a seat, you stand up.

—If we are not going to get seats but will have to sit on the floor that will explain everything. I thought for a moment that it meant that we would have to sit out on the wings. I will wait with bated breath to see just how long it takes either of the airlines-Trans Australia Airlines or Ansett Airlines of Australia-to cut out the no frills pricing arrangement now that they have effectively squeezed out East West Airlines and revert to a system of higher pricing until eventually they decide to cancel that service when it is not profitable and then cancel other flights they they have scheduled.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Ansett has a distinct advantage with its no frills service because it has chartered an Airlines of New South Wales aircraft for the no frills flight. Of course, Airlines of New South Wales happens to be wholly owned by Ansett, which gives that company a little advantage. It has now forced East West into the situation in which, from offering to provide at very little profit, I assure honourable senators, a service to the people of Canberra who want to travel to Sydney and the people of Sydney who want to travel to Canberra, it has been effectively squeezed out of the market by a Government decision to allow the existing duopoly to operate the same type of service. Of course, East West has had to take the decision to defer the provision of that service. As I said, I will sit back and see just how long it takes before the other operators get back to their existing caper of cancelling flights at their whim, increasing prices and reducing services to the travelling public.

I believe that people who contract to do a particular job in a particular area have a responsibility to the people for whom they contract to do the job. In this instance the airlines have made a contract with the travelling public of Australia. If I happen to want to go to Sydney at 12.30 p.m. and they have scheduled a flight to Sydney at that time they are obliged to run it. If the airlines cannot run the service at a profit they should not be in the business. We should not allow this ridiculous attitude to our two airlines policy to continue any longer.

I want also to draw the attention of the Senate to a particular concern of mine. I am sure other Western Australian senators are equally concerned. I refer to an article in the Sunday Times of 18 October which describes the problems being experienced at Perth Airport in the traffic control area. It makes a damning statement. I am reminded of an incident which occurred some years ago when I was travelling overseas and I expressed my concern at the amount of fuel and luggage that we were told was on board the plane. Later, when I was invited to the flight deck, I said to the captain: 'Is that an unusual amount?' He said: 'It is a little more than usual and if we had had to abort we would not have been able to because the runway is not long enough at Perth Airport'. That did not make me very confident when I was coming back to the Perth Airport. The newspaper article relates to traffic control operations. I will read the article into Hansard. It may take a few minutes, but I am sure honourable senators will be interested and concerned. It appeared under the heading 'Air chief slams control of traffic' and was written by Peter Laud. The article states:
Operators in the air traffic control nerve centre at Perth Airport are using secondhand spare parts to keep operations going, a Government air chief said yesterday.
And he warned that Perth could lose some of its domestic and International air links unless a new $3.6 million control headquarters was given the go-ahead.
Mr H. B. O'Keeffe, Transport Australia's First Assistant Secretary (Airways Operation Division) said some key equipment was almost 20 years old-kept going with ''cannibalised'' spare parts.
He said: ''We have been doing a Band-Aid job on it for years.
''Certain components have for some years been available only through dismantling equipment of the same vintage and transferring it from other locations.
''The expansion of facilities is hampered by the uncertain availability of such obsolete components.''
He said at the airports's 12-year-old Kalamunda radar unit up to five operators were working in space designed for two.
Existing equipment at the airport-where annual aircraft movements have rocketed from 58,000 in 1970 to 81,000 last year-is due to reach capacity by 1984-when movements will have topped 100,000.
Pressure on air traffic controllers working in already overcrowded conditions was resulting in delays of up to 10 minutes for some outgoing domestic services.
And RAAF Pearce, centre of the Macchi jet training program and Australia's busiest military airbase, has been forced to limit navigational exercises.
A new air traffic control centre, to replace one built in 1962, is a key facility in a five-year development program at the airport.
Checks have revealed that:
Surveillance from the existing tower is difficult because of runway extensions.
Night observation is impaired by apron floodlighting.
The control tower cabin is too small for a new five-man console to handle airport traffic in the 1980s.

I think it is rather marvellous how we always tend to buy equipment that we need but we never make sure that we have the space to put it in. In this case we have a five-man console going into an area in which two people are overcrowded in their working conditions. The article continues:
Tenders for the new tower structure, estimated to cost $900,000, are due to be called next March.
If the Commonwealth Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works-which met in Perth this week-gives the go-ahead the new tower should be in operation by late 1984.
The number of air traffic controllers will rise from the present 57 to 88.
By the year 2000 Perth Airport is forecast to be handling 66,000 overseas flights and 181,000 domestic services a year.
Mr O'Keeffe said before leaving Perth for Canberra: ''If we do not take action and improve facilities aircraft movements might have to be restricted with Perth losing some services.
''It's either that or compromise on air safety and that would not be acceptable either to the travelling public or to the Department of Transport.''
Four units comprise air traffic services at the airport-the control tower, the area control centre, the Kalamunda radar unit and the flight service centre.
Mr O'Keeffe said the facilities at area control and flight service centre were of a design superseded 17 years ago.

I could be quite wrong in my assumption-if I am, I would like someone to tell me-but I assumed that there is a component for airport tax in each ticket sold and that that money is earmarked for the express purpose of providing new and better services at the airport. If I am wrong, I am quite happy to be corrected. If I am not wrong, I want to know what has been happening to the funds provided by those taxes over a large number of years. The cost of domestic flying has not decreased. It is all very well for the airlines to say that they have introduced APEX fares, three months in advance fares, and travel by night and pay by day fares or whatever they like to call them, but they service only a small section of the travelling public.

The people of Western Australia and elsewhere who use Perth Airport-I remind the Senate that Perth Airport is an international airport-are entitled to know that the facilities that are being used, firstly, to get them up and, secondly, to get them down again are the best facilities available, that they are not being kept together by band aids and that the people working these facilities are fully cognisant of the responsibilities placed on their shoulders when they report for duty. They cannot do that if they are working in cramped, overcrowded conditions with material that was, as Mr O'Keefe said, superseded 17 years ago.

The other point I want to raise very briefly-I do not intend taking up much of the time of the Senate-is the quite recent decision of the Western Australian Government to discontinue a large number of bus services in metropolitan areas. It has cut the schedules until it now appears that there is no public transport available after 7 o'clock at night. There are further restrictions during the weekend. Of course this decision falls on those people who can least afford the imposition. I refer to those people who do not have a car, those who cannot afford taxis and those on lower incomes who are dependent on public transport for a number of things. They are not only dependent upon public transport to get to the shops and meet with their friends but also dependent on public transport to keep in touch with the rest of the community. They are dependent on public transport to maintain a relationship with their families. A lot of people on low incomes do not live together. A lot of children of low income families no longer live at home. They have married and moved away from the family home but they want to maintain contact. Public transport provides them with the opportunity to receive medical, dental and optical care and whatever other care they may need.

We have to recognise the fact that even in this day and age a large number of doctors have evening surgery. I would suggest that it is sometimes more convenient, even for people who rely on public transport, to visit their doctor in the evening. This will not be possible for a large number of people who reside in the metropolitan areas of Western Australia because of the decisions of the Western Australian Government. It also means, of course, that unless they restrict their entertainment, these people are no longer able to go out and enjoy the theatre, the arts or whatever they particularly enjoy doing, even it if is only going on a bus down to the pub to play darts; it is an avenue for them to go out, but not under this situation.

The elderly and those people on low incomes who do not have transport will now be confined to their homes, unable to socialise and all because a State government will not accept that there has never been a public transport system in the world which has made a profit. There is never going to be a public transport system in the world that is going to make a profit and provide the service that the public, those people in the community, need and deserve. I think this is a backward step for the people of Western Australia. But, as Senator Thomas knows only too well, they will have their opportunity within the next 18 months to change the attitude by changing the Government in that State. I suggest that, if they are finding it difficult now, they can only look forward to much more of the same in the very near future. There is this distinct attitude on the part of the Liberal Party Government in Western Australia to make things as difficult as possible for low income people who reside in that State. I think that it is a criminal attitude for the Government to adopt and I condemn it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start speaking on the subject on which I wish to concentrate tonight, one of the matters mentioned by Senator Coleman came home fairly hard to me today. Next Monday, I have to go to a major provincial town in Victoria. I was not due to get back to Melbourne until about four o'clock in the morning. So I decided to come up to Canberra late on Tuesday, on the 12.40 p.m. Trans Australia Airlines flight. I was booked on that flight. Today I had a phone call to say that flight was cancelled. I immediately said: 'You had better put me on the Ansett Airlines of Australia flight'. Lo and behold, the Ansett flight was cancelled too. So Senator Coleman is quite justified in her criticism. The two-airline policy should not mean that because one flight is cancelled the other is also cancelled. Surely there are enough passengers to go on one of those flights?

SPEECH.PARA: I address my remarks tonight to the Australian National Railways Commission report. One of the surprising facts that has come out of that report and from other sources is that VicRail-the Victorian Rail Department-is leasing trains from the Australian National Railways. The reason is that 50 of its own locomotives are out of service. That seems to be an awful lot out of service. The reason for that is that there are not enough spare parts in Victoria for these locomotives. Also the numbers in the maintenance crews are down to rock bottom. So, we have 50 locomotives out of service. This will disrupt the grain harvest in the forthcoming year. I hope that will be of some concern to the National Country Party members here, including yourself, Mr Deputy Chairman.

There was a report in the Melbourne Herald on 5 October about the Victorian railway system. A special operation called the TERI-that is the Transport Emergency Resource and Information project-has been set up. One of its tasks, as reported in the Herald, was: 'To pacify angry passengers'. If honourable senators know anything about the Victorian rail system, they will understand why it has to do that. As well as that, the Victorian railway employees are given a course in how to use a loud hailer. I am not too sure that it was intended that they should shout down the angry passengers or use it as a dangerous weapon to knock them back. Nevertheless, we now have this special task force in Victoria to dampen down angry passengers.

Honourable senators might ask: Why does the need for this exist? There is no doubt that the Victorian rail service is absolutely deplorable. In the last year its loss alone was $189m. I ask honourable senators to consider that amount-$189m. The trains are expensive when one wants to use them. They are nearly always late or cancelled and they are extremely uncomfortable. We still have what we term in Victoria the 'red rattlers'. These are carriages that are 60 or 70 years old, made of wood and painted a rather grimy colour of red. They are a fire hazard. All that is needed is one match and they will go up as quickly as one clicks one's finger. Therefore these red rattlers cannot be used in the underground in case they catch on fire. They can be used only on certain lines. The real problem is the fatigue of the underframes. That means that if there is any accident-a head-on crash or something-the carriages end up like matchwood. Honourable senators can imagine what would happen to the people inside them. Every day in Melbourne trains are late and cancelled. On the Australian Broadcasting Commission 3LO radio station every morning a list of cancelled trains is read out, and it is never less than 10 or twelve.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least they advise you beforehand that they are cancelled.

—The radio station advises people of the ones the rail authorities intend to cancel. Just to make the game a bit more interesting, a few more are knocked off in the process in case anyone thought he or she would catch the later train. Fares have sky-rocketed in Victoria. From 4 October this year, some short distance travellers are paying 83 per cent more to travel by train. The average rise is 15 per cent, and that is virtually double last year's rate of inflation. In September, the Melbourne Age pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: Commuters from Blackburn, Huntingdale or Moorabbin would pay an extra $2.30, or a total of $10 for a weekly ticket, a rise of 33 per cent.

That rather strikes home to me because I live in Huntingdale and I catch the train from there. I am not miserable enough to try to bluff my way through with a gold pass, as I know some members do. I actually pay. I thought I was buying a train rather than paying for a fare into the city the other day.

Freight charges have gone up by 19 per cent in one year and will probably go up another 19 per cent for each of the next three or four years. The Train Travellers Association estimates that late or cancelled trains in Victoria cost Victorian business $450m a year. Earlier this morning I heard Senator Lajovic ask a question in the Senate, implying criticism at the New South Wales Rail Authority for lifting prices in Sydney. I checked the Sydney Morning Herald and lo and behold, many of the train fares have gone up by 10c! I think we should compare the two rail services. Since 1970, Victorian rail patronage has dropped by 38 per cent, yet, in 1980 alone, the rail patronage of Sydney went up by 17.5 per cent. Let us do a price comparison because I think that may indicate why one is dropping and one is rising. A four-kilometre ride in Melbourne will cost 70c. A comparable journey in Sydney is 30c. A 10-kilometre ride in Melbourne is $1.10 and a similar length journey in New South Wales is 50c. A 44-kilometre ride in Melbourne-Melbourne to Frankston-is $2.40. This is a single fare. In Sydney the same ride is $1.10.

Honourable senators would have to ask themselves what the Victorian Government is doing about this-or anything for that matter. The first thing it did was to commission a report, known as the Lonnie report or, as some people say, the 'looney report', which was brought down late last year. The report was brought down late last year at about the time of the Federal election. Certainly, that helped us to win a couple of marginal Federal electorates. I wonder what it will do for us in the State election. The Government picked a businessman who had no knowledge of the railways to undertake the inquiry. I am reliably informed that one night when his son's best friend wanted to be driven to a railway station in his suburb, Mr Lonnie did not even know its location. Mr Lonnie recommended the closure of country lines, country passenger services and suburban services. One would not have to guess very far which lines he was going to close down. He closed down the Altona line, the Port Melbourne line and the Gorae line. He decided to close down all the lines which ran into Labor electorates. However, he did close down the St Kilda line but I think that was because he presumed that Mr Dixon, a fellow aspirant for the leadership in Victoria, was going out anyway and it was a good way to finish him off.

However, the Government has restored some of those railway services on a temporary basis. A similar type of line goes into Alamein in Melbourne and sneaks into the eastern suburbs. That had a lower patronage than any of the lines going into Labour electorates but, of course, it survived the axe. That goes into Mr Kennett's electorate. No doubt the Federal Government wishes that had been closed down also. Earlier this year, in June, we had a series of hijacks around Victoria. Trains were being stolen. Everyone said: 'The union ratbags and the Labor Party rabble are stealing trains'. I can assure honourable senators that members of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party were involved in that. People in those areas felt so strongly that they hijacked the trains and held the Government to ransom. The Lonnie report has been a total failure in solving our problems.

I have to admit that the Government has ordered some new trains. Incidentally, we cannot have double decker trains because they would not fit into the underground. The Government is to spend $55m over the next 10 years on trains and we will get an extra three to five trains a year. However, the engineers made a small mistake. They made them 7.5 centimetres too wide; so the trains can only operate on a very few tracks in Melbourne. If two of them ran in opposing directions we would have a classic train crash. It is typical of the Victorian Government; firstly, we have tracks in Victoria that are too wide and that no other trains in Australia fit; now we have trains that are even bigger still. Thirdly-this is a rather sensational development which has occurred in the last few days-the Premier of Victoria has announced that there will be free train rides in Victoria on Sundays over the holiday period. This is an enormous concession to the rail travellers who use trains quite a deal on Sundays. One can wait at a station and every 50 or 60 minutes get on a train free of charge-not every 10 minutes or 20 minutes, but every 50 or 60 minutes. A person can get on a train and be bashed up by hooligans because no station staff will be used to man the gates, there will be no ticket inspectors and no one else. So one gets a free train ride, quite possibly to hospital. The end result of that will be a failure. It will be used to justify the closing down of railway lines in Victoria on Sundays.

The fourth thing which the Government does to improve the railways lines is to blame the unions. We are told that they are wrecking the system. However, in the last year man hours lost on the railways have dropped by 700 per cent. That is in one year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I wish to deal with the problems facing Brisbane Airport and the air traffic controllers. As I listened to the story by the previous speaker, Senator Robert Ray, it reminded me of the time that I was on one of Queensland's famous trains run by Bjelke-Petersen. Of course, having travelled on such a train, if one were to travel on the Victorian trains one would have to agree that the trains in Victoria are of a very high standard. However, I return to the points I wish to make about the air traffic controllers. The problem facing the air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport is of national importance and it is very important to the State of Queensland. If the Government continues with its policy in relation to air traffic controllers and if no remedial action is taken the situation will develop where Brisbane Airport, along with other airports throughout Queensland, will be closed to air traffic.

SPEECH.PARA: Air traffic controllers in Brisbane have a loss rate of 8 per cent which is double the national average. The national average runs from about 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. During a discussion of the matter at an Estimates committee hearing, I posed a number of questions in relation to air traffic controllers. It was claimed by officers of the Department of Transport that the loss of air traffic controllers in the Brisbane area was because of age. I continued to question the departmental officer about the problem facing the controllers and why such a loss rate existed in the Brisbane area. He repeated that it was because of age. Having had a discussion with the air traffic controllers in Brisbane, I know that it is not due to age. The problem relates to health. Ill health is brought about by the sorts of pressures that are placed on the air traffic controllers because of the shortage of staff and the growth of air traffic in the metropolitan area of Brisbane. The loss rate applies not only to the young air traffic controllers but also to the older controllers. The loss rate continues because of the pressure which is placed upon them and the number of hours they have to work because of the shortage of controllers, because there are no replacements and because of the density of air traffic.

The controllers are subject to transfer throughout the State to places such as Mount Isa, Cairns and Townsville. Other members of their organisation who are employed in the other States are not subject to transfer in the same way as those employed in the metropolitan area of Brisbane. The air traffic controllers at Brisbane work with inferior equipment. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has claimed that the equipment is not inferior but, in answer to a question which I posed in this place, he replied that the sort of equipment that the air traffic controllers were working with in Brisbane had been designed in the early 1960s and was commissioned in Brisbane in 1965. This is 1981. There has been no change in the equipment that the air traffic controllers are using in the Brisbane metropolitan area.

The air traffic controllers work under the worst airport conditions in the whole of Australia. Brisbane has the fastest rate of expansion of air traffic of any airport of the Commonwealth of Australia. Due to the understaffing situation many controllers are waiting for up to two years just to take normal leave. Because of the shortage of air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport it is not easy for people employed there to take their normal annual leave when it is due. There are not the men available to replace them during their period of leave. This is having a fairly bad effect on the health of the air traffic controllers in the Brisbane area. I believe this is one of the reasons for the increase in the loss rate at Brisbane Airport to 8 per cent, which is 4 per cent above the national average.

Not only do we have problems in relation to the air traffic controllers in Brisbane. We also have problems in relation to a number of airports outside Brisbane. I believe the Senate should be made aware of the problems that exist at the Maroochydore Airport. This is one of the smaller airports situated outside Brisbane which are too far outside the air space area to be controlled by the air traffic controllers at Brisbane. They cannot control the planes flying in. The transport planes fly in carrying people from the southern States. At the same time we find that there are also people who are learning to get their pilots licences landing and taking off. On the one hand there are the large transport planes flying from the metropolitan areas and on the other hand there are the small planes being flown in the same air space by people learning to fly to gain their licences.

The Maroochydore Airport is the gateway to the Sunshine Coast area. It catered for something like 42,000 passengers in the year ending 30 June 1981. It is probably as big as the Bundaberg Airport. Maroochydore Airport is Queensland's fifth fastest growing airport but despite the busy nature of Maroochydore it has no air traffic controllers at all. There is no control on the number of aircraft and their passengers coming into the airport. The air traffic controllers in the Brisbane area believe that Maroochydore is becoming the most dangerous airport in Australia but they cannot supply the control staff as they do not have the numbers. They do not have the numbers to run the metropolitan area airports so they cannot provide any people to go to the Maroochydore Airport. Queensland has 20 per cent fewer air traffic controllers per aircraft handled than anywhere else in Australia.

Not only do we have the problem of having no controllers at the Maroochydore Airport coupled with the growth of the airport because of the number of passengers moving in and out during the year, but also we have a problem-an inspection was undertaken at the airport-in relation to the fire hazards. During a recent inspection we found that only two fire hoses near the main terminal were available and one behind a locked steel roller door. No fire extinguishers were visible in the main terminal building or passenger approaches to the runway. No fire-fighting information was displayed anywhere in the terminal or the airport. No smoke detectors were visible. There were no automatic alarms connected to the fire brigade or the police station. It takes something like 15 minutes to drive from the police station or the fire station to the airport and that is if the driver drives at a high speed. There are no fire tenders, fire-fighting equipment or fire-fighting staff stationed at the airport.

The Department of Transport must make adequate fire-fighting equipment available, even on loan, until the airport management can get its act together and the Department of Transport must restrict air-space for commercial aircraft using Maroochydore Airport until the air traffic controllers are working there. We see advertisements in the southern newspapers advertising cheap flights to the north coast which land at the Maroochydore Airport with bus services to Noosa and Caloundra. We find that the cheap flights are being taken by people in the southern areas who are going to the north coast for holidays. There is an increase in traffic and it will further increase because of the advertisements being placed in newspapers by the airlines. We find that there are no air traffic controllers in the area and no visible means of fire-fighting equipment anywhere near the area.

In the very near future we will find that there will be a major accident, whether it be in the air or on the ground. If it happens in the air there is no way in the world that people will be able to get any salvation from the staff or the people who should be available to fight the fire that might be caused. If there is a fire in the area no one will be available. There will be no expertise, no knowledge and no training for people in the area who might be available. It seems to me that with an airport which is growing at the fifth fastest rate of any airport in Queensland and is handling something like 42,000 passengers a year, the Department of Transport has a responsibility to see that the number of air traffic controllers are increased not only at the Brisbane Airport but also at the Maroochydore Airport. It should also see that some training is given to people in those areas.

I do not wish to take too much time of the Senate. One other point was raised during the discussion on the Estimates and that was the point that the Transport Department was handing over control of the Cairns Airport to the harbour board. Fancy a national government handing over an airport in an area such as Cairns, which will one day become the prime area for international flights bringing tourists to the State, to a local board which has been set up and which is not even responsible to the State Government. It has very little responsibility in relation to its finances and probably has no responsibility to the Auditor-General. What other country would allow its national government to hand over responsibility for an airport to a local board which has been set up in the area?

TALK.START.PARA: —Chad.

—It would probably happen in Africa or somewhere like that. It might be done in those areas. It seems to me to be pretty irresponsible on the part of the Minister for Transport and the Department to hand over an airport which, as anyone must know very clearly, in the very near future will be one of the major airports in one of the major areas of Australia. It will handle passengers from overseas who are coming into Australia. The Minister has the hide, the gall, the lack of knowledge or the lack of foresight to hand over this airport to some harbour board setup so that the national government does not have to pay the expenses of running that airport.
—Who is going to handle the security there?

—One can consider the argument of security or defence. We have seen this Government today saying that we are going to have an Australian force sent to Sinai to try to maintain peace. It seems to me that it does not have any real sense of real responsibility to the people of Australia. The upgrading of this Airport would be a defence investment. That is one more reason why Cairns Airport ought to remain a Commonwealth responsibility, yet the Commonwealth has pursued a deliberate policy of neglect and has allowed the Airport to run down.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I would like to return to the Brisbane Airport, to what is happening in other airports and to the situation concerning the air traffic controllers. I repeat that double the national average of people are leaving the air traffic controller service in the metropolitan area. One of the major reasons is the lack of people being appointed to that area and another is the lack of recruitment of air traffic controllers by the Department. I think that emphasises again the lack of foresight shown by the Minister and the Department of Transport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commence my speech tonight by thanking Senator Button, on behalf of honourable senators on both sides of the House, for his sterling effort in upholding the institution of this Senate for the last 10 minutes or so.
—Considerably helped by the interjections.

—Considerably helped, of course, by the performance from Senator Rae. Seriously, I would like to address myself to the 1981 report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. In doing so, I address myself to a few problems relating to the housing industry. The problems, as we know, are many and varied and in the debate this afternoon they were raised in the context of a statement made recently, and one which has been made frequently in recent days, by the Victorian Minister of Housing. That statement was to the effect that the Federal Government has not been allocating sufficient money in the areas of housing, especially in the area of welfare housing, the area that we call public sector housing.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to discuss generally the federal problem, but address myself mainly to the problem facing housing in South Australia. The problem in that respect is highlighted very significantly in this report. In many ways this report can be seen as a vote of no confidence in the policies of the South Australian Government, both in the general economic sense and specifically in relation to its housing policies. We have had decisions from the Federal Government on three fronts which have affected the housing industry. We have had massive reductions in government housing outlays. In 1974-75 housing outlays were 3.9 per cent of total Budget outlays. In this financial year, as stated in the Budget recently introduced, the outlays now stand at one per cent of the Budget, a decrease from 3.9 per cent to one per cent. They now stand at one-quarter of what they were in real terms when Labor was last in government.

In the specific area of public sector housing in 1974-75 the Whitlam Labor Government spent 3.9 per cent of its government expenditure, and the amount paid out in that Budget was $392m. In this current Budget, the amount allocated for housing has gone down to one per cent and stands at $255m. It is no wonder that the Victorian Minister has lent his support to the call of the Australian Labor Party both here and in Victoria for increased funding in this area. One has to be in one's electoral office only one or two days a week to have constituents come in with housing problems. I have had quite a number of people coming in who do not have homes. I refer to people with families and to single parents of one sort or another who are in desperate need of housing and who, because of the specific policies of this Government and, in our instance, the South Australian Liberal Government, cannot find suitable housing to accommodate themselves.

I have mentioned government outlays. I cannot go much further without mentioning the deliberate policy of this Government which has led to continuing increases in interest rates and finally the impost of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on building materials. In this respect I should like to refer briefly to a Press statement issued by Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones, the National Executive Director of the Real Estate Institute of Australia. On 19 August, in response to the Budget, he said:

The impost of a 2.5% sales tax on building materials used in the construction of new houses flies in the face of the Government's stated priority for home ownership and is in complete contradiction to the findings and recommendations of the Housing Costs Inquiry, set up by this Government.
That Real Estate Institute representative gives the lie to the Government's policy. He refers to a stated policy of home ownership, and that is very much all it is at the moment.

I wish to turn specifically to South Australia because the report to which I am addressing myself covers the South Australian situation. We in South Australia find ourselves in a much more serious position than other States. The forecasts in this report indicate the seriousness of this position very strongly. The report refers to these problems on page 75. I will quote very briefly from it. The report refers to the decline in the rate of growth in housing in South Australia and states in paragraph 6.5.28:

These patterns are expected to continue over the coming triennium. Net population loss through interstate migration is expected to average 6,000 per annum (a net loss of 500 was assumed in the last Report). This increased loss is attributed to the high level of unemployment compared with other States and to people moving to other States with better job opportunities.

In one short statement this independent report prepared by housing industry bodies and all levels of government says that the housing industry in South Australia is gone because of the economic policies implemented in that State. The report continues:

This low population growth will be a major constraint on housing demand in South Australia. Furthermore, current economic conditions and prospects are expected to dampen the rate of household formation.

I can quite well expect some mutterings from the other side of the chamber to suggest that the decrease in the rate of growth in population in South Australia is not the cause of this current Liberal Government. In response to that type of interjection before it arises, I wish to refer to the House of Representatives Hansard of 19 August 1981 when, in answer to a question on notice on page 528, asked by Mr Uren, the Federal Treasurer, Mr Howard, issued a set of figures which showed that in the financial year 1976-77 there was an increase in the South Australian population of 3.9 per cent. In the following year, 1977-78, there was in fact a decrease, a minor one, of 0.6 per cent. In 1978-79 there was a minor decrease of just over 3 per cent, but in the first year of the Tonkin Government that decrease in population doubled to 6.9 per cent, and that is where it stood for the financial year 1979-80. In fact, the figures supplied by the Federal Treasurer, together with this report, show to what extent the South Australian population is showing its vote of no confidence in the current administration of that State.

I turn specifically to some of the indicators for housing for South Australia. When we look at them, we find that they all indicate one thing; that is, that the industry is in deep crisis and the crisis will continue. The statistics show that there has been a decline in the number of houses financed, in the number of housing approvals granted and in the number of houses commenced. For the first five months, to May 1981, 8,292 houses were financed in South Australia. In the same period one year earlier, in a period which felt the effects of policies implemented by a Dunstan and then a Corcoran Labor government, over 9,500 homes were financed. In fact in the first full year of Tonkin administration 1,276 fewer homes were financed than for a similar period the year before. Let us look at the amounts of money which were spent in the area of housing in that same five months period. In the term of the first five months to May 1980, $236.7m was spent. In the same period this year, only $225.3m has been spent. The figures in this area indicate quite significantly that even without taking inflation into account there has been a decrease of over $11m in finance in the housing sector.

I turn now to the number of dwellings that have been approved for construction, another figure which is provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In the six months to June 1981, 2,406 new private homes were approved for construction in South Australia. In the same period in 1980, once again a period which was very soon after the fall of the Labor Government and subject to the policies of that government, over 2,870 homes were built. Once again that indicates another vote of no confidence in the Tonkin administration in that almost 500 fewer homes were built at the start of this year than there were last year.

One asks oneself why South Australia is suffering in this way. As I said earlier, the report on the housing industry to which I am referring highlights two of the major problems in this area. I have referred to those problems and quoted from the report in relation to them. We do have the problem of population loss. The report makes a prediction as to the number of houses to be built, in view of that loss, in South Australia in the forthcoming year. A year ago, the prediction was that 9,000 new houses would be built. This year, the Association revises its assessment of the forthcoming year and predicts that only 8,500 houses will be built. That is the final, conclusive fact which emerges from this report, in its assessment of the Tonkin administration's housing policy.

I submit that the reasons are clear. South Australia does have poor economic conditions and a recessionary policy, but that is not an affliction of that State alone. It has been perpetrated throughout the country by the deliberate policies of this Federal Government, policies which have proven to be unworkable and impracticable in the United Kingdom. They will also, given the unpopularity of President Reagan, prove to be unworkable in the United States. Equally, I predict that they will prove-as is already evident-to be unworkable in Australia. That will be shown by the vote at the next Federal election. In respect of South Australia, the national problems have been heightened by an incompetent, inept administration.

I will merely refer to the summary of economic indicators which have a direct effect on the housing industry. I have mentioned population growth. In respect of the consumer price index, over the previous year South Australia has had one of the largest increases in Australia. I have already given the figures as to number of new houses financed. Another indicator that one may look at is the number of new motor vehicle registrations. In South Australia, the figure for the June quarter of 1981 was only 6 1/2 per cent higher than that for the June quarter of 1980. Throughout the rest of Australia, new motor vehicle registrations have increased by 10.7 per cent.

Retail sales growth in South Australia in the same period also lagged behind. In regard to the growth of job vacancies-an issue on which the Tonkin Government came into office with grandiose promises-there has been in fact a decrease in the 12 months to May 1981 of almost 29 per cent. Throughout Australia, there has been an increase of just over 19 per cent. The unemployment rate in South Australia stands at 8 per cent whereas for the rest of Australia it stands at about 5 1/2 per cent. The most indicting figures in this category are those that I saw today. They reveal that, in every one of the last 21 months of the Tonkin administration, South Australia has had the highest rate of unemployment in Australia.

In respect of employment growth, another indicator that is often studied by the Federal Government, over the 12 months period to June 1981, the rate for South Australia has been 1.6 per cent. For Australia generally, it has been 2.3 per cent. I do not know whether I am holding up anyone who may want to speak after me but I propose to end my remarks by making the point that I see this 1981 report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry as a massive vote of no confidence in the economic policies of the South Australian Liberal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening I heard one of my colleagues, Senator Coleman, speaking about air transport in Western Australia. I would like to take a short time to say something about air transport in the western parts of Queensland. Amongst the papers that we are debating tonight are some which relate to both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines. It is my opinion that neither of those organisations is really pulling its weight in rural Queensland. In fact, Ansett has almost totally withdrawn from areas of Queensland which are not on the coastal city routes; TAA is doing its best to pull out of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland is very dependent upon air transport, because it is such a vast State and highly decentralised. To give an indication of the size of the State in relation to other States which are south of it I will cite some figures. Queensland has an area of 1.7 million square kilometres. By comparison, Victoria has 0.2 million square kilometres and New South Wales some 0.8 million square kilometres, and is therefore about half the size of Queensland. In addition, Queensland is very highly decentralised. If honourable senators picture a map of Queensland, north of Brisbane they will find such major cities along the coast, or near the coast, as Gympie, Maryborough, Bundaberg, Gladstone and Rockhampton. From the Tropic of Capricorn north there are cities such as Mackay, Townsville and Cairns. Even north of Cairns there are major centres which, although not heavily populated, are important as far as the general commerce of Queensland is concerned. In addition, there are cities of note to the west of the coast. Toowoomba is a major inland city and Mount Isa is a very major city which is further inland. A number of other major towns are also well back from the coast. Therefore, in addition to Queensland's vast distances, this high degree of decentralisation makes air transport vital to the State.

I would like to give honourable senators an idea of some of the distances in Queensland so that they may know how far Queenslanders must travel and how dependent they are on air transport. If one travels from Brisbane to Cairns, as many of us in Queensland do quite often, one travels 1,435 kilometres. The distance between Brisbane and another major city, Mount Isa, by direct flight is even greater-1,580 kilometres. From time to time some honourable senators-I notice other Queensland senators in the chamber tonight-probably travel distances such as I will talk about in a moment. From Brisbane to one of the Torres Strait islands is a distance of 2,300 kilometres one way. That is greater than the distance from Brisbane and Melbourne. That should give honourable senators an idea of the length and the vastness of the State, which makes air transport so vital for Queenslanders.

In recent weeks the people of western Queensland have seen something quite remarkable happening. It has seemed remarkable to them because they are fighting for the survival of an airline in their area, yet they have seen TAA, Ansett and another major operator fighting one another for the Canberra-Sydney route. It is remarkable that those airlines have been competing for this route which, judging from the way they are competing for it, must be profitable yet in western Queensland people are fighting to retain an airline. The airlines have been falling over themselves to try to get the Canberra-Sydney route, yet they are falling over themselves to get out of western Queensland.

I want to comment about the services in Queensland and western Queensland. In general, those along the coastal areas of Queensland are reasonable. They are probably reasonable because they are profitable routes. The Brisbane-Cairns route is quite profitable. On a number of occasions, I have been unable at short notice to get a seat on a flight on that route because the plane has been totally booked out. There are some direct flights between the two centres, but there are more on the Brisbane-Townsville route, which is also profitable. Nowadays, with the tourist industry developing in central Queensland and the areas just north of it, the routes to those areas are also profitable. Probably one of the most profitable at the moment is the Brisbane-Proserpine route, which five or six years ago was not well known at all. Many flights go directly from Brisbane to Proserpine and some even go from Sydney to Proserpine.

In comparison with the good services that we have on the Queensland coast, the services in western Queensland are abysmal. I acknowledge that TAA is providing a service there-Ansett is not-but it is a poor one. I will give an indication of something that happened to me recently which is not atypical. I am sure that it would happen to a number of people who wished to travel to western Queensland.

I wanted to go to a meeting at Longreach on a Friday morning. I have my office in Brisbane; so I wanted to leave from that city. To be at the meeting at Longreach at about 10 or 11 o'clock on the Friday morning I had to leave Brisbane at about midday the day before. The plane made a number of stops and eventually got to Longreach at about a quarter past four in the afternoon. It was not too bad flying when I did a few weeks ago. But one can imagine what flying conditions are like in western Queensland during summer. It is not that pleasant to fly at that time of year. Nevertheless, I had to leave on the Thursday to be able to attend the meeting at Longreach on Friday morning.

By the time the Friday morning meeting was over, the Friday plane to Brisbane had left. It had left some time in the morning while I was still at the meeting. The next flight that I could have caught to Brisbane did not leave until the Saturday afternoon. So to attend a two or three hour meeting at Longreach I had to leave Brisbane about midday on the Thursday and I would have arrived back in Brisbane at about 6 o'clock on Saturday night. In fact, I thought of driving and I probably would have been able to get up and back much more quickly than by flying. But I decided not to drive because, quite frankly, some of us drive too much. It is a little less dangerous if one lets someone else carry one around in an aeroplane.

On that occasion that is what I normally would have had to do. I say 'normally' because I was a little lucky. On Friday afternoon following the meeting I was offered a lift back to Brisbane in a charter aircraft. I was able to get back to Brisbane on Friday night. I might mention here that I was quite thankful for the lift which was offered to me by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt. This arrangement was satisfactory for me. It meant that I was home 24 hours earlier than I would have been. However, any person who did not have that opportunity would have been away from Brisbane for a long time in order to attend a short meeting.

It is probably not so much people travelling from Brisbane who face this problem. It is the people from areas such as Longreach who have to conduct some business in Brisbane and then get back to their home town who face this problem time after time. They have to stop over in Brisbane as I would have had to stop over in Longreach if things had gone normally. This gives us an idea of the type of service which they are offered, a service which is not all that good. I might mention that if I had gone back to Brisbane on the Saturday afternoon I would not have travelled with TAA because the airline does not operate a service out of Longreach on that day. I would have flown back with Bush Pilots Airways Ltd. That flight would have gone from Longreach to Emerald and from Emerald to Brisbane in what is called the Metroliner or what the people at Longreach call the jet propelled pencil.

Three major areas in western Queensland are dependent upon TAA for their air transport. If we go west from Brisbane we have places such as Roma, Mitchell, Charleville, Quilpie, Windorah and Birdsville. That general area is dependent upon TAA for its air transport. If we go up into central Queensland from Charleville we have places such as Blackall, Isisford, Longreach, Aramac, Muttaburra and Winton. Those general areas in central western Queensland also depend upon TAA for their air transport. Then there is a third area from Townsville out to Mount Isa which takes in places such as Charters Towers, Hughenden, Richmond, Julia Creek and Cloncurry before going into Mount Isa. Those three general areas are heavily dependent upon the TAA Fokker Friendship aircraft which fly there.

TAA has said that it cannot continue to fly into these areas unless it receives a subsidy. Executives of TAA told me that there is no other way out other than that the airline receives a subsidy. If the airlines charge higher fares to try to recoup its costs it will then have fewer passengers and the whole system will grind to a halt. Nobody will travel on the planes and they will be withdrawn. In fact, some people in western Queensland now prefer to take a bus. People from places such as Longreach find that it is far cheaper to travel by bus to Brisbane even though such a trip takes about 20 hours. It costs about half as much to travel by bus than to fly.

I acknowledge the fact that the Fokker Friendship aircraft are probably reaching the end of their operational life. They are probably not as economical as we would like but they are the type of aircraft that is needed in these western areas. People in western Queensland do not want to see the Fokkers replaced by a plane which has fewer facilities and, probably more importantly so far as I am concerned, less freight carrying capacity. I will deal with freight in a moment. I will outline the reasons people want to see the Fokkers retained. First of all, they have flight attendants. One might ask why we need flight attendants. Children who travel on a service such as the one I described earlier which leaves Brisbane at midday and arrives at Longreach at a quarter past four in the afternoon and involves a number of stops need supervision. They probably sometimes need the help that a flight attendant can give them. A number of young children in these areas travel by aircraft. They may have to travel to school or go away for medical treatment. Sometimes they have a parent or an escort with them. Sometimes they travel by themselves. The people of these areas would like to see aircraft with flight attendants.

They would also like to see aircraft flown by two pilots. I notice that a Queensland senator has just come into the chamber. He is a pilot and he would probably be quite happy about flying in an aircraft with one pilot. He would probably be quite happy to pilot a plane himself in these areas. But when one is not an experienced pilot, when one does not know much about the mechanical aspects of flying a plane and one is travelling in these areas, one certainly likes to have two pilots up front just in case something happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —It all costs money.

—Of course it all costs money. I imagine that this is one of the reasons TAA is finding it unprofitable to be in these areas and why it is saying that it will be unable to operate unless it receives a subsidy. There are probably other reasons such as the type of planes that are being flown. It might cost money to operate planes with two pilots but at the same time it is much safer to have two people up front. For safety's sake, I would rather it cost money. It also costs money to provide flight attendants. However, I think that flight attendants are necessary in some situations. I will come back to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I have outlined the reasons the people of these areas want to see the Fokkers remain in service. They want these aircraft to operate until some other aircraft which is more economical but which has the same facilities and freight carrying capacity as the Fokker comes on to the market. One of the reasons I mention the freight carrying capacity is that during the wet the roads in these areas are often blocked altogether. Sometimes the railways lines are blocked. The only way of getting provisions into these areas is by aircraft. The Fokker has a freight carrying capacity which is useful on such occasions. TAA mentions that a subsidy is necessary. I do not think we should dismiss the idea of providing a subsidy in western Queensland. I am not quite sure what subsidy is necessary but some TAA people to whom I was speaking recently said that they would probably need about a $3m subsidy a year to keep providing the service in western Queensland. Let us accept that it is $3m or even let us accept it may go up to $5m. I would like to mention just two areas where subsidies are paid in Australia to provide people with transport, not necessarily air transport.

I noticed in the explanatory notes we had in our consideration of the estimates for the Department of Transport this year that the estimate for providing an air fare subsidy for travel on routes between Melbourne and Tasmania is $5m. In other words, the Australian Government will provide a subsidy of $5m to keep air travel between Melbourne and Tasmania on a proper basis. Even if we were to have a $5m subsidy for western Queensland it would not be unique. Coming closer to home I do notice that here in the Australian Capital Territory ACTION buses, the A.C.T. Internal Omnibus Network as it is properly called, had a loss of $11.7m on its operations in 1980-81. If ACTION buses had a loss of that amount it means that we as taxpayers through the Australian Government are paying a subsidy to the people of Canberra for ACTION buses to the tune of $11.7m-over twice as much as would be required for the subsidy for the western Queensland area network. I notice that the estimate for 1981-82 in the Appropriation Bill that was before us here this afternoon was put at $12.2m, so things are not getting any better here in Canberra. We are still paying out this money by way of subsidy so that the people of Canberra can have a bus service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you have a look at the South Australian railways?

—I have just mentioned these two areas. I do not say that there is anything wrong with either of these two areas. I am not quite sure of the amount of loss that you are referring to but within a reasonable level I do not see that there is any real reason to be upset about subsidising public transport. I must admit it seems a little high to me to have a $12m loss here in Canberra, but there may be reasons for it. There are many areas of public transport that do not have a profit-in other words, they run at a loss-and governments provide subsidies so that people are able to use those services rather than have to use other services such as a motor vehicle, for instance, in Canberra or the major cities. If we accept the fact that we are going to pay subsidies like this why do we not provide subsidies for an air service of the type that is required in western Queensland?

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I acknowledge the fact that the aircraft that are being used are probably coming to the end of their economical life. I am told, and other people would be more aware of this than I am, that there are aircraft coming off which would be able to replace the Fokker and which would be far more efficient than the Fokker. I acknowledge that some of the routes in western Queensland do not provide the passengers with a full service that some of the airlines would like to have. But acknowledging all those things I do believe that the people in western Queensland have a case for asking for some sort of assistance to allow TAA to keep its operations going in that area.

When the meeting that I referred to earlier in my speech was on the Minister for Transport was in Longreach and he was presented with a number of submissions from organisations in Longreach asking him to keep this air service operational. The people in Longreach, of course, were interested in their particular area but there are all these other areas that I have mentioned as well that deserve to have the air service continued. I was rather encouraged by one of the comments made by the Minister at that meeting. He said that he lent towards the idea of providing a subsidy. He could see the merit in it but he said he would have to take it back and convince his Cabinet colleagues so that the money could be made available.

The point I would like to mention tonight is that the people in western Queensland do have a case. Subsidies are being paid in other areas for public transport. Subsidies are being paid for air transport. If the Minister for Transport is convinced that a subsidy may be the way out, then I would certainly support him so that he can take that case to his Cabinet colleagues and see whether the money is available. I am sure that most of the representatives from Queensland would support him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell him he has got your support and that will help him in Cabinet.

—I think the honourable senator is probably being a little facetious with his remarks, but I was not. I do think that when this sort of thing occurs, when a group of people like this in Queensland are seeking support for what is a basic service, it is not only up to the people on the Government side to try to give the Minister support but also I think people on both sides should give the Minister support in trying to provide this subsidy. Whilst the honourable senator was probably a little facetious in his remarks I was quite genuine in my remarks and I think it is important that the Minister should get support from both sides because if he does not receive support from both sides-supposing he heard some remarks from this side which were disparaging towards this idea of a subsidy-he might have less cause to fight for the case as hard as he normally would. I think it is important that we have a bipartisan attitude on this sort of question because these people definitely deserve the air services and the subsidy to which I have referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
