The speech read as follows-

On 4 June 1981 the Government announced the Guidelines for the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the 1982-84 triennium and asked the Commission to recommend the detailed distribution of grants. On 24 September, I tabled Volume 2 of the Commission's Report, which responded to the Guidelines.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide a legislative framework for the allocation of funds following Government approval of the financial recommendations put forward by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in respect of State institutions, although some funds yet to be allocated for 1983 and 1984 will be included in subsequent annual amendments. The grants are for recurrent expenditure by universities and colleges of advanced education for the 1982-84 triennium, and 1982 expenditure for Technical and Further Education and for capital and equipment expenditure in universities and colleges.

Amounts expressed in the Bill for the 1982-84 triennium reflect new cost adjustment procedures adopted by the Government whereby, from the beginning of 1982, a prospective allowance is made for cost increases. Grants for 1983 and 1984 are expressed in the same terms, on the basis that each year they will be adjusted for further cost movements. The Bill also amends the existing legislation for the 1979-81 triennium to provide for cost adjustments in respect of the existing tertiary education program.

Before describing the detailed provisions of this Bill, I should like to set the Government's funding decisions in context. Notwithstanding our overriding objective to contain public expenditure as an integral part of the Government's economic strategy, there has been a small increase in real terms in the sums made available in 1982 for tertiary education.

Within the total funds provided for tertiary education there has been a reallocation of resources between the sectors. In real terms, while total expenditure in higher education has been slightly reduced by 0.4 per cent, funds for TAFE have been increased by 6 per cent. The additional funding provided for TAFE reflects the high priority which the Government accords to TAFE where enrolments are rising substantially and where important initiatives are being undertaken in relation to transition programs. The Bill provides for the continuation of a substantial TAFE capital program. In total 72 projects will be under construction in 1982 at 58 locations. Of these projects 35 will require a Commonwealth contribution in excess of $5m. In 1982 the Commonwealth Government will provide more than $112m for TAFE capital.

The Government has also continued to provide priority for higher education in the context of its overall budget strategy notwithstanding that enrolment levels have stabilised. In this context, the Government has noted the concern expressed by the Commission on the declining proportion of young people who are proceeding to higher education. The Government will be asking the Commission to undertake a more detailed study of this decline against the background of the enrolment patterns and prospects for tertiary education as a whole.

The Government has noted that the planning ranges originally proposed by the Commission earlier this year for enrolment levels for universities and CAEs, for the 1982-84 triennium, should be achieved.

The Bill provides funding consistent with the decisions taken by the Government for the rationalisation and consolidation of resources in higher education. The Commonwealth is firmly convinved that its policy of consolidation will not only improve the efficiency of institions and enable them to be more responsive to community demand; it will also improve the quality of education provided for students. Its program of consolidation was initiated following advice from the Commission, and the Government will continue to look to the Commission, in consultation with the States and institutions concerned, for advice on the consolidation and rationalisation of tertiary education. I am pleased to inform the Senate that of the thirty colleges of advanced education identified for rationalisation, at this stage acceptable arrangements have been received for all but seven. I pay tribute to the way in which State Governments have co-operated with the Commonwealth over the consolidation of institutions. In Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia, all of the consolidation proposals made by the Commonwealth have been agreed to by the States and action is in train in respect of the consolidations. Some particular issues in New South Wales and Victoria remain to be resolved, and I look forward to further consultations with these States on the oustanding issues.

In the meantime, funds for 1982 for those colleges of advanced education in New South Wales and Vicotira, for which acceptable consolidation arrangements have not yet been received, have been included in the legislation in a national unallocated reserve. Should acceptable consolidation arrangements be reached before the end of the year, the Minister, after advice from the Commission, will be able to allocate amounts from this reserve to the newly consolidated institutions.

Under the terms of the Government's decisions on rationalisation, the Commonwealth will continue funding for the Wollongong Institute of Education and Newcastle, Armidale and Townsville Colleges of Advanced Education only if they merge with the Universities of Wollongong, Newcastle, New England and James Cook University of North Queensland respectively. Allocations for Wollongong, Newcastle and New England universities for 1982 have been included in the Bill on the basis that amalgamations with the respective colleges will proceed. In order to ensure the maintenance of the two streams of tertiary education in these universities however, the minimum amounts required for teaching purposes in advanced education, as recommended by the Commission, have been earmarked in the legislation.

In the case of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education where acceptable arrangements for amalagmation have been developed, funds for 1982, 1983 and 1984 have also been appropriated in the Bill. For the other three universities and the related colleges where suitable amalgamation arrangements are yet to be proposed, grants have not been appropriated for 1983 and 1984. These will be provided in a subsequent legislative amendment.

Should suitable arrangements not be worked out by the end of 1981, it will be possible for those funds presently allocated to the three New South Wales universities for 1982 in respect of advanced education to be transferred to the national unallocated reserve. In those circumstances, the legislation would enable funding for the three universities and the related colleges to continue for 1982 only. Funds for 1983 and 1984 will have to be the subject of further legislation.
The Government would be able to make similar funding arrangements in respect of the other outstanding colleges listed for amalgamation to which I refrred earlier.

The Bill incorporates the funding recommendations for individual institutions and projects as recommended by the Commission. In some States not all of the funds available for advanced education have yet been allocated to particular colleges and the Bill provides that this can be done at the request of the States concerned. In accordance with the Commission's recommendations, provision will also be made to permit these funds to be transferred between years. These funds should provide added flexibility which will assist with the consolidation and rationalisation of higher education institutions that is already proceeding in the States.

The Bill provides for the limted reintroduction of tuition fees from 1982. The Bill specifically excludes the charging of tuition fees for students undertaking courses leading to first awards. It also exempts students who commenced second degree or diploma courses before 1982 from paying fees for those courses, and it sets a maximum fee, that is for full-time students, of $1,000 per annum. Subject to these principles, the Bill contains a provision for the Minister to make determinations as to the circumstances in which students are either required to pay tuition fees or are to be exempt.

Subject to various exemptions, to be covered by the determinations, students who have already gained a diploma or a degree, who enrol in a university or an advanced education course, will be required to pay tuition fees. Exemptions from tuition fees will apply, for example, where higher degree students are in receipt of Commonwealth awards or awards of at least $3,500 per annum from universities, colleges of advanced education and State Governments. The States and institutions have been consulted on the detailed arrangements.

The Bill will contain as a condition of recurrent grants that institutions charge fees in accordance with these arrangements and that they do not charge fees in other circumstances. The Bill provides for recurrent grants scheduled in the Bill to be offset by an amount equivalent to the money from fees which those institutions will be required to charge.

The Australian National University Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill, which are also being introduced at this time, contain provisions for the reintroduction of tuition fees in the same terms as this Bill, except where particular requirements necessitate differences.

The Government has considered the Commission's recommendation that the arrangements for the disapproval of new teaching developments should be extended to cover such developments regardless of the source of funds. It does not propose to legislate in the way recommended by the Commission but will ask the Commission to continue to monitor new teaching developments and to bring to its attention any examples of proposed new teaching developments funded from other sources which in the Commission's view are not in the best interests of the balanced development of tertiary education in Australia. I will also seek the co-operation of State Governments and institutions in this context.

In accordance with the Government's election undertakings the Bill contains a specific allocation of $16m over the triennium for research centres of excellence, and $0.9m in each year of the triennium for the development of community language courses in universities and colleges of advanced education. The allocation of funds to particular universities and colleges of advanced education for the development of community language courses will be approved by the minister after taking account of the views of the Commission and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Similarly detailed allocations for the research centres of excellence will be announced after the Government has considered the recommendations of the special committee established to provide advice on the implementation of this initiative.

The Bill provides an increased level of support for those non-government teachers colleges in the States which, until now, have been in receipt of partial recurrent funding. The two institutions included in the Bill, McAuley College in Queensland and Avondale College in New South Wales (together with Signadou College in the Australian Capital Territory), are not recognised as colleges of advanced education. The Government's decision to increase the level of support for these institutions is consistent with its view that freedom of choice in primary and secondary education is dependent upon the preparation of teachers with a special commitment to teach in non-government schools.

The Bill also provides financial assistance to the Northern Territory for advanced education purposes. Following an inquiry into the proposal to establish a university in the Northern Territory the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommended that an external studies centre be established at the Darwin Community College, and that subject to the agreement of the Australian National University, the North Australia Research Unit of that institution be given the capacity to co-ordinate research directly related to the needs of the Territory. The establishment of an external studies centre is currently under discussion, but funds for the proposed centre have been included in the legislation in the national unallocated reserve. Provision for the North Australia Research Unit of the Australian National University will be included in the annual appropriations of my Department.

The matter of additional financial provision from 1983 for superannuation for staff in universities and colleges of advanced education, which was recommended by the Commission, is under separate consideration by the Government.

In summary, the Bill provides evidence of the Government's continuing commitment to the development of tertiary education in Australia. Some particular parts of the tertiary education sectors have faced, and will continue to face, the need for substantial readjustment. This is required if valuable resources are to be allocated to the most urgent priorities. All Governments would like to increase spending on education-it is an investment in the future of Australia. Resources, however, are not unlimited, and the Government's decisions are both reasonable and responsible.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at the Australian National University. In addition to this primary purpose, the Bill provides for two other amendments to the University Act, requested by the University, concerned with aspects of the administration of the University. These relate to the election of undergraduate and postgraduate representatives on the University Council, and the granting of status and exemptions in respect of courses at the University.

In relation to its primary purpose, the same principles are involved in this Bill as in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill for the re-introduction of tuition fees. The three Bills are viewed as parallel legislation for this purpose and have been drafted in the same terms except where the particular requirements of the States Grants Act or the Acts of the two institutions necessitate differences.

This Bill is similar to the States Grants Bill in its provision which empowers the Minister to make determinations in the same terms and subject to the same general conditions, as that Bill. The same annual limit of $1,000 is set.

The Bill differs from the States Grants Bill in that there is no specific provision for the adjustment of grants to take account of fees revenue collected. This power is not needed in either this Bill or the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill.

Whereas the States Grants Bill places the obligation on the State, as a condition of grant, to ensure that fees are charged in respect of those students required to pay fees, in the case of this Bill this obligation is placed on the Council of the University. In order to give effect to this obligation, the Council is empowered to make a statute in line with the requirements of the Minister's determination.

In addition to its primary purpose, the Australian National University Bill also contains two amendments to the Act requested by the University. Clause 3 is intended to clarify the distinction between undergraduate and postgraduate students for the purpose of the election of representatives to the University Council. The Act provides for undergraduate students having two representatives on the Council and other students having one representative. Clause 4 broadens the power of the University to grant status or to grant awards to persons who have undertaken studies in other institutions. At present this power is restricted to students from other universities so that the position of colleges of advanced education, for example, is not recognised in the Act. Clause 4 similarly includes a power for the University Council to grant exemptions in respect of particular courses. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

This Bill is intended to provide for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at the Canberra College of Advanced Education and is a companion measure to the Bill to amend the Australian National University Act and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill in this respect.

The same principles are involved in this Bill as in the Australian National University Bill and the provisions of the Bill relating to the re-introduction of tuition fees are in the same terms. There are no additional matters covered by the Bill.

The Bill empowers the Minister to make determinations in connection with tuition fees on the same basis as with the University Bill and there is a similar obligation for the College Council to ensure that each student liable to pay tuition fees does so. The same annual limit of $1,000 is set. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — In speaking to the defence equipment statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) this week I say at the outset that this is one of the most important statements, if not the most important statement, presented to this Parliament in the three-odd years I have served in this chamber. I think the people of Australia owe a great debt to the Government for bringing down this statement. In particular, they owe a great debt to the Minister for Defence for the way he has handled this program with great care and great circumspection. Above all, the people of Australia owe a great debt to the evaluation team of the Department of Defence-the servicemen and civilians who worked for a period, in aggregate, of over 10 years in preparing the submission accepted by Cabinet this week. I also thank the Australian Democrats for their support of the statement when it was brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: A major part of the Minister's defence statement dealt with the selection of the new tactical fighter. This is a matter of fundamental importance to the defence of Australia. We spend a great deal of time in this parliament discussing internal matters, such as welfare programs and various administrative and legislative matters for the benefit of the community, and they are very important matters for us to spend our time on. But, over and above everything else, the defence of the nation is the primary responsibility of the government of the day. We have to maintain the security of this country. It is in that context that the defence statement must be considered. The importance of this statement is not just in terms of the aircraft selected but it will form a fundamental part of the defence of this nation insofar as the choice of that aircraft, which will be one of the main armaments of the Royal Australian Air Force for the next 25 to 30 years, will dictate the nature of the response we can make to threats to this country.

The obvious thing that this aircraft will do, as a fighter, is give us control of air space. It is axiomatic that if we do not control air space we cannot move on the land underneath it. That is very important to a large mass like Australia. However, the most important aspect of the new tactical fighter lies in the capacity it gives Australia to deter any aggressors. In that sense the strike capacity of the aircraft, which was the second string to the RAAF requirement, is in many ways the more important component of the two. In defence debates a lot of time is spent talking about strategic concepts. Indeed, when the Mininster's Defence statement was made, the Opposition spent quite a while discussing the lack of strategic concepts. It simply is not possible to define in specific terms what the threat to Australia will be. As General Sir John Hackett said in a statement earlier this year, 'once you define a scenario you always can come up with a theoretical counter to it as to why no move should be made along those lines'. The defence of Australia does not turn on being able to define precisely the nature of the threat. It is a matter of a general review as to what is the most likely risk that can befall us and of taking a broad approach to counter that threat. In very general terms, the threat to Australia from any aggessor comes either through the land bridge from Asia or through the sea. Therefore, the strike capacity of this new tactical figher is very important as a deterrent to any movement through the land bridge or in the maritime role.

Last year I spoke on two occasions in considerable detail on the characteristics of the two contenders for the new tactical figher force. With respect to Australia's needs-I emphasise, specifically with respect to Australia's needs-I indicated that in my judgement the F18 aircraft was the better of the two. The General Dynamics product, the F16, is a very good aircraft, if slightly dated in some ways. But in my judgment and in the judgment of the Cabinet and the selection committee it is not the optimum choice for the specific needs of Australia. I can see that it is a very useful aircraft for some of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, such as Denmark, for Taiwan and for the United States Air Force in an entirely different way, where it is part of a very large inventory. The characteristics of the F16 are that it was designed to be the simplest type of high technology dog-fighter to counter threats that existed during the Vietnam war. It is equipped only with the infrared AIM9L or AM9 missiles, which are a very short range dog-fighting weapon with a killing range of about five nautical miles. The whole design parameter is built around this concept. That means that its radar range is quite short; it only has to have a range to acquire its targets out to about 30 nautical miles to cope with the envelope of about five nautical miles for the missile it is fitted with. Above all, its basic design parameter was to be part of what has become known as the high-low-mix-the low threat in a situation where the high threat is taken are of by far more sophisticated equipment. In the case of the United States Air Force it is taken care of by the F15, which is the ultimate air superiority fighter that it has. In other words, this fighter was never meant to stand alone.

Last year I listed the defects in the aircraft as I saw them. I say again that we are not talking here simply about an aircraft; we are talking about a weapons system. It is true that a modern fighter has to have certain characteristics of performance with respect of its airframe and engines. It has to have range and manoeuvrability. It has to be able to carry certain stores and weapons. But it has to be seen as an integral weapons system with a navigational system, a target acquisition system, a missile guidance system and the ability to interface electronically with the missiles that it is carrying. That is very different from just looking at a simple airframe and engine combination.

The problems that I saw with the F16 were related principally to its target acquisition and missile guidance system. The radar fit was quite a short range system, as I mentioned before. It had not programmable signal processor with it; it is a hard-wired system. Basically modern radar systems rely on having a powerful enough set to get a signal out and a good return back and then having an on-board computer so that that signal can be processed through various modes and programs to extract the information wanted. That was not possible with the old F16 system. There were great difficulties in improving that system. The physical restraints of the size of the cross-section of the nose of the F16 dictate that it has a very small antenna size. I pointed out that the power output through a radar antenna depends very much on the diameter. A 10 per cent increase in diameter is equivalent to a 46 per cent increase in systems power.

Another problem of the F16 is the fact that it is a single-engined aircraft and the engine it has is a particularly unreliable one in service. Let me say that it is a very high technology engine. It is built to the limits of current technology. But, because of that, it is a bit overpeaked and it suffers from a reliability point of view, which has been reflected in the loss rate for the F16 in service, which has been paralleled by an in-flight engine failure in the twin engine installation in the F15s. It is a high by-pass ratio engine which puts it towards the civil type airliner engines, which gives it a very low specific fuel consumption on the cruise. However, this means that it has poor acceleration characteristics and when it does go on to full power, particularly in the afterburner mode, it uses a great deal of fuel. So, in that situation, range is compromised.

It is a very expensive engine to build and it roughly costs twice the price of one of the 404 engines in the F18. It is also a very expensive engine to overhaul for the mandatory replacement of certain parts. It has a problem on throttle response, particularly in the top left-hand corner of the flight envelope at high altitudes and low air-speeds. When it goes from either a moderate power setting or an in-flight idle power setting to 100 per cent power or afterburner power it has had a regrettable tendency to compressor stall, which is undesirable in a combat aircraft. The result of these problems with the F100 have led to a high attrition rate with the aircraft, which is very significant for a country like Australia which wants to run a long fleet life out of an aircraft. The production line, presumably, will close down half way through the life that we want from those aircraft.

The F16 has the reputation of being a very manoeuvreable aircraft. It is said to be a great dog-fighting aircraft but that is not technically true when one looks at its flight envelope. It is a very manoeuvreable aircraft in the low altitude mode, between 20,000 feet or 10,000 feet. But the type of fighting we envisage doing in the Pacific area is not carried out at those low altitudes but rather at the top end of the altitude spectrum. It has a control problem in that it has a limitation on its angle attack. In other words, the relative air flow is limited by the flight control system to somewhere around 22 degree to 27 degrees. That is a limitation in a fighting aircraft, particularly when one gets up towards its ceiling. If one is dog-fighting there and cannot go into all angles of attack, the altitudes that that aircraft can be put in are severely compromised.

All of those factors that I have mentioned have come to pass and led to what was known as MSIP-the Multinational Staged Improvement Program-by General Dynamics to overcome shortcomings that I have listed. It was on that basis that the modified F16, the F16C, was presented to the Royal Australian Air Force. THe MSIP seeks to overcome all of these problems. The essential point is that it will be 1985 before that program is fully flight-tested, evaluated and placed on the production line. There are problems with this. I do not doubt that Westinghouse will get to an acceptable level of development with its new radar, but there are no guarantees on that. It may slip on the way. When it will get there and at what cost is quite impossible estimate at present.

The design concept of the F18 was quite different. The time when it was designed was also quite different: It was a generation later. When we are talking about electronic developments today, time is absolutely crucial. The design concept of the F18 was to provide in the one aircraft an air-to-air and an air-to-surface capability with a one-man crew. There have been many fighters and many fighter bombers in air force service around the world, but all of those aircraft have either started out as fighters, which had the capacity later to be modified for the fighter-bomber role, as did the Mustang, or conversely with the Mosquito which started out as bombers and had the capacity to be modified to the fighter role as was the Mosquito. The F18 is the first aircraft that right from the drawing board was designed to perform both roles without compromise. It was also set out to be very maintainable, with low costs both on man hours and on equipment and with a very high degree of reliability. That was partly a consequence of it being designed for aircraft carrier operations for the United States Navy, because one simply cannot carry out the maintenance at sea that one can on land. It has a very high corrosion resistance and a very high degree of reliability in both the airframe and the engines.

Not only is it a twin-engined design but it also has two extremely reliable engines in it. They are the General Electric F404 engines. The design philosophy there adopted by General Electric was to set out to design something 5 per cent or 6 per cent below theoretically obtainable limits so that there was always a conservative margin left. It is an engine that has performed exceptionally well in service from a reliability point of view. It has also performed extremely well in the air. The engine can come right back to in-flight idle, go on to 100 per cent power with afterburners, close it down and keep moving the throttle as fast as one can with complete response every time without any compressor stall or any problems at all. It also has a low by-pass ratio engine with respect to the F100. That means that it accelerates very quickly and decelerates also very quickly. Those are two properties which are very important in a fighter. This gives the F18 the fastest acceleration of any aircraft presently flying. It similarly gives it the fastest deceleration. It is faster than the F15 until it gets right out towards the ultimate end of the speed range. The F18 has gone through its flight test program with no more problems than are normal with an aircraft of that type. The problems that did exist have by now been modified and corrected and the whole of the flight envelope has been explored.

In general layman's terms, what is good about the F18? First of all, it is a very well engineered aircraft, as one would expect from McDonnell. It has two reliable engines. It is a very manoeuverable aircraft and it is probably more agile than anything else in the top half of the flight envilope in excess of 20,000 feet. That is where we will be fighting when we use this aircraft in the air superiority role in the Pacific theatre. Quite simply, it has the best cockpit layout of any aircraft in the world. McDonnell has done an enormous amount of ergonometric work, simplifying all the systems and the control layout and coming up with a cockpit which is better than that in any other aircraft flying today. It has a head-up display system where all the essential parameters are projected on the pilot's windscreen. The symbology of this is far more advanced than anything else available.

It has the hands-on stick and throttle system where all the controls that are required to fly the aircraft to acquire the targets, and to launch the missiles are on either the left hand side or the right hand side of the pilot on either the throttle or the control stick. As I mentioned, the aircraft is optimised for both air-to-air and air-to-surface missiles. It has a fully digital electronic system. Most importantly, it has an effective ESM and ECM electronic counter measures suite aboard. There is no ECM capacity on the F16. If an ECM capacity is required on the F16 it is added in the form of pods-the ALQ131 pod or one of the other American systems. This is a great defect because any offensive situation will be contested and it really is an electronic war. We must have an ability to be able to detect radar signals, to analyse them to determine whether they are friendly or unfriendly, to find out whether they are tracking or guidance, to locate the source and to apply counter measures, either by a jamming or a decoy, within a fraction of a second; otherwise that aircraft will be lost to an enemy missile. An ECM capacity should be built into an aircraft at the drawing board stage. From an electronic counter measures point of view, the F18 is a top state of the art aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would be the Soviet opposite number to it?

—I think it would be the Foxbat. The radar of the F18 is the top radar in existence today. It can be outranged by the radar of the F15 and the F14, but the modes and the facilities that are built into this radar exceed the capacities in anything else flying. In fact, the F15 has been modified to accept the modes that are in the F18. Most importantly, from our point of view, it has a very good air-to-surface capacity-both air-to-land and air-to-sea. We have a great interest in having a maritime capacity in this aircraft. It comes qualified with all the ordnance in the United States Navy inventory, except the Phoenix missile, which is the missile carried by the F14. It has a range in excess of 100 nautical miles. Also it has a cost which is probably in excess of $1m for the one missile. It comes with the AIM-9Ls, the AIM-7Ms, the Sparrows, the Harm, which is an anti-radiation missile for taking out radar sites, the AGM-84A, the Harpoon and the GBUs. This is a very important difference between that aircraft and the F16. The F16 will carry all these weapons on its store stations on the wing, but that is not what it is about. One can bolt a 44-gallon fuel drum on to these wing stations and fly with them. The big difficulty is the electronic interfacing and the guidance between the target acquisition systems on the parent aircraft and the missile. That is where the millions of dollars in proving are involved. This is where the F18 has a great advantage, particularly in respect of the Harpoon, over the F16. It is fully qualified-flight tested to launch these missiles. It is also a very low maintenance aircraft which means, in peace time terms, that it will not cost us an arm and a leg to keep it flying. Of course, in a wartime situation that has a great force multiplier effect. In other words, this means that we can do the job with fewer aircraft than we could with an aircraft that was more manpower intensive. It has a complete suite of built-in test equipment so that the aircraft itself can monitor its own complex electronic systems.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to answer all of the charges which were laid by the Opposition-by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, in another place and by Senator Evans, when they spoke after the statement was presented. I view some of the charges which they made as being quite serious. I have always tried, on the occasions when I have spoken on defence in this chamber, to treat it as a bipartisan issue and to follow the example set by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). I do not see defence in terms of party politics. We are all concerned about the welfare of this nation. The security of it is the most important part of that welfare. The part that I took exception to in Mr Hayden's speech was the very clear implication that the selection body that looked at and reported on the selection of this aircraft, in his eyes, was clearly inadequate, not to say incompetent. I will not accept that proposition at all. The team consisted of a large number of highly qualified people. Service people and civilians were involved. They have been working on this program for nearly five years. Not all of them members of the Royal Australian Air Force. Certainly, all were not pilots. There were engineers, scientists, mathematicians, analysts, systems analysts of all kinds and specialists in the various fields. Thirty-six men were involved in all. Twenty of them were from the Air Force and 16 were from the civilian component of the Department of Defence.

There was also a considerable amount of support from the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and the Central Studies Establishment. Indeed, the Central Studies Establishment worked quite independently of the team that was examining these two aircraft and made four major reports. I do not know what was in their reports. The material is confidential. Presumably it supported the decision of the main selection body. I think it is very wrong for the Leader of the Opposition to attack the integrity of the evaluation team. What the team did will become a model for the evaluation of other aircraft by other air forces around the world. The team made its evaluation on the most thorough grounds possible. It was made impartially. Members of the team exhaustively considered every detail. They analysed all the information that was before them and they made endless model studies of attrition rates, serviceability and went through all the possible costing parameters.

If the reports in the Press are to be believed, the team overwhelmingly favoured the F18. I think the charge that Mr Hayden made that the Minister did not back up in detail how the decision was arrived at can be simply explained in terms of the fact that a lot of the information that the selection board used was material that is regarded as commercially in confidence. It was material commercially sensitive to the interests of both manufacturers, material which they made available to the Government of Australia on the clear understanding that it was for the information of the Government and was not to become a matter of public moment.

After attacking the integrity of the selection team, the central charge of the Australian Labor Party turned on the matter of cost. I regret to say that Mr Hayden fails to recognise that when one compares things one has to compare like with like. The Minister made the claim that there was a 7 per cent differential between the two competitors on the prices offered to the Australian Government. That figure accords with the figure presented to the Canadian Government in April last year when the same two aircraft were before the Canadian Government for consideration. Both of these aircraft were offered to the Australian Government by the United States Government in a standard foreign military sales contract with fixed price incentive clauses-that is, both a target price and a ceiling price were nominated by both manufacturers. Below the target price the contractor makes an agreed profit. Between the target and the ceiling price the contractor shares the cost with the Government. Above the ceiling price the contractor makes no profit at all.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make an appeal to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to ensure that the Australian Government will use any powers it possesses to smash the National Front which is trying to capitalise on the economic distress in various parts of Australia, particularly in the outer western suburbs of Sydney. It is trying to divide people on the basis of colour or creed. I think we can all learn lessons from abroad. There is no doubt that some of the problems the Thatcher Government has encountered with race relations developed when the National Front in Britain was allowed, under the guise of free speech, to prostitute that principle. I do not want to see that happen in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think my party has always expressed reservations in relation to the annual immigration intake. When a set number is applied and people come to Australia as permanent residents we will not condone people trying to divide other people on matters of colour or origin. That is the whole theme of this National Front. It is true that in the area concerned there is a very high teenage population and job opportunities are extremely limited. But those matters are not solved when people resort to the law of the jungle. As to the responsibilities of the Federal Government, I know that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Ian Macphee, has already written to Cameron, the No. 1 man in this National Front, making disparaging remarks about his views and pointing out what he is doing.

I notice also that Bishop Bede Heather, a Catholic churchman in the area, has also expressed concern in relation to what can happen. Whilst there might be a media bonanza for a couple of days, if riots occur and people are attacked because of racial characteristics and all the rest of it, a scar is left on those teenagers involved. Many of those people will carry perpetual feelings of animosity to other people who make up the components of our community.

I had the opportunity in a very minor way to peruse a report prepared by Commissioner Walker, who is certainly not a friend of mine, in relation to a dispute in the New South Wales railways system in an area in which the work was arduous. There was a question of favouritism or otherwise. In that case racial rivalries were found. In a broader ambit, I make an appeal to the Australian Government not to be namby-pamby about it. I know some people argue that civil liberties are sacrosanct. They are to a point but that should not mean that licence takes over from liberty. I know the views of the Minister for Immigraton and Ethnic Affairs and I know the attitude of the New South Wales Minister responsible for police, Peter Anderson. They certainly will not tolerate this sort of loutism combined with racism.

I want to direct my remarks particularly to this individual called the Skull who was featured in the Sydney Press tonight. He has been around a long while. In the days of the anti-apartheid demonstrations in Sydney and at the earlier Springbok tour he got his kicks molesting women demonstrators. That was one of his general ideas. I know of another incident subsequently in the famous election rally of 1972 which led to the election of the Whitlam Government. He was there that night. To the credit of the New South Wales Special Branch he was moved away swiftly. Whilst I have complete confidence that the Wran Government through the police will not have any qualms about grabbing hold of him and his friends and dealing with them as harshly as the law permits, the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility.

I say that because if we looked back to the 1930s we would see that we had one blot on our record. I refer to the race riots in Kalgoorlie in the 1930s. Surely we have learnt lessons about it. I go so far as to say that the provisions of the Crimes Act should be used. I say that being fully aware that that view can be distorted. The fact of the matter is that this Government from time to time has had recourse to proscribing organisations. If the principle is there it should be applied to blot out this neo-fascism. There is no question about that. It should be nipped in the bud.

We in the Opposition have had a lot of irritation. We have expressed and we will continue to express concern about the limited job opportunities among teenagers. We all know that the solution to the problem is not to accuse anyone else and deem them to be a rival regardless of whether they are born in Australia or overseas, whether they have different religions or whether they have different facial characteristics. These are things that have to be stamped out very quickly. I make a very strong appeal that the Commonwealth Attorney-General will use any Federal laws, if necessary, to harass this group and drive them into the ground. The National Front represents the dregs of society. When I look at this photograph of the Skull I think I have seen him around Sydney a lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Mr Ross May?

—Yes, that is. He has never done an honest day's work in his life. Way back in the 1930s the police smashed a razor gang by applying the consorting Act. Men like him have to be harassed all the time. The police should make their life a misery. I have no pity at all for those people. We should drive them into the ground in every way. I repeat that I know the New South Wales Government will play its part. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, has already gone on record as damning these people. Prevention is better than cure. I will leave the matter to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I spoke to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) before he left Australia. I hope the Acting Attorney-General will have a very close look at the law to see whether this organisation can be smashed and harassed. We could look to see whether the Skull pays any tax. Where does he earn his living? We could do a lot of things.
—He is an invalid pensioner.

—I would give him a medical examination to see what makes him tick. I am quite frank about it. Instead of worrying about harassing genuine people I would like to know just what income the Skull is paid. He should be fully interrogated. I make this appeal that this organisation be smashed by joint Federal and State organisations. This is not the time for the resurrection of the Hitlerite superiority of races. It is all very well to say that it is a nine-day wonder. We get more teenage problems in the western suburbs of Sydney. They are difficult and they have their counterparts in other parts of Australia. We have to hit hard and quick. I would like to feel that when I come back to the Senate next week I will find that by combined Federal and State operations the Skull and his friend Cameron are behind bars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about smashing the Government-figuratively that is-in relation to three matters of concern to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, although I do not blame him personally in that they are matters which relate to Ministers he represents in the Senate. One is a matter of a totally unsatisfactorily answered question and the other two matters relate to other unanswered questions. The Senate may recall that in mid-August there was a dispute involving the Australian Broadcasting Commission and broadcasting engineering officers. This occurred on the weekend of 14 and 15 August.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government required the ABC to implement stand-downs under the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act supposedly of those who could not be gainfully employed because of the ABC being off the air. In fact, the full crew of 24 in Hobart were stood down supposedly because they could not be gainfully employed. In actual fact the only difference in their duties because of the ABC being off the air on that Sunday night was not putting to air a brief news bulletin. Apart from that, they would have been fully and gainfully employed on normal duties involving the preparation of taped program material for the coming week, maintenance and all sorts of other parts of their normal duties. As I understand it the management in Hobart was quite willing to have them continue in their normal duties and did not accept that they came under the CE(EP) Act as being unable to be gainfully employed. Yet there was insistence from those at the top; whether it was from within the ABC or whether it was the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) I do not know.

I asked for an explanation at the time-this is two months ago-of those stand-downs. I suggested that the Government was not being honest about the matter and in fact wanted to lock out all the other employees of the Australian Broadcasting Commission because of the broadcast engineering officers dispute. After two reminders to the Minister, I finally received a reply last week that, in my view, was totally inadequate. The reply from Senator Baume, on behalf of the Minister for Communications, stated:

Full consideration was given by responsible senior officers in the ABC as to the staff whose work was affected by the BEO's strike. I am advised that, as a result, only those who could not be usefully employed were stood down.
I would particularly point out the phrase 'I am advised that'. I suspect that that is the Minister trying to avoid responsibility for the information in that, as I have said, it is quite clear--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister?
—It says that the Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. I refer to your colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Sinclair.
—That is usually the preface to a lie.
—As Senator Walsh says, we are never quite sure about what Mr Sinclair may say.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, following that comment I must rise to a point of order. Senator Walsh said: 'That is usually the preface to a lie'. Senator Coates then said: 'We are never quite sure'. I believe that infringes the appropriate Standing Order relating to imputations about a member of another place. I ask that both statements be withdrawn.
—Senator Walsh, I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw the remark that it is usually the preface to a lie; it is usually the preface to a statement that is not correct. It is habitually used by Senator Guilfoyle.
—Senator Walsh, that is not a withdrawal. You will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—I withdraw.
—Senator Coates, will you now withdraw?

—Did the Minister require a withdrawal from me? I am not sure whether I actually used the word 'lie'. If I said anything contrary to the Standing Orders, I withdraw. I was trying to show that the staff involved could have been gainfully employed-would have been gainfully employed-and it is wrong to suggest that only those who could not be usefully employed were stood down. They were all stood down en masse at the Government's instructions. I think it is wrong that that sort of answer is given to a question when there is a genuine inquiry about the method of communication between the Government and the ABC management in New South Wales and the other States.

SPEECH.PARA: The other two matters I want to refer to quickly concern unanswered questions. I refer to Question No. 998 and Question No. 1000 to Senator Baume representing the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). They were initially asked on 18 August. I know that that is only two months ago and that there are many questions on the Notice Paper dating back to the beginning of the year, if not to last year. The point about these two questions is that I believe there is no reason why the information could not have been provided to me by now. I think it is regrettable, to say the least, that it has not happened. Question No. 998 refers to the Government's plans for the Perpetual Trustees building in Hobart, which was bought by the Whitlam Government and which in recent times has been left unoccupied and without attention. I want to find out what the Government's plans are for this building. Will it renovate it or sell it? What will it do with it. The fact is that in recent weeks scaffolding has gone up around that building, so obviously something is happening there.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't been told?

—That is right, I have not been told. Obviously some plan has been decided on and some work is proceeding on the building. For all I know it could be being demolished, which would be the greatest crime that the Government could commit against that part of the streetscape in Hobart, which is a valuable historic intersection. In view of the fact that something is happening at that site, I think there should have been an answer to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1000 refers to the Government's staffing plans at the Commonwealth Government Centre in Hobart. I believe that the night security staff were informed by the Department of Administrative Services last week that they were likely to receive retrenchment notices by the end of the year. I do not know the exact details, but they were given some information about their future in view of all the rumours. Senator Mulvihill referred to this sort of matter in relation to the Commonwealth Government Centre in Sydney on Tuesday night. When I heard about this meeting I thought, obviously, that the Government had come to a conclusion about its plans and I was upset that I had not received an answer to the question in view of the fact that, clearly, the Government had come to some finality about the matter. On reflection, I thought that, fair enough, the staff involved should have heard first and not through some news item or an answer to me. However, I thought there should have been an answer within a few days of when the staff were informed in view of the fact that the question was straight forward. I would have thought that the Minister for Administrative Services could have provided an answer to that question as well.

I raise those three matters and express my annoyance at the way in which the ABC question was answered, totally inadequately, and in regard to the other two questions which should have been able to be answered but which have not been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two honourable senators have contributed to the adjournment debate tonight. I begin by responding to Senator Coates's expressions of concern, firstly, in relation to the answer he received from my colleague the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). I point out that when questions are put on notice for a Minister who is not a Minister in this chamber the answers which are provided by that Minister are not edited by a Senate Minister; they are put into Hansard on receipt from the Ministers who are represented.
—I was not blaming you for that.

—I just want to make that clear. I suggest that what is required in this instance is that we make known to the Minister for Communications the expressions of concern of the honourable senator tonight and seek a response for him on those matters. In relation to Question No. 998 and Question No. 1000, I will take those up with the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) with a view to trying to expedite a response and will pass on to him the expressions of concern of the honourable senator.
—You agree, on the face of it, that it is a bit rude?

—I agree on the face of it that they have been there since 18 August. I will make that known to him. Senator Mulvihill raised an issue of some importance; that is, the activities of an extremist organisation in, particularly, the western suburbs of Sydney, according to recent newspaper reports. He drew attention to two of the people whose names have been associated with the activities of that organisation. Like Senator Mulvihill, I have had the doubtful fortune of seeing the gentleman known as 'The Skull' at various meetings and have seen some of his behaviour. I have seen some of the reports of his appearances in court on different charges. That is how I knew he was an invalid pensioner; he is so described in his various court appearances. I will certainly pass on Senator Mulvihill's concern. However, I point out that the practice of totalitarianism in the defence of democracy is scarcely a defence of democracy, so that whilst Senator Mulvihill has called for stern action against these gentlemen I take it that that would not extend to putting them behind bars, as Senator Mulvihill hopes they might be by next Tuesday. I hope he would not envisage that happening without a proper trial, committal or anything else.
—As long as the wheels of justice move in that direction.
—Then I think that we are ad idem in what we are saying. I thank the honourable senator for bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate tonight.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Centre for Research on Federal Financial Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the cost to revenue of the Centre for Research on Federal Financial Relations: (a) in the last financial year; and (b) since the Centre's inception.
(2) Can the Minister describe any useful contributions which the Centre has made in the field of Federal financial relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Although the aim of the Centre is to research all aspects of Commonwealth-State financial relationships, the program of the Centre has concentrated on four major fields of study:
financial and economic analysis of the Australian and other federal systems;
criteria and machinery for determining the allocation of financial resources among Federal, State and local governments;
the impact of the federal financial system on major functional areas of government;
theoretical studies in the economics of fiscal federalism.

The Centre through its public lectures, conferences, and seminars provides information of benefit to all levels of government in the complex area of financial matters and their effect on inter-government relations. The Centre has also contributed to the work of the Commonwealth Grants Commission and the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

By ensuring that all research work is published thus allowing as wide a circulation as possible, the Centre contributes much in the way of guidance to the direction of future Commonwealth and State activities in this important field. Details of papers which have been published to date are included in the Centre's annual reports on activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Family Law Act provide that a separated couple can live under the one roof, be considered to be leading separate lives, and be entitled to file for divorce on the grounds of separation.
(2) Would the Department of Social Security regard such a couple as leading separate lives for payment purposes if the Family Court has designated them as such.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) To obtain a divorce, a couple must satisfy the Family Court that they have been separated for a continuous period of not less than twelve months. It is understood that, under the Family Law Act, the parties to a marriage may be held to have separated and to have lived separately and apart notwithstanding that they have continued to reside in the same residence or that either party may have rendered some household services to the other.

(2) Where a divorced couple are living under the same roof, the Department of Social Security would determine the pension or benefit entitlement of each under the Social Services Act on the basis that they were single persons, unless there was evidence that either or both were living in a de facto relationship.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that neither the Queensland nor the Western Australian government has any legislative obligation to publish the results of environmental impact studies conducted prior to the establishment of new industries.

(2) Will the Minister guarantee that the Commonwealth will retain full control of nuclear safety matters in any proposed shedding of responsibility for nuclear activities to the States and the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) On 5 June 1981 the Ministers for Trade and Resources and National Development and Energy made a joint announcement concerning the on-going review of the Atomic Energy Act and related matters. The statement noted the Government's view that the Atomic Energy Act in its present form does not provide an appropriate basis for the development, regulation and control of nuclear activities. Recognising and accepting its constitutional responsibilities, the Government has consequently decided to establish a new legal base developing, with the States and the Northern Territory, appropriate State legislation complemented as necessary by Commonwealth legislation, to ensure that national obligations and concerns are fully honoured. A principal Commonwealth responsibility is to ensure that observance of Australia's obligations under the International Non-Proliferation Regime. New non-proliferation legislation is to be developed as a high priority matter. The matter of a legal framework for licensing and regulation of nuclear activities in Australia is also being examined.

The policy of the Government is that responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia is to be implemented as far as possible by the States and the Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1981 (Hansard, pages 3192-3) Senator Grimes asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice, concerning services in Victorian hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The print media in Victoria has suggested that the Victorian Health Commission is looking closely at possible ways in which the services and facilities provided by private hospitals can be effectively used along with public hospital facilities.

As a result of detailed consideration by the Government of the recommendations of the Jamison inquiry the Government decided to introduce new health funding arrangements. The Jamison inquiry highlighted the fact that there is considerable waste, inefficiency and duplication in the States' hospital systems. The new arrangements will provide State Governments with positive incentives to manage the total supply of hospital services, both public and private within their borders and to seek to remove any waste, inefficiency and duplication in their hospital systems. For Victoria this should 'free up' resources without lowering the present standard of health services in that State.
The new health funding arrangements are principally aimed at ensuring that State Governments take up their proper responsibilities for providing health services.

Under the new arrangements the Commonwealth provides funding to the States for public hospitals, services previously funded under the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme through general revenue grants at the level of funding provided in 1980-81, plus 10 per cent, less a share of the revenue that the States can reasonably be expected to raise by the introduction of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges from 1 September 1981 having regard to new health insurance arrangements which came into effect on that date.

With the revenue increase arising from increased charges, the States that implement the arrangements fully will have at their disposal increased resources in 1981-82 and there will be no requirements laid down by the Commonwealth as to the services to which these resources should be allocated.

Under the new arrangements the Victorian Government has the responsibility to determine its own priorities in the delivery of health care and to allocate funds to individual hospitals in accordance with those priorities as it had under the hospital cost-sharing arrangements.

It is a matter for the States to determine how they will administer their responsibilities and explore, if they wish to, co-operative ventures with hospitals in the private sector. Such arrangements have operated in the past in Victoria, when public patients have been admitted to a private hospital as an extension of the public hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 629) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. By way of preface, I refer to yesterday's declaration by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that greater attention should be paid by all governments, particularly this Government, to industrial safety. I remind the Senate that, during the last session, Senator Peter Baume said that an interdepartmental committee was determining whether industrial safety in the Commonwealth sphere would be the responsibility of the Minister for Science and Technology or the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether any decision has been made. I would imagine that the Minister for Industrial Relations should be the one to look after industrial safety.
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Review of Commonwealth Functions decided that responsibility for industrial safety in the Commonwealth sphere would be transferred from the Department of Science and Technology to the Department of Industrial Relations.

The implementation of this decision has been the subject of a review by the Public Service Board in consultation with the two Departments concerned and preliminary findings have been sent by the Board to the Department of Industrial Relations for consideration.
Once discussions have been held between the Department and the Board, the review will be finalised and the transfer of functions completed.
